The Soviet Union has said Soviet forces only would be committed to a military operation under U.N. auspices. Shevardnadze later told reporters the Soviet Union would not consider committing any troops at this time. He cited painful memories of World War II. The Iraqis appeared intransigent. ``If war is imposed upon us by the United States, this will be our destiny,'' said Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari. ``Our people will not kneel, we will rise to this responsibility,'' he said, as Baker glared at him and fidgeted impatiently. Sitting in the council chamber below a mural of a peaceful world arising from the ashes of war, Kuwait's foreign minister said Iraq ``is pushing the region to a conflagration which we do not want, but which appears to be the only avenue to restore our rights.'' The Kuwaiti, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber, reviled the ``wild beasts'' from Iraq whom he said were pillaging his country and murdering his people. Iraq's ambassador linked his nation's cooperation with Western efforts to promote a general Mideast peace settlement, including a homeland for the Palestinians. ``Iraq calls for peace, it desires peace, not for us alone but for the entire Middle East region,'' al-Anbari said. Nine affirmative votes were required for passage. Any of the five permanent council members - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China - could have vetoed the measure. The other members change on a rotating basis. The council resolution strengthens Bush's hand with Congress and the American people in calling for offensive action against Baghdad. Hearings on the gulf crisis continued on Capitol Hill with criticism Thursday from former Navy Secretary James Webb, who added his voice to those questioning Bush's plan to send another 200,000 troops to Saudi Arabia to back up the 240,000 already there. ``The president's mistake in sending so many troops should not be compounded by a further error in using them in a premature, unprovoked ground offensive,'' Webb said.

DOC.HEAD: More Economic Woes: Welfare Rolls Rise
With LaserGraphic, PM-Welfare Caseload-List
DOC.TEXT: In another sign of a weakening economy, the number of people on welfare rose in all but one state in the past year. An Associated Press survey of welfare rolls in all 50 states found that only Wisconsin had bucked the trend, partly because it enacted pioneering programs to get people off welfare. Although a troubled economy was the villain in many states, it was not the sole reason - or even the most important one - in others. Officials in some states attributed the increase to changes in immigration law or to programs that help poor people apply for welfare. Some mentioned changes in federal Medicaid requirements that have brought more people into the welfare system. And some were simply stumped by the upsurge. ``Our economy is good, the employment picture is good, so we're not sure what factors are responsible,'' said Alfred K. Suga, deputy director of Hawaii's Department of Human Services. Hawaii had one of the smallest increases - 1.1 percent - in the number of households receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the benchmark welfare program. New Hampshire had the largest - 46 percent. ``Those numbers are startling,'' said Tom Pryor, an administrator in New Hampshire's Office of Economic Services. ``The primary reason that we see for that increase has been the decline in the New England economy.'' Elsewhere in New England, AFDC caseloads went up 25 percent in Vermont, 19 percent in Connecticut, 14 percent in Maine and Rhode Island and 10 percent in Massachusetts. The Southwest also was hard hit by welfare increases, partly because new immigration rules allowed more non-citizens to qualify for welfare. The AFDC caseload was up 9 percent in California, where nearly 2 million people were receiving benefits in September. It rose 23 percent in Arizona, 17 percent in Texas and 14 percent in New Mexico. Many states attributed the increase to their own efforts to reach out to poor people and enroll them in welfare programs. Some have adopted a ``one-stop shopping'' concept for social services, so that poor people seeking one form of public assistance are given access to others. Another factor has been a federal mandate that makes Medicaid available to more pregnant women and infants. This has caused huge jumps in Medicaid caseloads - they are up 46 percent in Indiana, for instance - and has also caused a spillover into other programs, such as AFDC and food stamps. ``When someone comes in and asks for Medicaid, we don't just check to see if they are eligible for Medicaid, we check to see if they are eligible for more services,'' said Sherron Heinemann, spokeswoman for the Texas Department of Human Services. The government has no current figures for AFDC caseloads nationwide. The average monthly caseload for 1989, the most recent year for which figures were available, was 3.79 million households. There are more recent figures for food stamps - the Agriculture Department says there were 20.2 million people receiving food stamps in September, up 7 percent from the year before. The Farm Belt and portions of the Deep South have come closest to resisting the welfare upsurge. Farm states such as North Dakota, Iowa and Kansas have shown increases of less than 1 percent, as have such Southern states as Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana. Wisconsin's AFDC caseload actually dropped 2 percent in the past year, and that came after three years of even larger declines. Officials attribute the drop to a strong state economy and experiments that require children of welfare recipients to stay in school and welfare mothers to work or attend school. The state provides day care for working welfare recipients. ``What we are seeing is the payoff of the efforts to encourage people to move from welfare to independence,'' said Elizabeth Snider-Allen of the state Division of Economic Support. The rise in welfare caseloads in other states will be costly. The federal government pays the entire cost of food stamps - an estimated $14.1 billion this year - but states pay anywhere from 32.5 percent to 50 percent of the cost of AFDC. ``What will states do?'' asked Marcia Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Officers. ``They'll just pay it. They really don't have a choice. ... And they will divert funds from other programs to do it, most likely.'' The rising caseloads also may mean that states will be less likely to increase eligibility or benefits for AFDC, which already are well beneath the federal poverty level in most states. In Alabama, for instance, a single parent and two children receive $124 a month in AFDC benefits. ``The money barely keeps them intact,'' said Tony Lee, a lobbyist for the poor in Washington state, which pays an average of $545 per month for families on AFDC. ``They stagger from one crisis to the next, the rent, the telephone bill, the lights. They just don't have the energy and everything else it takes to make it.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Facing Critical Test of Credibility On Question Of Gulf Force
With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council, for years divided and ineffectual, has been widely praised for its newfound courage in a series of bold resolutions aimed at ending Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But in its latest and toughest resolution adopted Thursday - authorizing military force to eventually evict Iraq - it may have undertaken its most dangerous mission. After successes in peacemaking and peacekeeping in Afghanistan, the Iran-Iraq cease-fire, Namibia, Central America, Western Sahara and soon in Cambodia, the United Nations has encountered in the gulf what may be the post-Cold War litmus test of its effectiveness. The last time the U.N. Security Council approved the use of force to redress aggression was in 1950 in the Korean conflict. Never before has the council acted so swiftly and decisively to counter aggression as soon as it erupted. U.N. resolutions have led to sweeping economic sanctions against Iraq, enforced by an air embargo and a maritime embargo. On the high seas, the council sanctioned the use of force to implement the trade embargo. In the Iran-Iraq war, the council waited seven years before approving Resolution 598 in 1987, demanding an immediate end to the war. That resolution failed to impose sanctions against either side. Iranian diplomats said Iraq probably felt emboldened by lack of U.N. action in the Iran-Iraq war when it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. In its 12th resolution condemning Iraq's aggression, the council Thursday voted 12-2, with China abstaining, to sanction a military strike if Iraqi troops do not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. Cuba and Yemen opposed the decision. Military action is sanctioned, but not mandated, and therein lies the rub, some diplomats say. If the United Nations and its members fail to achieve a peaceful settlement, which all of them say they seek, the organization will be faulted for lack of effectiveness. Failing a peaceful settlement, if there is no military followup, the organization and its members will be faulted for lack of commitment. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told the Security Council Thursday, ``We must not let the United Nations go the way of the League of Nations. We must fulfill our common vision of a peaceful and just post-Cold War world. ``But if we are to do so, we must meet the threat to international peace created by Saddam Hussein's aggression.'' He cited the conquest of Ethiopia by Italy in 1936, likening it to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Emperor Haile Selassie's appeal to the League of Nations ultimately fell upon deaf ears. ``The League's efforts to redress aggression failed,'' Baker said, ``and international disorder and war ensued. History now has given us another chance.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze told the council that Iraq's conquest of Kuwait confronts the council ``with the first extremely grave test of the post-Cold War period.'' No member of the council, he said, seeks a bellicose outcome of the crisis. ``But neither should anyone be mistaken about the collective will of the international community, about its resolve and readiness to act,'' he said. Former U.N. Undersecretary-General Brian Urquhart, a key player in peacekeeping efforts during U.N.'s lean years in the 1970s and early 1980s, called the council's effectiveness ``really an astonishing turnabout. ``I think this will be genuinely a turning point in human history, because this will be the test of whether collective security is a valid response to aggression.''

DOC.HEAD: Satellite Network Pays Fine For Hard-Porn Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: The operators of a company that once beamed pornographic movies to home television viewers pleaded guilty to a federal obscenity charge and agreed to pay a $150,000 fine, the Justice Department said. Paul L. Klein and Jeffrey Younger also promised to forever refrain from promoting or distributing sexually explicit films or publications, the Justice Department said Thursday. Their Home Dish Only Satellite Networks Inc., which once used a satellite to feed such movies as ``Hard Core Girlfriends'' and ``Ramb-Ohh Sex Platoon'' to 30,000 subscribers to its American Exxxtasy Channel, pleaded guilty in federal court in Buffalo, N.Y. HDO's guilty plea marked the first prosecution under a 1988 law that bars distribution of obscene material by cable or subscription television. Until investigators pulled the plug on the operation last March, HDO was the only nationwide satellite network beaming hard-core pornography to home television viewers, the Justice Department said. The movies were transmitted from the company's Buffalo office to a satellite uplink station operated by U.S. Satellite Inc. in Salt Lake City, that relayed them to the GTE Spacenet Corp. satellite, the Justice Department said. In Buffalo, the company pleaded guilty to one felony count of transmitting an obscene promotional movie, ``Hot Shorts,'' on Feb. 25, 1990 from Buffalo. It also agreed to plead guilty to a separate felony charge in Salt Lake City, Utah, of transmitting the movie ``Hardcore Girlfriends'' the next day.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He's Not Considering Draft
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he has no plans to ask Congress to reinstitute the draft because the nation's all-volunteer army ``is as strong as it can be.'' In an interview at the White House with Univision, the Spanish language network, Bush said he was ``definitely not'' considering bringing back the draft. ``Because we don't need it. We have an all-volunteer army. It is as strong as it can be,'' the president said. ``We don't need a draft.'' Bush also said he wanted to confer further with congressional leaders on the subject of a possible ``lame duck'' session of Congress to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. He meets Friday with congressional leaders. ``I am very anxious to know what they think would be productive because it is important that we send a solid signal,'' Bush said. The president indicated he was not considering calling Congress back into session and would prefer not to do so.
DOC.HEAD: Darman Stands By Speech; Gingrich Says Darman Should Resign
DOC.TEXT: The White House says budget director Richard Darman and Rep. Newt Gingrich have settled differences, but Darman is standing behind a speech that enraged the Georgia Republican and other GOP conservatives. Darman, in a Nov. 16 speech, ridiculed efforts by administration conservatives to promote self-help programs for the poor as a major Bush domestic initiative next year. On Wednesday, Gingrich, the House Republican Whip, accused Darman of making ``an assault on members of his own party'' and said the budget director should either recant or resign. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that Darman and Gingrich spoke by telephone for 45 minutes and smoothed over their differences. ``Director Darman and Newt had a long conversation this morning and they are great and good friends, and there's no problem,'' Fitzwater said. However, Fitzwater said Darman was not withdrawing the comment he made in his speech and a Gingrich spokesman said ``Newt stands by his earlier statement.'' Tony Blankley, Gingrich's press secretary, said the two have agreed to try to resolve their policy differences.

DOC.HEAD: Efforts to Turn Historic Ship Into Museum Nearly Sink American Legion Post
DOC.TEXT: Kamikaze pilots couldn't sink the USS Cabot in World War II, but a lawsuit, a fire, costly repairs and red tape nearly scuttled both the aircraft carrier and an American Legion chapter. The rustbucket's fate is still in doubt, but with a $2 million grant recently approved by Congress, members of American Legion Post 377 say it now looks like the venerable warship will win its last battle. ``Just about everybody else thinks we're crazy, but someday this will be a first-class naval museum and everyone that sees it will be proud,'' said Gordon Pfluger, Legion post commander. The post's efforts to acquire the ship and convert it into a museum have put it $750,000 in debt and entangled it in a lawsuit with another group that had plans to use at least part of the vessel as a floating casino. The ship was taken over by federal marshals after Carter Green Redd Inc. of Gulfport, Miss., sued for return of $47,000 it said it paid for the rights to open a casino. Blaine Kern, a member of the foundation created to run the ship, said the casino plan was nixed after the Spanish government, which last owned the vessel, objected. He said a settlement with Carter Green Redd Inc. is being pursued. The ship, commissioned in 1943, saw service in the Pacific until the end of World War II, surviving two kamikaze attacks. Its crew earned nine battle stars and the Presidential Unit Citation for extraordinary heroism in action. In 1967, the Cabot was transferred to the Spanish government and became the SNS Dedalo, flagship of the Spanish navy. It was retired last year. ``It was sitting there just rusting away,'' said Legion member Herb Wagner. ``The Spanish government said that if we would use it as a joint Spanish-American museum, we could have it.'' In 1989, the carrier steamed up the Mississippi River to New Orleans where it was presented to the Cabot-Dedalo Museum Foundation, made up of Kern, members of the Legion post, and others. But when the foundation tried to dock the ship across from the city's famous French Quarter, the Coast Guard balked. ``The currents along the west bank of the river are too strong,'' Pfluger said. So the ship sits at a condemned wharf, where Wagner said it is racking up $1,000 a day in docking fees. Its electricity was shut off when the foundation couldn't pay a $4,100 bill, and it caught fire earlier this year, about the time the federal government declared it a National Landmark. The fire caused $15,000 damage. The fire damage is covered by insurance, Wagner said, but the foundation owes the insurance company $40,000. When all the financial problems are sorted out the Legion hopes to move the ship to nearby Kenner and begin renovations. ``We can't afford to quit now,'' Wagner said. ``We've got too much in this thing. We've raised and spent three quarters of a million dollars and we only have 89 members. We've done everything but hold up convenience stores. Do you know how many bingo games we've held?''

DOC.HEAD: 80 Foreigners, Mostly Swedes, Leave Iraq
With PM-Gulf-UN
DOC.TEXT: About 80 foreigners, most of them Swedes, left today aboard a chartered Iraqi Airways flight bound for Stockholm, airport sources said. The flight included 65 Swedes, five Britons and and five Finns, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said five or six other Westerners were on the flight, but that their nationalities were not immediately known. Iraq has said that Swedes trapped by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait may leave if they wish. The Swedish Embassy in Baghdad said Thursday two of its nationals have opted to stay. All the other Swedes who had been stranded in Kuwait or Iraq since the invasion were on today's charter. President Saddam Hussein banned all foreigners from traveling in response to a U.S.-led multinational military buildup against Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait. But various groups of foreigners have since been allowed to leave at the intervention of former or current politicians from their countries or humanitarian organizations. About 1,300 Britons remain in stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, 350 of them interned at vital installations as human shields. Some 250 other foreigners, mainly Americans, also are being held in the so-called human shields to guard against a possible attack by the multinational force in the Persian Gulf. Meanwhile, the National Assembly, in a late Thursday night session endorsed a call by Saddam to allow all Belgians to leave. About 30 Belgians were stranded by the invasion, five of them remain in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-UN,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``It will go around the world loud and clear that this guy's got to get out of there.'' - President Bush on the U.N. Security Council resolution setting a Jan. 15 deadline for Saddam Hussein to give up Kuwait and free foreign hostages, or face military action. --- ``No one can accuse the council of impatience. The military option is reality, not bluff.'' - British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. --- ``We do not underestimate American military power, but we scorn their evil intentions.'' Saddam, declaring Iraq is ready for war.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Surges Sharply Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar surged sharply against the yen Friday, as market players sought a safe investment after the U.N. Security Council adopted a resolution to permit the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. The weaker yen and possibility of war in the Middle East helped push share prices down, dealers said. The dollar closed at 132.75 yen, up 2.60 yen from Thursday's close of 130.15. After opening at 133.70 yen, it ranged from 132.40 to 133.85 yen in active trading totaling $18.44 billion. The dollar is traditionally seen as a safe investment in times of international tensions, while the yen is weakened by possibility of war in the gulf because Japan imports virtually all its oil. The dollar's jump followed its overnight advance in New York, where it closed at 133.25 yen as investors anticipated the U.N. decision. But buying slowed after the dollar hit the mid-133-yen levels and a move to buy back the yen resurfaced, traders said. ``There is still a fundamental sense that the American economy is in bad shape,'' said Yoshiyuki Kawai, a foreign exchange dealer at the Tokai Bank. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 22,454.63 points, down 257.97 points or 1.14 percent from Thursday's finish of 22,712.60 points. Volume on the first section was 320 million shares, up from 300 million shares Thursday. Takuo Futamura of Sanyo Securities said the market's bearish sentiments in the face of Middle East tensions resembled the way share prices drooped during Emperor Hirohito's illness before his death in January 1989. Investors are also wary of the declining trend in Japan's economy, he said. ``We see severe times ahead,'' said a dealer at Cosmo Securities, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 86.31 points as of 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Thursday's close of 86.11 points. Their yield fell to 7.425 percent from 7.480 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Forecast Produces Fear, Frivolity
DOC.TEXT: People from Illinois to Arkansas are divided over whether a climatologist's scientifically shaky forecast of an earthquake during the next few days is cause to party or reason to get all shook up. In some places, schools are closing. Disaster drills are being staged. Sales of bottled water, canned food and earthquake insurance have jumped. ``I think we have everything in place,'' said Elaine Van Horn of Memphis, a believer whose family joined 11 others to put up a stockpile of emergency food and camping gear. ``We've been working on this probably since about August.'' Others are amused. A rock band called the Rhythm Hounds planned a ``Shake, Rattle and Quake'' night Sunday at the P&H Cafe, a Memphis beer hall. A pub called Zinnie's East advertised half-price specials Monday at an ``It's Your Fault Earthquake Party.'' In Falls City, Neb., the owner of a variety store recently ran this advertisement: ``It's New Madrid's Fault: It's an Earthquake Sale, Nov. 26 to Dec. 8, if we're still here. We're shaking down our prices.'' E-Day, if you will, is sometime around Monday. That's according to New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning, who last summer said there was a 50 percent chance of a strong quake on the New Madrid Fault within 48 hours on either side of Dec. 3. The fault runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark., about 35 miles east of Memphis. ``It's nonsense,'' said Brian Mitchell, director of the Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at St. Louis University. An advisory panel to the U.S. Geological Survey said Browning's forecast has no scientific merit. That word was tempered, however, with the warning that a quake could happen at any time. It's just that Dec. 3 has no special significance, the panel said. Memphis, with 650,000 residents, is the closest big city to the fault, which produces more than 200 small earthquakes a year. Scientists give a 60 percent chance of a strong New Madrid temblor over the next 15 years. Over 50 years, the probability is better than 90 percent. But scientists say no one can predict the exact day of an earthquake. Schools in parts of Tennessee, Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky and Illinois canceled classes early next week. Officials at those schools, generally in small towns and rural areas, say attendance would be low if classes were held. Earthquake disaster drills have been staged throughout the region, and many businesses expect more workers than usual to be absent on Monday. Don Wood, a spokesman for the Memphis and Shelby County Emergency Management Agency, said some residents apparently will leave the area for a few days. ``I know people who say they're going to New Orleans and wonder if the Mississippi River will flood them down there if the earthquake hits here,'' Wood said. Browning, 72, bases his theory on the gravitational pull of the sun and moon, which he says will be particularly strong during the prediction period. If the New Madrid Fault does produce a strong quake one of these days, it will likely be in the low 6-range on the Richter scale, scientists say. A quake of that magnitude could cause serious damage. The fault produced a series of such earthquakes in 1811 and 1812, their strength estimated at 8.0 or higher on the Richter scale, which did not exist at the time. They were the strongest earthquakes in U.S. history.

DOC.HEAD: Nordics Ready for Soviet Refugees and Prepare for Worst
DOC.TEXT: Scandinavians have plans to quickly erect refugee camps and reinforce their borders if a predicted harsh winter brings a tide of Soviet refugees, officials say. But the Nordic countries are also readying food aid, with the hope that if the Soviets are well-fed at home, they'll stay there. ``Our policy is to feed them ... so they don't have to come across the border at all,'' said Asko Mattila, a Finnish Foreign Ministry official. ``A worst, worst-case scenario, with a great migration, like wolf packs welling over the border ... is not something we regard as possible,'' said Bjorn Blokhus of the Norwegian Foreign Ministry. A legislator in Moscow told Nordic parliamentarians last month that up to 6 million Soviet refugees could head west in search of better living conditions. Soviet officials say they have enough food, but haven't been able to distribute it properly. Germany, motivated by wishes for Soviet stability as well as gratitude for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's role in German unification, has committed $19.5 billion in aid and credits to Moscow. On Thursday Bonn decided to give the Soviets the $340 million in food and medical supplies that were stockpiled in West Berlin after the 1948-49 Berlin Blockade. Swedish officials have developed a plan to put up emergency shelters and extra security that could go into effect within 24 hours. It is described as an operation of last resort. Swedish Immigration Minister Maj-Lis Louw said the way to prevent a flood of economic refugees is to make it clear ahead of time they will not be accepted in Scandinavia, long known for generous asylum laws. Danish Foreign Minister Uffe Ellemann-Jensen said the migration of Soviet and Eastern European citizens could dwarf current refugee problems. ``This problem will place huge demands on our resources,'' he said. Although neither Denmark nor Sweden border the Soviet Union, refugees could enter by ferry across the Baltic Sea. The recent arrival in Finland of hundreds of Somalis who flew from Africa through Moscow gave Nordic leaders a glimpse of what could happen when the Soviet Union ends travel restrictions on its citizens. The Norwegian military has announced it is prepared to donate the food, tents and medicines it has stockpiled for war to refugees who might want to cross the 70-mile arctic border with the Soviet Union. ``In a military sense, I don't think it (a Soviet food shortage) has much significance, unless a civil war breaks out. And of course, that is possible,'' said Dagfinn Danielsen, the northern Norwegian military commander. Finnish officials deny news reports they plan to build refugee camps or increase guards along the 800-mile border, the longest any Western nation shares with the Soviet Union. ``We don't even consider it a possibility that thousands of Soviets will rush across our border,'' said Gen. Matti Autio, commander of the border guard. But the Finns will send thousands of tons of meat and potatoes to the Soviet province of Karelia, which partly belonged to Finland before World War II. The food shipment is a commercial deal, though, not charity. ``I know those people very well. They are very hardy and a mere food shortage is not going to drive them over here,'' said Teuvo Korpelainen, county mayor in Tohmajarvi, 10 miles from the Soviet border. Forecasts say temperatures may fall below minus 40 degrees this winter in Karelia. ``It's the cold that will do it, if anything,'' said Korpelainen. ``If they run out of heating oil and the temperature falls to minus 40 degrees, then we'll see them over here.'' In 1989, Finnish officials issued 65,000 visas to Soviets. More than 200,000 have already been issued this year, because Moscow has eased travel restrictions. Three new border posts have been temporarily opened, but Autio said the 3,600-man guard force would not be strengthened. ``We can manage with the men we have,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper's Lawsuit Accuses Drivers of Violent Conspiracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to RESTORE `million.'
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News has filed a $150 million racketeering lawsuit accusing its striking unions of using violence in an organized effort to win their demands or force the sale of the newspaper. The lawsuit, filed Thursday in federal court, claims the alleged conspiracy included attempted murder, arson and robbery. Police officials have said they found no evidence of a conspiracy in 229 incidents during the 5-week-old strike. The lawsuit claims strikers are using violence to achieve one of two goals: forcing the tabloid into accepting wasteful contracts or making it accept a union buyout plan. Named as defendants are the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union of New York and Vicinity; the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group representing the nine striking unions, and 23 drivers. Theodore Kheel, the unions' unpaid legal adviser, said ``the underpinning of this lawsuit was blown out of the water'' at a state legislative hearing Monday when police officials testified they had found no conspiracy. Nine of the tabloid's 10 unions representing some 2,100 strikers began a walkout Oct. 25. The paper has published daily, but distribution has been spotty, advertisers have pulled out and delivery trucks and newsstands have been attacked. The lawsuit seeks $50 million in damages, which can be tripled under racketeering law to $150 million if the newspaper wins.

DOC.HEAD: Guilt, Gratitude and Worry Behind German Generosity to Soviets
With PM-Scandinavia-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The German rush to help the Russians stave off a hungry winter is rooted in the generosity of a wealthy country, worry over a return to Stalinism in Moscow and a frank admission of German guilt for World War II. Above all, Germany is thanking Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev for not blocking the unification of East and West Germany. ``We know that on this difficult path to unity you were with us, you helped us, and we are grateful,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl said in a speech welcoming Gorbachev to Germany early this month. Although Gorbachev appealed publicly for more aid during his visit, the German government was at first reluctant. Germany already had committed a whopping $19.5 billion in aid and credits to Moscow, largely to finance the withdrawal of Soviet troops from the formerly Communist eastern part of Germany. On Thursday, however, Germany took a step that gave rich meaning to the treaty of friendship, non-aggression and cooperation that Gorbachev and Kohl signed on Nov. 9, the first anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall. The government decided to give the Soviets the mass of foodstuffs and medical supplies that were built up in West Berlin against a repeat of the 1948-49 Berlin Blockade, in which Josef Stalin tried to starve the West's isolated island in Berlin. The government values the reserve at $340 million. Kohl, in this decision, appeared to be several steps behind the public, especially in Berlin, where the suggestion arose almost two weeks earlier to give the Soviets the ``Berlin Reserve.'' On Thursday, a planeload of 25,000 pre-packaged meals for children's hospitals and orphanages flew from Hanover to Moscow in the first shipment by German charities aimed at easing the chaotic food situation in the Soviet Union. Organizers say the relief airlift will fly every day, an echo of the immense U.S. and British airlift that saved West Berlin four decades earier. At the same time, the mass-circulation Bild newspaper started its own campaign - ``A Heart for Russia'' - encouraging the public to assemble aid packets or donate $34 (50 marks) minimum to a special Red Cross fund for Soviet hunger relief. Stefan Gaensicke, spokesman for the Axel Springer publishers that own Bild, said the campaign sprang from the company's ``lone crusade since 1958'' for German unity. ``When it finally came about, we knew damn well to whom we really owe it all, to the man in Moscow who said, `It makes sense, we'll have to let the East Germans go,' '' Gaensicke said. On Wednesday the grass-roots campaign took on an official character. Kohl went on ZDF television to appeal for donations. The ZDF program showed empty Soviet stores, Russian women fighting over blocks of cheese, and an expose of the blackmarketeers who steal food, sometimes letting it rot if they can't sell it. Stern magazine, allied with ZDF in the campaign, said Thursday it was donating $340,000. Stern called on all Germans to help rescue 20 million to 50 million Soviets from a ``Hunger Winter.'' ``It is a commandment of humanity. Especially for us Germans, who inflicted immeasurabee suffering on those people in World War II. Twenty-six million Soviet citizens lost their lives,'' the weekly's editorial said. It reported that some Soviets now say that under Stalin they at least had bread, if not freedom. ``We cannot permit a new Stalin to take power in the Kremlin, just because the hungry are screaming for bread,'' Stern said. The German union of war-wounded and handicapped people, which has 500,000 members, is supervising the delivery of aid packets to old people's homes, groups of the handicapped and families with small children. The German shippers' organization put out a call to its members for trucks and expertise in surmounting the road, rail and bureaucratic bottlenecks in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Harry Caudill, Appalachian Author, Dead at 68
DOC.TEXT: Harry M. Caudill, an author whose 1963 expose of Appalachia's social and enviromental problems helped inspire President Lyndon Johnson's War on Poverty in the 1960s, shot himself to death at age 68. The muckraking writer, lawyer, historian and state lawmaker died Thursday. A friend said Caudill suffered from Parkinson's disease and a World War II injury to his foot and had been depressed. Caudill's writings helped shape federal programs to control strip mining, improve mine safety and eradicate poverty. His ``Night Comes to the Cumberlands'' in 1963 was credited with bringing Appalachia's problems to the nation's attention. ``Coal has always cursed the land in which it lies. When men begin to wrest it from the earth it leaves a legacy of foul streams, hideous slag heaps and polluted air,'' Caudill wrote in the book. ``It mars but never beautifies. It corrupts but never purifies.'' Johnson subsequently backed a wide range of social programs to develop the region. The president used the Appalachian mountains as a backdrop when he announced his War on Poverty at a tarpaper shack near Inez in 1964. By last spring, Caudill had written 10 books, 80 newspaper essays and editorials and some 50 magazine articles. ``Harry was always the one to challenge the unchallengable,'' said Ron Eller, director of the Appalachian Studies Center at the University of Kentucky. ``He was the one to speak out and the one to confront the corporations and the wealthy. That kind of courage is what made him a champion to those in the region.'' Caudill shot himself in the head with a pistol while seated in his yard, which has a view of Pine Mountain, an imposing ridge he cherished deeply. ``He did it in typical Harry style ... to go outside and be near the mountains,'' said Edison Banks Jr., Letcher County assistant commonwealth's attorney and a former student of Caudill's. His struggle with Parkinson's and a war wound restricted his mobility in recent months, said Tom Gish, a publisher of The Mountain Eagle newspaper in Whitesburg and a boyhood friend. Gish said Caudill had been depressed. Caudill was born in Whitesburg, served in the Army and graduated from the University of Kentucky College of Law in 1948. He championed education reform during three terms he served in the Kentucky House, from 1954 to 1957 and from 1960 to 1962. He turned to writing in the early 1960s and taught Appalachian history for eight years at the University of Kentucky until his retirement in 1985. He is survived by his wife, Anne; a daughter, and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Whose Case Led to More Freedom For Mental Patients Drowns
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose court case gave West Virginia's psychiatric patients freedom to live with as few restrictions as possible drowned after wandering off during a visit to a doctor, authorities say. Ella Hartley, 53, died Tuesday. She was last seen alive at an Ohio River boat dock where she told bystanders she was going for a swim, said police Capt. Paul Price. On Hartley's behalf, the Appalachian Research and Defense Fund, a public advocacy group, filed a class-action lawsuit seeking more freedom for mentally ill people able to care for themselves. In what became known as the Hartley decision, the Kanawha County Circuit Court ruled in 1982 that mentally ill persons should be kept in ``the least restrictive environment possible.'' The decision resulted in Huntington State Hospital's mental patient population falling from 1,500 to 90. ``The idea was that the mentally ill would do better if they were placed in the community than they would if they were cooped up in a mental institution,'' said Richard Christopher, a patient advocate at the hospital. But he said the people released back into the community never received the support and supervision they required, and that it created the circumstances for an accident like Hartley's to occur. ``People kept coming back through the system, and somewhere along the line someone is bound to get hurt,'' he said. State health officials refused to discuss Hartley's case. Hartley was a temporary patient at Huntington on Tuesday when a hospital employee took her to a doctor's office nearby. Sometime during the visit she left the escort's supervision. Her sister, Sue Davis, said that although Hartley maintained her own apartment, she had frequently been hospitalized and a hearing on whether to commit her had been scheduled for Thursday. She said her sister suffered from a chemical imbalance that causes erratic behavior. The malady can be controlled with drugs, but she said Hartley had apparently stopped taking them. John Ambrose of the National Mental Health Association in Alexandria, Va., said the Hartley decision was part of a national trend toward releasing mental patients that began in the 1970s. Sidney Kapantias of the Huntington Information and Referral Service, a social service agency, said counselors there were well aware of Hartley's role in changing the way the mentally ill are cared for. ``It was always stunning to people to know that it was her class-action lawsuit that facilitated the release of so many people from mental hospitals,'' he said. ``Was she a victim of her own law? I don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Held for Allegedly Plotting to Kill Bush, Destroy Military Installations
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. soldier born in Kuwait was behind bars today on charges of plotting to kill President Bush and attack military bases. Jamal Mohamed Warrayat, 32, allegedly discussed with an undercover FBI agent plans to kill Bush, as well as Secretary of State James Baker and members of Congress. Court papers said he also conspired, as the leader of a group of seven people, to attack unspecified military installations in North Carolina and Texas. None of the others was named or charged Thursday. ``At this point in time there is no evidence to show that any foreign government promoted or assisted in this activity,'' U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff said Thursday. He gave no motive or would not comment further. Warrayat was held without bail at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. He could get up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted. Defense attorney Terence Scott said the charges stemmed from Warrayat's ``ramblings'' and were not supported by evidence. Warrayat was born in Kuwait, moved to the United States in the early 1970s, became a citizen and served about four years in the Army until 1979, Scott said. Warrayat spoke to an undercover agent in late August, telling the agent in Arabic that his group had weapons and materials to carry out small terrorist operations, according to court papers. Warrayat wanted help getting explosives, money and technical training and claimed to have drawings and diagrams of the military targets that he made while in the Army, authorities said. Warrayat, who lives in Rutherford, worked as a taxi driver until recently but was unemployed at the time of his arrest Tuesday, Scott said. During a hearing in federal court in Newark, Assistant U.S. Attorney Donna Gallucio said Warraya'st parents and other family members live in Kuwait and Iraq and he has traveled to the Middle East several times during the last six years. Gallucio said a search of Warrayat's home turned up a legally purchased handgun.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Security Council Statements
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights from the statements made Thursday by foreign ministers, ambassadors, and the secretary-general on the passage of a resolution giving Iraq an ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait:

Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari: ``If war is imposed upon us by the United States, this will be our destiny. Our people will not kneel, we will rise to this responsibility. ... ``The Council is but a willing tool in the hands of the American administration. ... ``Iraq calls for peace, it desires peace, not for us alone but for the entire Middle East region. ... ``This would be the most dangerous resolution ever passed by the Security Council ... and a violation of the U.N. Charter.''

U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III: ``Our aim today must be to convince Saddam Hussein that the just, humane demands of the Council and the international community cannot be ignored. ``If Iraq does not reverse its course peacefully, then other necessary measures, including the use of force, should be authorized. We must put the choice to Saddam Hussein in unmistakable terms. ... ``Today's resolution is clear. The words authorize the use of force. But the purpose, I truly believe, is to bring about a peaceful resolution.''

Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber: ``The intransigence of the Iraqi regime is pushing the region to a conflagration which we do not want, but which appears to be the only avenue to restore our rights. ... ``The Iraqi aggressor showed no sense of mercy or compassion, indeed, no espect for the divine or human codes of conduct.''

Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze: ``We have been faced with the first grave test of the post-Cold War period and we are coping with it. ... ``We want begin the pause of good will, by calling upon Iraq and President Saddam Hussein to rise above considerations of prestige, to display wisdom and foresight and place above all else the interest of the country and fate of its people. ... ``Those who break the peace should know that all necessary means will indeed, inexorably, be used against them. ... ``All of us would only be happy, if the need to resort to such means did not arise.''

French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas: ``Can we then tolerate such a blatant challenge for any extended period of time, especially in a region which is highly sensitive, where the expectations for security and stability call for special consideration? ... ``Aggression should no longer be considered the privilege of the strong, the misfortune of the weak and the object of resignation for all the rest. ``This text is also consistent with the logic of the attitude Iraq has displayed. If Iraq chooses to remain deaf to the appeal for reason and respect for law, that is to say remains locked into the use of force, what other choice are we left with but to resort to this same means, which would appear to be the only ones it recognizes?''

Cuban Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca Peoli: ``We must redouble the effort to try to achieve the just solution we all desire. ``We also express our concern over the enormous increased concentration of the forces of the United States and its allies in the Gulf ... which would bring about enormous destruction to countries in the region ... ``Cuba believes it is not advisable to adopt a resolution which constitutes a virtual declaration of war... ``We are now expected to support a deadline for war. ... It is the duty of the United Nations to respond with wisdom to any manifestation of extremism, instead of embracing a fanatic cult of the use of force.''

Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen: ``I feel deeply that members of the international community share common grounds on the Gulf crisis on two points, namely, they all oppose the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait and call on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait immediately, while at the same time they all wish to see that the Gulf crisis be settled through peaceful means. ... ``The United Nations ... should act with great caution and avoid taking hasty actions on such a major question as authorizing some member states to take military actions against another member state.''

British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd: ``In a world composed of nation states and in an organization consisting of nations states, the obliteration of one member state by another is an act on its own. It undermines and threatens the whole structure of international order, and thus the safety of all our citizens. ... ``Withdrawal must be complete. If not, then member states are authorized, acting with the government of Kuwait, to use such force as may be necessary to compel compliance. ... ``There is an option for peace, and the Iraqis hold it in their hands. It is for them to use that option or discard it. ... ``The military option is reality, not bluff. If it has to be used it will be used, with the full backing of the Council.''

Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar: ``The Security Council has taken a decision of immense portent. I would like to stress that, even on the most stringent reading, the resolution just dopted envisages at least 45 days of earnest effort to achieve a peaceful solution of the crisis. ... ``To my mind, the situation requires that diplomatic effort be undertaken with renewed determination to put the present crisis on the road to a peaceful outcome.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Ultimatum Prompts Mixed Emotions Among Hostage Families
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of American hostages are agonizing over the U.N. resolution aimed at driving Iraq from Kuwait, many noting that while force may be the only answer, it will put the lives of their loved ones in danger. The resolution, adopted by the U.N. Security Council on Thursday, authorizes an attack if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein doesn't withdraw his troops from Kuwait and free all hostages by Jan. 15. ``I've got a son over there and, of course, when the bullets start flying he's in danger,'' said George Carroll of Winfield, Kan. ``But I still think it's about all we can do. We can't let this go on forever.'' Carroll's son, a pediatric neurologist, is trapped in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Some hostage families said the ultimatum itself might endanger the estimated 900 Americans stranded in Iraq or Kuwait. Kristine Knutson said she is anxious about what Iraqi troops might do in the face of a Jan. 15 deadline. Her husband has been in hiding since the couple decided she and their four young children should flee to Minnesota. ``For his peace of mind, it might help knowing there's a deadline,'' said Ms. Knutson, who asked that her maiden name be used to protect her husband's identity. ``But I wonder how (the Iraqis) will react to the increased pressure.'' David McDonald Jr., who has a close friend in hiding in Kuwait, said he believes his friend, a Midwestern dentist, would support the resolution. ``My friend is not a warmonger, but I think he realizes it's the only realistic option if Saddam is to be stopped,'' he said. But Donnita Cole, who was among a group of hostage relatives scheduled to visit the Iraqi capital of Baghdad next week, said she cannot abide an offensive stance - at least not until every diplomatic option is exhausted. ``I want to know what gives our president the power to decide that on a certain date we're going to start a war,'' said Mrs. Cole, whose husband is among Western hostages being held by Iraq as ``human shields'' to discourage an attack. ``What gives him the power in the month of November to say that in January we're going to start a war?'' she asked. ``It should not be an American military offensive as a presidential option but as an act of Congress, and the people Congress is supposed to represent.'' ``At least (the resolution) puts some kind of a time frame on it all,'' said Bonnie Anderton, whose husband has taken refuge at the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad. ``But it's just another ratcheting of the stakes,'' Mrs. Anderton said from Larkspur, Colo. ``And (Saddam) has said he's going to ignore it.'' Jennifer Williams, 21, who is planning a trip to Baghdad to plead for freedom for her father and stepmother, said the deadline is spurring her to do as much as she can while she still has the chance. Her parents are being held as human shields. ``I think many people in my situation would do the same thing,'' said the student at Southern Methodist University in Dallas. ``It's not an option. It's something I have to do,'' she said. ``I don't want my family to die in a war ... and because of this deadline, I feel like I need to act quickly.''

DOC.HEAD: 48,000 Mine Workers Walk Out in Pay Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Forty-eight thousand mine workers walked off the job today in the largest strike since Turkey granted unions the right to strike in 1963. The strike followed the breakdown in contract negotiations between the Mine Workers Union and the state-owned Mine Research Insitute and the Coal Mines Enterprise. In response, the employers said they will begin a lockout Tuesday. Turkish papers reported today that the government had dispatched special commando units of the army to the region to prevent any violence in the province. In negotiations which lasted six months, the government companies offered annual pay raises of about 75 percent. The unions demanded that the wages be raised five-fold in view of high inflation and what they deemed insufficient raises in the past. The average monthly wage for a miner working in the coal pits was $180 and the union was demanding $900. Union president Hasan Huseyin Kayabasi told workers at the largest mining area of Zonguldak that ``this strike is the start of a process to get rid of those who have condemned workers to wages of misery.'' He was referring to the ruling Motherland Party and its policies to keep wages low despite inflation of around 60 percent in recent years. Contract talks broke off Wednesday after President Turgut Ozal, founder of the Motherland, told reporters the workers were demanding too much. After hearing Ozal's remark, union officials said there was no use attending a meeting with Cabinet ministers designed to resolve the pay dispute. Most of the striking workers are employed in coal mines in the province of Zonguldak on the Black Sea Coast.

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial Ruled in Faith Healing Case
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared in the negligent homicide case of a woman who relied on faith instead of medicine to heal her leukemia-stricken son. District Judge Bruce Bennett declared a mistrial Thursday night when the jury, after eight hours of deliberation, said it could not reach a verdict. Anneta Williamson, 43, of Loranger, was tried in the 1989 death of her 5-year-old son, Don. Mrs. Williamson is a member of a fundamentalist Christian denomination that believes in curing the ill through prayer and fasting. The prosecution did not immediately indicate whether it would retry Mrs. Williamson. The defense had cited a 1985 law was designed to protect Christian Scientists, who also practice faith healing. The law holds that religious healing instead of medical treatment ``shall not, for that reason alone, be considered to be criminally negligent mistreatment or neglect of a child.'' However, Assistant Attorney General Ken DeJean argued that the 1985 law does not apply in cases of negligent homicide. The prosecution's final witness, Dr. Sheila Moore, a specialist in children's cancer, had testified that 60 percent to 70 percent of children who develop leukemia recover.

DOC.HEAD: Second Wave of Sealift Hauling Weapons for Allied Forces in Gulf
With PM-Gulf-UN, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A huge fleet is hauling hundreds of thousands of tons of tanks, cannons and other materiel to the multinational force in Saudi Arabia in one of the biggest military sealifts in history. Some 150 naval and merchant ships, now in a second wave as new thousands of troops are sent to the region, have transported nearly 2 million tons of equipment and supplies to the 350,000-member allied force since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Maj. Gen. William Pagonis, commander of military logistics for Operation Desert Shield, said the sealift, augmented by a 3,000-plane airlift, is ``probably unheard of in history. ``In Vietnam, it took five or six years to have this many troops on the ground. Even in Korea, they never moved this amount of people and materiel this rapidly.'' Between early August and mid-November, U.S.-chartered ships carried more than 2,000 tanks, hundreds of other armored vehicles and artillery guns, U.S. officials in Saudi Arabia say. Another 185,000 tons of materiel were airlifted from the United States and Germany, along with 190,000 troops. Britain, France, Egypt and Syria also transported hundreds of tanks, armored vehicles, guns, missiles and helicopters along with thousands of troops in some 60 vessels. Now there's a second wave as President Bush bolsters U.S. forces with another 200,000 troops, marines, sailors and airmen and all their hardware. Close to 100 ships were involved in the first wave, about 60 percent of them government owned. ``It's a heyday for the merchant marine,'' said Cmdr. Jamie Baldwin, who commands a group of naval reserve officers involved in the sealift. ``Civilians are contributing substantially to the sealift.'' The first ships were the roll-on, roll-off ships of the U.S. Maritime Prepositioning Squadron, which left the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia, 2,100 miles east of the gulf, on Aug. 7. The ships arrived Aug. 15. Next came the Afloat Prepositioning Force ships, also based in Diego Garcia, which carried Army and Air Force Equipment. These civilian-manned ships were followed by the Fast Sealift Support, converted container ships that carried Army Infantry Division equipment. Then came the Ready Reserve Force Ships, which were activated for Operation Desert Shield. The last group included merchant ships chartered to the U.S. government. They included various ship types, and included foreign-flagged vessels. ``It was incredible,'' said a shipping executive based in Saudi Arabia. ``One hundred vessels came in three months, an average of one a day. I wouldn't think that even in World War II there was such movement at such speed.'' The United States has appealed to its NATO allies to provide more ships and transport planes to move men and materiel to the gulf. Naval officials have been quoted as saying most were available at either commercial charter rates or for free. Most of the first wave of ships came 7,000 miles from the United States. The U.S. government likened the task to moving a mid-size city halfway around the world. The second wave is coming mainly from Europe, which cuts down sailing time. By mid-January, the sealift is expected to have transported three U.S. armored divisions from Germany. The eastern Saudi ports and Jubail, 150 miles south of the Kuwaiti border, and Dammam, further south, are the main unloading centers for the U.S. sealift. Pagonis said the huge, modern facilities there were a major factor in keeping the flow running smoothly, with as many as 10 vessels unloading at a time on some days. The British, French, Egyptians and Syrians, which between them have deployed or are sending more than 50,000 troops and hundreds of tanks, use the Red Sea port of Yanbu.

DOC.HEAD: Street Crosses Judge One Too Many Times
DOC.TEXT: The continuing adventures of T. Milton Street, the Traffic Court official who racked up 26 tickets while driving without a license, found the self-proclaimed ``poor people's hero'' without a job. Street was fired Thursday by Traffic Court President Judge George Twardy for courtroom antics ``unbefitting a Traffic Court employee.'' Street on Wednesday had protested the handling of his case by yelling at a Traffic Court judge, then sitting in her chair for most of the afternoon. ``That is not right,'' Twardy said. ``I'm not going to stand for it.'' Last week, Twardy suspended Street after it was learned that he has 26 outstanding tickets and owes $2,559 in fines. Street also has not had a license or insurance for the past 11 years, Twardy said. Street, a former state senator hired as assistant budget director of Traffic Court last year, is challenging a rule that requires payment before getting a Traffic Court hearing. He thinks it is unconstitutional and unfair to poor people. Twardy also fired Street's son, T. Milton Street Jr., a court officer suspended for not paying for nine tickets. The son accompanied his father during Wednesday's sit-in, which ended when police asked them to leave as the office was closing for the day. Street said he would challenge his firing. ``George Twardy hasn't heard the last of me,'' he said. ``I'm going to be a hemorrhoid in his backside.''

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Fear Threat of Cheaper U.S. Rice if Market Opened
With PM-Thinking the Unthinkable, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fusao Harada has toiled most of his 60 years in a family rice paddy in this rustic village, stubbornly surviving war, poverty and an only son who shuns farming. But his biggest challenge may be yet to come if the Japanese government bows to U.S. pressure and decides to remove a ban on imported rice that is much cheaper. Harada, a stocky man whose nearly six acres of land stretches toward tree-covered hills on the eastern edge of Tokyo, says he is ready to meet that challenge. ``As a farmer, I can't bear to see a rice field overgrown with weeds,'' he said. But other farmers are less sanguine. ``Opening up the rice market will lead to the destruction of Japanese farming,'' said Teiichi Tanaka, 63, a farmer from Niigata prefecture in central Japan. Competition with cheap U.S. imports would be akin to ``making a toddler fight against a sumo wrestler.'' The Japanese government has long protected its farmers by banning virtually all rice imports, claiming the country needed to remain self sufficient in its staple grain. The price of Japanese rice is about 2.4 times that of U.S. rice, according to Agriculture Ministry statistics. Pressure has been applied on Japan to show its commitment to free trade by gradually easing the ban. Vice President Dan Quayle made a pitch for opening the market during a November meeting with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in Tokyo. The issue may come to a head in December during a crucial international meeting on trade in Brussels. Many farmers are predicting dire consequences for Japanese agriculture if the ban is lifted. They claim they cannot compete with imports because the economies of scale of huge U.S. farms are impossible on the tiny plots of arable land squeezed between Japan's many mountains. But the farmers' troubles actually began brewing long before the threat of rice imports materialized. The Japanese diet has been shifting from rice toward meat and bread, and farming villages have been turning into ghost towns as the younger generation heads for big cities. ``I am going to be the last farmer in this family,'' lamented Tanaka, whose son is a white-collar worker. Japan now has 5.9 million farmers, 1 million less than a decade ago, who comprise only 8 percent of the working population. Rice-growing farmland has declined by about 741,000 acres during that period, as paddies have given way to factories and new homes. Nationwide farmers' groups remain powerful because the Japanese political system gives rural areas strong electoral clout, and the government's official line on the ban has yet to waver. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said the international community should recognize Japan's need to maintain food security through domestic production. ``Japan is going to emphasize again (in the December trade talks) that Japan is the largest importer of agricultural goods in the world and also that the self-sufficiency rate is the lowest among the industrialized countries,'' Watanabe said. Many Japanese also see rice farming as central to their culture, because rice plays a central role in Shinto, the country's native religion. Still, an increasing number of influential politicians are saying that the market should be opened to imports. Many farmers believe it is only a matter of time before the ban is removed. In addition to U.S. demand for liberalized trade policies, the political clout of rural areas is likely to decline because of the dwindling farm population and planned electoral reforms. One 68-year-old woman, whose son chose to run a pastry store in a former rice paddy instead of cultivating the family land, gave up rice farming five years ago. Now she works alone in a garden near her home in Kamogawa, raising strawberries, cabbage and scallions. ``Japanese farming is finished,'' she said with a sigh before returning to her gardening.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies Friday in hectic, early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the dollar was boosted by the U.N. Security Council's resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq and by comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan that he was concerned about the dollar's weakness. ``The dollar is widely viewed as undervalued and people don't want to play against that,'' a trader in Milan said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 2.60 yen to a closing 132.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 133.15 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5055 German marks, up from 1.5025 -1.2823 Swiss francs, up from 1.2805 -5.0813 French francs, down from 5.0820 -1.6985 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6860 -1,130.00 Italian lire, up from 1,122.75 -1.1665 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1645 In London, the pound was quoted at $1.9370, compared with $1.9485 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $384.80 per ounce at midmorning, down from $386.75 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $384.30, down from $386.75 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 0.18 to close at $385.01. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.12 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.13.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germans Face Fourth Election in 34 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: After four decades of rigged elections that gave the Communists a numbing succession of imaginary landslides, eastern Germans are suddenly awash in the freedom to choose. On Sunday, they will join their western countrymen for the first united German elections since 1932. It is the fourth free and fair election in the past 10 months in what used to be East Germany, however, and some people have lost their enthusiasm for ballot casting. ``I won't vote Sunday,'' said Andrea Fischer, who also skipped the last two elections. ``The more I know about these parties, the more they seem almost comical.'' After overthrowing the Communist hard-liners, East Germans jubilantly chose a democratic government in March. In May, they elected new local leaders, throwing out hundreds of Communists still clinging to power. On Oct. 14 - a scant 11 days after German unification - they chose the governments for the five states their nation had become. But with another historic chapter about to be written Sunday, a definite air of apathy hangs over the former nation. Some of it has to do with the seeming inevitability of the outcome. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose conservative Christian Democratic Union dominated the first three races in eastern Germany, is expected to handily retain his post. A little of it has to do with a growing familiarity with democratic political campaigns. The novelty has worn off, the euphoria is gone. Political rhetoric is greeted with Western-style cynicism. Most of all, pressing problems have come to dwarf the small thrill of voting. The eastern Germans are expecting a dramatic surge in joblessness as their sputtering enterprises use up what little credit they have left in coming months. ``I have a child and a job that I only work four hours a day,'' said Ms. Fischer, 33, a postal employee who lives in the village of Schildow, north of Berlin. ``I just believe my vote won't make a difference,'' she said. Ms. Fischer, who would have supported the environmental Greens party or the left-leaning Social Democrats, says she believes even they don't have a strong enough message to lure her to a voting booth on Sunday. Karin Wernecke, a 30-year-old Berliner and former Communist, will vote as she always has: for the Communists, now reformed and renamed the Party of Democratic Socialism. ``We won't win, but we need this voice,'' she said. Ms. Wernecke, a single jobless mother, says she has little hope for the future under the Christian Democrats. Harry Schneidereit is one of the optimists. At 65, he has a chance to finally do what he always wanted to do. ``I have been a watchmaker for 40 years,'' said Schneidereit, who runs a small shop in northern Berlin. ``This is the first time in my life I can decide what I want. This is the essence of life for a shopkeeper.'' Schneidereit could not visit his parents in West Berlin after the wall was built. He had to let the government decide what he could stock in his shop, what prices to charge, how much he could pay his employees. Now he has a new product line but is struggling to compete with the lower prices of the big retailers. Still, he said he would have it no other way. That's why, he said, Sunday's election is important: To continue the former nation's evolution. ``It is important that we have no apathy,'' he said. ``This man, this big man, he has promised that he would help and now he should help. This is the way to hold him to his promise.'' The ``big man'' is the rotund giant Kohl, who promised East Germans both unity and Western-style prosperity if they elected his party in March. Unity came, but prosperity still has not. Schneidereit detects apathy among the people in his shop, stunned by the realization that times are hard and things are likely to worsen before they get better. Schneidereit will vote for Kohl, but he says eastern Germans themselves carry much of the burden for making the chancellor's promises come true. ``We can't say `Oh, we poor people,' '' he said. ``Look at the Soviet Union. ``We have to find the right way,'' he said. ``We have to take our destiny into our own hands.''

DOC.HEAD: NBC Edges Field In November TV Ratings Sweeps
DOC.TEXT: NBC is still king of the hill after claiming its 11th straight ratings sweeps victory. It has surrendered the top position only once in 23 tries since 1985. Nobody was surprised and few outside the network were very impressed when NBC claimed its latest victory Thursday in the monthlong viewership tallies held each November, February, May and July. Sweeps figures, bolstered by blockbuster programming like major motion pictures, entertainment specials and other choice shows, help TV stations set their advertising rates. ``The purpose of the sweeps is really to provide numbers that our local stations can sell,'' said Robert Niles, NBC's vice president for research. ``This is a nice victory.'' It was a smaller, narrower victory than in past NBC wins. The other networks noted that NBC's winning margin was 13 percent lower than in 1989. ``While we may have slowed down, year to year, nobody's passed us,'' Niles said. NBC won prime time with a 13.1 average rating and a 22 share; ABC was second by a tick, with a 12.8 rating and 21 share; and No. 3 CBS had a 12.0 rating and a 20 share. A ratings point represents 931,000 television households in the A.C. Nielsen Co. survey; a share represents the percentage of all television sets tuned to a show in its time period. Among high-profile sweeps shows, NBC had the month's top-rated theatrical movie, ``Three Men and a Baby,'' and the two-part made-for-TV movie ``The Big One.'' ABC had the second-highest rated movie, the made-for-TV ``Stephen King's `It''' and ``Crocodile Dundee.'' Limited success in the movie category cost CBS, said David Poltrack, the network's senior vice president for audience research. ``The major reason for CBS being third in the sweeps is that you have to go all the way down (the list) to No. 6 to find CBS,'' he said. For Fox Broadcasting Co., which had added two nights of programming this season, its 6.6 rating and 11 share had to be a disappointment, one industry analyst said. Fox boosted its ratings just a tenth of a point and its audience share by just 1 percent over last November's sweeps. ``The sweeps numbers just confirm that with an expanded lineup, it's getting tougher to compete,'' said David Marans, senior audience researcher for the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. ``CBS almost had twice the audience that Fox did,'' he said. ``Any plans that Fox had for further expansion have to be questionable, if they're only competitive on one or two nights now.'' Fox officials did not immediately return phone calls seeking their reaction to the November sweeps. NBC's victory comes with just over 1 million more households tuned in than third-place CBS, and a 2 percent larger share of the audience. No. 2-rated ABC had only about 280,000 fewer housholds tuned in and a 1 percent smaller share. ``It's the closest we've been to first place in a non-Olympics year since 1984,'' said Alan Wurtzel, ABC's senior vice president for research. ``Basically, NBC and ABC are the same.'' NBC's narrow win signals possible change in the network ratings game, Marans said. ``If you look at the demographics, ABC is pretty much on its way to becoming the leader in prime time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: A Pension and Half an Office From a Grateful Nation
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher, the longest serving British leader this century, has been rewarded for her 11{ years in power with a pension about equal to the salary of a well-paid London secretary. She will also receive a private office at Parliament, but only so long as she remains a Parliament member. Beyond that, the only perks of former office will be a limousine and a security detail. Since she could be a target of the Irish Republican Army for decades, security could cost the government hundreds of thousands of dollars a year. Her pension of $34,185 a year - roughly the earnings of a senior secretary in central London - is calculated according to a procedure laid down in 1937, a government spokesman said. It provides that a prime minister gets a pension amounting to 15 fortieths of his or her pay, irrespective of length in office. Because she is still a member of the House of Commons for the north London district of Finchley, the 65-year-old Mrs. Thatcher also gets the $52,066 salary of a legislator, bringing her total government income to $86,252. Mrs. Thatcher has crammed the filing cabinets for her Finchley constituency into the tiny office at the House of Commons of a fellow legislator, Peter Morrison, said her former press secretary, Bernard Ingham. She is using space in Morrison's shared office at the Commons but is due to be given a larger one for herself as the ex-prime minister. That, too, will go if she leaves the 650-member Commons. Space is at a premium and most legislators have to share. Meanwhile, admirers have got together to provide her with a privately funded set of offices in a building near the Houses of Commons. Her aides say she is hoping to set up a Margaret Thatcher Foundation, dedicated to promoting her views on free markets and private enterprise. The foundation would pay for the office. The salary of the prime minister is $130,395, but Mrs. Thatcher, who is married to a retired millionaire, chose to be paid $107,680, the same as other Cabinet members. Britain's four other surviving ex-prime ministers, Harold Wilson and James Callaghan of the Labor Party, and Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party predecessor, Edward Heath, also retired on the 15-fortieths of their prime ministerial salaries at the time. The pensions are raised annually in line with inflation.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Citing Weak Demand, Plans More Production Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout that expected loss is in operating income, sted net income, CLARIFIES how production cutback will be accomplished; ADDS that laid-off workers will get 95 percent of salary. No pickup. A version also moving on financial wires as PM-GM-Stempel.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is cutting production for the second time this month because of slumping demand and says it expects to suffer its first quarterly operating loss this year since recession-wracked 1981. GM did not say how many of the automaker's 280,000 hourly workers will be laid off to accomplish the cutback in production. GM Chairman Robert Stempel told a Fort Wayne, Ind., business group on Thursday night that the world's leading automaker expects its fourth-quarter operating results ``will decline significantly'' from the third quarter. GM spokesman Terrence Sullivan in Detroit said the chairman's statement ``certainly implies'' GM will have a fourth-quarter operating loss. An operating loss differs from a net loss. Net earnings or losses reflect, in addition to earnings on a company's core operations, such factors as the sale of assets, the cost of plant closings and various accounting practices. GM did not say whether it would post a net loss. While the automaker posted a record net loss of $2 billion in the third quarter, that was due to a $2.1 billion writeoff for plant closings, which overwhelmed a $109 million profit on its truck- and auto-making operations. The automaker announced earlier this month it was cutting fourth-quarter production by 181,000 vehicles. Stempel said Thursday that GM was reducing production by an additional 111,000 cars and trucks. The reductions will leave GM with plans to build 1.07 million cars and trucks at its U.S. and Canadian plants during the fourth quarter, which ends Dec. 1. GM declined to say which of the company's 100 plants in North America would be affected. As a result of the cutback, GM will make 144,000 cars and trucks in December, 40 percent fewer than what it had previously planned to build. Under the GM contract, laid-off workers get 95 percent of their salary. Stempel said the lower production reflects an erosion of consumer confidence stemming in part from the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Many people have been taking a `wait and see' attitude toward major purchase decisions. For the auto industry, this has translated into weaker automotive demand that has meant temporary plant shutdowns and layoffs,'' he said. ``What GM is saying is that `We are not going to get caught with a surplus of cars that we have to sell (with) extreme rebates and have to shut the plants down in January and February,' as they did in 1990,'' said auto industry analyst Arvid Jouppi of Arvid Jouppi Associates Inc. in Detroit. Analyst Ronald Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco predicted GM would post a net loss of $150 million to $250 million for the quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Man Imprisoned in Home Charged With Murder, Armed Robbery
DOC.TEXT: A car thief confined to his home by an electronic ankle bracelet lured a man to his apartment with the promise of a drug deal, then robbed and murdered him, police said. Samuel Santiago, 18, also robbed a pizza deliveryman in front of his apartment while under the electronic supervision of prison officials, police said. The ankle bracelet transmits a signal to a receiver attached to the telephone if the prisoner moves outside a 100-foot radius of the phone. ``He knew just how far he could go without setting off the alarm,'' police Sgt. Ron Rewers said Thursday. Santiago was charged Thursday with murder and two counts of armed robbery. He was jailed today without bail. Santiago began serving a three-year sentence for car theft in 1989 and a month ago was accepted into a home imprisonment program that includes 460 felons, said Nic Howell, a state Corrections Department spokesman. On Monday, Santiago fatally shot Rudy DelCastillo, 18, at the entrance of his home after an accomplice, Federico Conde, 18, lured the victim there by offering to sell him drugs, police said. Santiago and Conte allegedly robbed the man of gold chains and more than $1,000 in cash. Conde also was charged with murder and armed robbery. The night before the shooting, a pizza deliveryman was robbed at gunpoint while making a delivery to Santiago's home, Detective A. Perez said. Howell said this was the first serious criminal charge made against a participant in the home imprisonment program, which was started in 1989 as a way to ease prison overcrowding and has had 1,800 participants. Officials monitor inmates 24 hours a day via the telephone receivers, which signal Correction Department computers if prisoners stray, Howell said. Only non-violent offenders are selected, Howell said. ``This one incident should not bear on the rest of the program,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chilly Weather Across Nation; Heavy Snow in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell in Spokane, Wash., early today and was expected to blanket much of Oregon, Montana, Idaho and the Great Lakes area by late tonight. A winter storm watch was issued for the Cascade and Olympics mountain ranges, which were expected to get up to 18 inches of snow by late tonight. Five inches were expected in the Great Lakes region. Meanwhile, gale-force winds were forecast for the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana, as well as portions of the central-Atlantic states and Idaho and Montana. Gale-force winds blew across Montana on Thursday, flipping a freight train near Livingston and disrupting rail traffic across the state. Chilly temperatures were forecast for most of the nation today, with highs ranging from the 30s and 40s in the North to the 50s and 60s across the Midwest and along most of the East and West coasts, and the 70s in the South. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at Naples, Fla. DOC.HEAD: Precede NICOSIA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to ADD quotes, details of meeting, byline. No Pickup
