DOC.TEXT: Iraq today rejected a U.N. Security Council ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait by mid-January and vowed to teach the United States and its allies a ``hard lesson, unprecedented in history.'' State-run Baghdad Radio interrupted regular programming to broadcast what it described as ``an important announcement'' by the ruling Revolutionary Command Council led by President Saddam Hussein. The statement said the Security Council endorsement Thursday night of the use of force against Iraq if it does not leave Kuwait by Jan. 15 was ``illegal, null and void'' because Baghdad said it was imposed by the United States. ``It is first and foremost an American decision in which certain powers participated only under American pressure,'' said the announcement, monitored in Nicosia. ``The United States practiced all forms of pressure, terrorism and bribes'' to pass the resolution. The measure was approved by a 12-to-2 vote. It was opposed by Cuba and Yemen, the only Arab member on the 15-member Security Council. China abstained. The Baghdad announcement noted that the council had failed to end Israeli occupation of Arab territories and said this was one of the reasons why Arab masses would reject the latest resolution against Iraq. ``The Iraqi people reject this injustice and are ready to fight in the defense of their territory,'' the announcement said, referring to Kuwait, which Iraq annexed after the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraqis now refer to Kuwait as their 19th province. ``This nation of impossible missions will teach all those (arrayed against Iraq) a hard lesson unprecedented in history,'' the announcement said. ``Millions of Iraqis are committed to confronting tyranny and injustice.'' Before the Security Council session, Saddam said Iraq would not be intimidated by a resolution authorizing military action against it. He insisted that his armed forces had the technology to defeat sophisticated American weapons, such as the Stealth fighter bomber. ``The Americans are still influenced by Rambo movies, but this is not a Rambo movie. This is something different,'' Saddam said on Thursday. ``It is a shameful resolution, tarnished with the scandals that have transformed the Security Council into a cover for U.S. hegemony and a theater for its dirty deals,'' the Revolutionary Command Council statement said. ``The double standards of these powers have become crystal clear after the latest resolution,'' it said. It reiterated a call for ``a dialogue'' to resolve the Kuwait crisis and the Palestinian question on ``the basis of equality and mutual respect.''

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic Hurricane Season: A Lot of Sound, Not Much Fury
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Atlantic hurricane season had more storms than usual and some forecasters predict that's just a hint of more frequent and more forceful hurricanes in the coming years. But this year's batch did not include the devastating storms of years past and at least one forecaster thinks 1991 will be a calmer year. The season ends today. Dr. William Gray, a professor of atmospheric science at Colorado State University, thinks a dry spell in West Africa during the past two decades explained the reduction of storms along the eastern seaboard in the last 20 years. In 1988 and 1989, there was near normal rainfall in the Sahel, the semi-arid land on the southern fringe of the Sahara Desert. Some meteorological experts think the rainfall signaled the end of a 20-year drought - and may have spawned Gilbert in 1988 and Hugo in 1989. Gray on Thursday predicted a below-average hurricane season in 1991. He based his forecast on several factors, including an anticipated below-average rainfall in the Sahel. But Gray and other forecasters agree that the general outlook for the 1990s and the early years of the next century is for more intense hurricanes than those of the last two decades. ``We've been through a real long period of hurricane inactivity in the '70s and '80s up until 1985, and I think we're coming out of that,'' said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables. ``Perhaps the Gilberts and the Hugos were signaling that,'' he said, recalling Hurricane Gilbert that wracked the Caribbean and Hurricane Hugo that devastated South Carolina - two of the most destructive Atlantic hurricanes ever. Hurricanes have been recorded in the Atlantic every month except April, but are rare outside the hurricane season, June 1 to Nov. 30. In this year's season, there were 14 named storms, eight of them hurricanes. The average number of storms is nine, with about six becoming hurricanes. Usually only a couple of those storms strike the U.S. While many of the storms spun harmlessly through the Atlantic, several caused their share of destruction. The most deadly storm was Hurricane Diana, which swept into Mexico in early August, resulting in flash floods and mudslides that killed 96 people and caused extensive damage to roads, property and agriculture, the weather service reported. A weather disturbance becomes a tropical storm, and is given a name, if its sustained winds reach 39 mph. Storms become hurricanes if winds reach 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0447 to correct category code
WASHINGTON TODAY: Does Drawing a Line in The Sand Make War Inevitable? ^An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The deadline is set. The United Nations is giving Iraq until Jan. 15 to pull out of Kuwait or face forcible eviction. But war is not inevitable even though a line was drawn in the sand Thursday by the Security Council. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has nearly seven weeks to withdraw his troops - and avert a war. Congressional Democrats are unlikely to relent in their determination to restrain the Bush administration. Former U.S. military commanders have questioned the wisdom of going to war with Iraq. And diplomats of various persuasions will redouble their efforts now to convince Saddam to release his hold on Kuwait. ``We do not stop the diplomatic and political efforts now at all,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III said after the Security Council vote. ``We have, in fact, a pause here for peace that will permit us to continue to pursue these efforts,'' he said as he headed to dinner with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France ``to explore with them what their ideas are.'' As the council rolled to its 12-2 vote in favor of the U.S. resolution - China abstained - speaker after speaker stressed not a military solution to the crisis but the possibility that Saddam would take the world's threats seriously. Canadian Foreign Minister Joseph Clark said the resolution gave the Iraqi leader ``an opportunity to reflect.'' ``It is up to Iraq; it is not too late,'' Clark said. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd called the resolution a clear message that ``we are making a strong bid for peace on the basis of him withdrawing'' from Kuwait. And Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said ``we want to begin a pause of good will.'' In an otherwise tough speech to the council, the Soviet foreign minister called on Saddam ``to rise above considerations of prestige, to display wisdom and foresight.'' Shevardnadze said it was ``time to think again.'' Baker has ruled out partial solutions and insisted on unconditional retreat from Kuwait. So that appears to leave little room for diplomacy to work. There would seem to be no face-saving device for the Iraqi leader to grasp. And yet, Baker said that while Saddam should not reap rewards for aggression, ``that should not be equated with an unwillingness to pursue diplomatic and political approaches.'' Baker gave no hint what approaches might be considered in the days before Jan. 15. But a careful look at the resolution shows there is a lot of room for maneuver. ``Yes, it authorizes the use of force,'' Baker noted. ``I would remind you that it doesn't require it. It's our view that this is the best way to give peace a chance, if you will.'' Forty years ago, when the U.N. Security Council decided to act against North Korea, the member nations adopted a resolution calling on all states to ``repel'' the invasion of South Korea. The resolution approved Thursday simply authorizes the taking of ``all necessary means'' to implement the 11 other resolutions approved by the council since the Aug. 2 invasion. That suggests the 12 nations that voed for the resolution want to avert a clash. There is no direct reference to war in the text. ``No one here has sought this conflict,'' Baker said. Rather than callin the resolution a mandate for war, Baker called it ``a pause for peace.'' And yet, Jan. 15 is a deadline. After that day, President Bush, Saddam and other key actors in this dangerous drama will find it very difficult to avoid making the hard choices they have postponed so far. For Bush, the deadline means he cannot wait much later without undermining the credibility of his own military threat. As for Saddam, stalling any further is a dare to come and get him. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Police and Prosecutors Apologize
DOC.TEXT: A jury that acquitted a man of attacking a police officer recommended police and prosecutors apologize for arresting him. When the Jackson County jurors issued the unusual statement this week, they didn't know that Ronald L. Webb, 21, had been held in jail after being unable to pay a $100,000 bond from the time of his arrest Aug. 1 until the verdict. Jurors found out later that Webb was in jail during the birth of his third child. And they did not know police sold his car from the city tow lot because being in jail had kept him from claiming it by a deadline. The jurors apparently believed the defense contention that a rookie police officer lied in her testimony to avoid being disciplined. After deliberating for about an hour Wednesday the jury asked for more time to compose a statement. A few minutes later, jury foreman Gene Scott read the statement, which said ``an apology is in order to Mr. Webb and his family for any hardships or inconvenience'' caused by the arrest. Police Chief Steve Bishop said police had probable cause to make an arrest, and ``no apology is necessary.'' Jurors found Webb innocent of charges of first degree assault on a law enforcement officer and armed criminal action. If convicted, he could have received up to a life sentence on each count. Webb, who faces court dates on several driving violations, had been taken to a police station June 21 for a traffic ticket, and admittedly walked away to avoid being arrested for driving with a suspended license. At that point, police charged he got into his car and tried to run down Officer Clarissa Hager. She was not injured.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Man Ordered to Learn English as Part of Probation
DOC.TEXT: A Korean immigrant who pleaded guilty to selling fake designer purses has been ordered to learn English during the next year as part of his probation. Interpreter Yong Spears told U.S. District Judge Tom Stagg that Bup Song Choe, 35, of Irving, Texas, will ``try best'' to learn the language. ``Try best, nuts!'' Stagg responded during a hearing Wednesday. He told Choe that he must learn English during his one-year probation, with his probation officer reporting on his progress. Choe brought fake Louis Vuitton, Gucci and MCM purses to Shreveport from Dallas and sold them to a local merchant. His attorney, Gary Udashen of Dallas, asked for a light sentence, saying a prison term of a year or more could keep Choe from becoming a U.S. citizen. ``He loves America as well as his own country. He wants to be American citizen,'' said Choe's wife, who also showed Stagg a photograph of their sons, Robert and Sam. The boys and Mrs. Choe, whose first name could not be obtained from the court, are U.S. citizens. ``It's a good thing that you want to become a citizen, but it's also true that you were a guest in this country when you broke its laws,'' Stagg told Choe.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Applaud U.N. Deadline for Refocusing Their Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to RESTORE dropped military rank in 5th graf, `Air Force...' Pickup 6th graf pvs, ```Now something's...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-UN-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From the paratroopers who landed on the first plane to the newest arrivals in the desert, U.S. troops today welcomed a U.N. deadline allowing force if Iraq fails to leave Kuwait by Jan. 15. ``It gives the soldiers a focus for the future. People now have something to key in on,'' said Capt. Michael Langman, 26, of Headquarters Co. of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division. Langman, of New York City, was among the first paratroopers to set foot on a Saudi airstrip nearly four months ago as part of Operation Desert Shield. The 82nd was considered a tripwire if Saddam Hussein chose to expand his agression beyond Kuwait and into Saudi Arabia. ``Now that they're talking about an offensive, it looks like we've got a mission again,'' Langman said. ``Guys want to kick some butt.'' Air Force Sgt. Scott Grant, 25, of Toledo, Ohio, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Thursday. But he was just as eager to learn that the United Nations had issued an ultimatum. ``Now something's going to be done,'' Grant said. The biggest boost about the U.N. action is knowing a date for something to happen, according to soldiers who have been sweating it out in the desert. ``The worst part of all has been not knowing,'' said Lt. Jackie Jones, 25, of Springfield, Va., part of a Patriot missile battery with the Army's 18th Airborne Corps. ``This sets a date. It gives us a timeline. It's a big motivating factor,'' she said. ``The longer you stay over here with nothing happening, the more lax you're likely to be. ``We're not here to babysit,'' said Ms. Jones. ``We'd just like to get on about our business and go home.'' At least one serviceman felt the vote gave Saddam too much time, which the Iraqi president can use to dig in and better his defenses. ``It should have been done two months ago. I hope it happens tomorrow,'' said Seaman Steven Simpson of Hartford, Conn., part of the U.S. Navy's Seabees Construction Battalion. ``We've given this guy ample opportunities to withdraw from Kuwait. Who knows if there's a Kuwait left? He stripped it down. He pillaged the whole country. He deserves what's going to happen to him,'' Simpson said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Announces First Medical Assistance to Soviets Since WWII
With PM-Scandinavia-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan will provide its first medical assistance to the Soviet Union since World War II to help ease shortages there this winter, the Foreign Ministry announced today. Japan will also supply $19.5 million worth of equipment and technological help for victims of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster, said ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the medical assistance would be worth much less than the aid for Chernobyl victims, which is being funneled through the World Health Organization. Japan has had a policy of not extending financial aid to Moscow until it agrees to return a group of islands it seized from Japan at the end of World War II. But the medical assistance will be extended on humanitarian grounds, Foreign Ministry officials said. The Soviet Union also is seeking emergency food from the international community this winter. ``We'd like to watch the situation in regard to the food situation,'' Watanabe said. ``We have no evidence that we should give emergency food aid,'' he added, citing reports of a bumper Soviet wheat harvest this year. Soviet officials say they are having trouble distributing the food because of bottlenecks and bureaucratic conflicts.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Sheriff On The Warpath To Collect $4 Billion In Overdue Fines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to recast, picking up 3rd graf pvs, `I'm not...'. Other minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: There's a new sheriff in town. And it's high noon for scofflaws who owe $4 billion in fines to the strapped city. Philip Crimaldi took over the city's antiquated and underused sheriff's office on July 30. He's been leaning hard on scofflaws ever since. ``I'm not in a personality contest,'' he said. City agencies issue a plethora of summonses: to building and fire code violators, litterbugs, illegal vendors, store owners with dirty sidewalks, pet owners who refuse to scoop, noisy nightclubs, restaurants that emit foul odors. New York uses its own employees, outside collection agencies, city marshals and, on rare occasions, the sheriff's office to shake money out of scofflaws. But the sheriff's office, which has the most legal power, collected only $2 million last year. Crimaldi, who says most people don't even know New York HAS a sheriff, collected $5.5 million in the past four months. All of it previously was deemed uncollectible by private collectors, who concentrate on the easiest pickings. ``An astronomical number of people in the city disregard summonses of all types,'' Crimaldi said. ``Whether you live in Dubuque, New York, Detroit or San Diego, when you get a parking ticket on your windshield, your first instinct - it may be a primal instinct - is to tear it up,'' conceded mayoral spokesman Lee Jones. Jones ought to know. Seven years ago, his mind was on personal problems instead of alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations. He ended up paying $2,200 in fines. ``The city of New York's going to get what's due,'' said Jones. ``Those who don't pay mean the rest of us have to pay more.'' Realistically, said Crimaldi, about $800 million of the $4 billion owed the city is collectible. The rest, though still on the books, is up to 20 years old. Parking violations are the biggest category; as of Tuesday, unpaid tickets totaled $1.6 billion. Some of those have been on the books eight years. The new sheriff's approach is simple. He finds out who owes money. He sends a letter, threatening to seize their bank account, car and other assets. Then he takes it. ``We've raided stores and found the city's dunning notices wrapped in bundles in the safe,'' said Crimaldi. ``They'd get a notice, another notice and another notice. Nothing ever happened. Word spread, merchant to merchant: `They're not going to get you.' ``Well, now, hello and surprise!''

DOC.HEAD: New Zealand Court Awards Custody to Washington Doctor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with quotes from father; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The father of an 8-year-old girl embroiled in a bitter parental court fight says it is ``meaningless'' to continue the battle following a New Zealand decision awarding custody to his former wife. Eric Foretich, a Northern Virginia oral surgeon, said the decision giving Elizabeth Morgan custody of their daughter Hilary means ``one of us is going to have to give up, and I guess it's going to be me. It's meaningless to continue. What's the point? ``I can't physically take her from New Zealand, and I'm not going to move there,'' Foretich said. Under the terms of a court order issued by New Zealand family court Judge P.D. Mahoney, Morgan must remain with her daughter, Hilary Foretich, in Christchurch, New Zealand, WUSA-TV and WRC-TV reported late Thursday. She also must report to the court every six months on the girl's progress and refrain from any further publicity about the case, the stations said. In New Zealand, there was no announcement today of any court decision. Such decisions are often kept secret, and New Zealand law provides strict penalties for violating gag orders. Hilary's legal representative in the case, Isabel Mitchell, would make no comment Friday night. Morgan separated from Foretich before Hilary was born. Later, in a custody battle publicized around the world, she accused him of sexually abusing the child. Foretich has denied the allegations. When District of Columbia Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon ordered Morgan to allow Foretich to visit her daughter, she sent Hilary into hiding with her grandparents and went to jail for more than two years. Mahoney said he ruled in Morgan's favor despite what he said were serious reservations about the negative attitudes she had fostered in her daughter, the television stations reported. The judge reportedly said there was a strong argument for saying the child should remain in her mother's care, where her physical, educational, spiritual and emotional needs are being met. Morgan's brother, Robert Morgan, declined to comment late Thursday. Her attorney, Stephen Sachs, also refused to comment, saying a gag order had been imposed in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Five Possibly Targeted in Kahane Suspect's List
DOC.TEXT: FBI officials have warned five New York leaders that their names were found on a list kept by the man accused of killing Israeli extremist Rabbi Meir Kahane, according to a published report. The list included Rep. Gary Ackerman, two federal judges, a former assistant U.S. attorney and a columnist for the weekly Jewish Press, New York Newsday said in today's editions. FBI officials believe El Sayyid Nosair acted alone when he gunned down Kahane during a Nov. 5 meeting at a midtown hotel, but are still trying to determine whether he was backed by a terrorist group. The list appears to strengthen the theory that the killing of Kahane, the founder of the militant Jewish Defense League and an aggressive advocate of Israeli security, may have been part of a larger conspiracy against Jewish Americans, New York Newsday said. ``It certainly adds to suspicions that this was part of some greater plot,'' the newspaper quoted an unnamed law enforcement official as saying. The official added it doesn't necessarily show that anyone else was involved in the shooting. Joe Valliquette, a spokesman for the FBI, confirmed that federal agents are looking for links between Nosair and any terrorist groups, but declined to comment on the investigation. Newsday said, quoting unnamed law enforcement sources, that investigators found names of five people scrawled on a bank calendar in Nosair's home: Ackerman; U.S. District Judges Jack B. Weinstein and Edward Korman; former assistant U.S. attorney Jacques Simmelman; and Howard Adelman, a columnist in the pro-Israeli Jewish Press. Investigators said there may have been a sixth name, but it could not be confirmed. Law enforcement officials said Nosair has not explained the cryptic list, but they warned the people named on in to take precautions, Newsday said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Astronauts: This Countdown is the One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Columbia is...', to UPDATE with forecast slightly worse, add quote on countdown. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `NASA has...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's seven astronauts expressed optimism the shuttle's fifth countdown would lead to liftoff as the clock ticked toward this weekend's launch. ``This time, why, I think we have a very good feeling. We're ready to go,'' Columbia's commander Vance Brand said after arriving with his crew late Thursday from Johnson Space Center in Houston. Columbia is scheduled to blast off at 1:28 a.m. EST Sunday. The countdown proceeded uninterrupted, with only ``nickel and dime problems ... the type of things we typically have during a launch countdown,'' NASA test director Al Sofge said today. Meteorologists today forecast a 65 percent chance of good weather at launch time, slightly worse than earlier predictions. The main concerns are low clouds and possible high winds. NASA has been trying since May to send up Columbia with the $150 million Astro observatory, which will be operated by the crew. Because of hydrogen leaks, three previous countdowns came to an abrupt halt hours before liftoff. Numerous repairs were needed before the shuttle was pronounced safe. Problems with the observatory also forced a postponement. Comet Levy, one of the objects to be observed, is moving rapidly out of the solar system and not nearly as visible as it would have been in September, during the last launch attempt. ``You've all heard comets are harbingers of bad news and bad luck. Well, this time we have no comet so we're going to go,'' said astronaut Jeff Hoffman, one of the crew's four astronomers. Among those afraid to get their hopes up are scientists who have been working on the Astro mission for years. ``We're just as excited. The only qualifier is we've learned to be somewhat skeptical if it will actually happen until we see it get launched,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator for one of Astro's four telescopes. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope will focus on some of the hottest objects in the universe. The mission originally was scheduled for 1986 but was delayed by the Challenger accident that year.

DOC.HEAD: More British Troops For Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: British army reinforcements arrived in Northern Ireland today to combat an expected Christmas season terrorist campaign, the army said. The army headquarters in Northern Ireland said the extra 600 troops were being deployed to help the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's police force. It is the first time in four years that reinforcements have been sent to the British-run province, the army said. ``This is not a reactive measure but part of a prudent management of security force activity,'' an army spokesman said. ``They will be retained in Northern Ireland as long as it is absolutely necessary.'' The constabulary said intelligence reports indicated that both the outlawed Irish Republican Army, which is mainly Roman Catholic, and Protestant paramilitary groups planned an increase in attacks in the coming weeks. A spokesman refused to say where the troops will be based, but sources said they would be spread throughout the province, increasing patrols and roadblocks. Seventy-two people have been killed in terrorist incidents in 1990, 27 of them since October. In 1989, 62 people were killed. The reinforcements bring the number of British troops in Northern Ireland to about 11,000, the Ministry of Defense said. Britain sent troops to Northern Ireland when sectarian and political violence erupted in August 1969. Since then, nearly 2,900 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Argues That Patience With Saddam Could Be Immoral
With PM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle responded to calls for caution in the Persian Gulf by saying that too much patience with Saddam Hussein carries a steep moral price. Holding back on the use of military force against Iraq could lead to greater U.S. casualties and increased suffering for the people of Kuwait, Quayle said in a speech Thursday at Seton Hall University. ``With every day that passes,'' the plight of the people of Kuwait ``grows more and more desperate,'' Quayle said. ``Is this a moral course of action?'' ``Will continued patience with Iraq help make the world vulnerable to nuclear blackmail by Saddam Hussein?'' he asked. ``Does patience today risk greater American casualties tomorrow?'' Quayle's call for a limit to patience countered calls for caution by two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who on Wednesday urged Bush to give sanctions at least a year to work. And on Thursday, former Navy Secretary James Webb told the Senate Armed Service Committee that ``the president's mistake in sending so many troops should not be compounded by a further error in using them in a premature, unprovoked ground offensive.'' Quayle argued that a precedent had to be set in the post-Cold War era that the world community would not tolerate territorial aggression. ``If Saddam Hussein succeeds in his aggression, it is likely that his success will embolden other dictators to emulate his example,'' he said. The Persian Gulf crisis ``will set a precedent - either on behalf of greater world order or on behalf of greater world chaos.'' Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri have appealed to Bush to give time for U.N. sanctions against Iraq to work. Quayle countered by throwing down the gauntlet to Congress to act if members did not approve of the president's policy. ``If Congress doesn't like what the president is doing, Congress has the power to deny funds to the president,'' Quayle said. Several dozen protesters greeted the vice president with banners that read ``Hey Dan, Should I Join The National Guard?'' Quayle avoided serving in Vietnam by joining the guard in Indiana. But Quayle's audience at the Roman Catholic school was largely sympathetic. It hissed and booed at a student who asked Quayle how he could push for a war that may involve tens of thousands of casualties when he avoided combat in the Vietnam War. ``There's nothing wrong with serving your country by serving in the National Guard,'' Quayle said to overwhelming applause.

DOC.HEAD: First Red Cross Aid Convoy Leaves for Moscow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with charities continuing work, KGB to watch over distribution of western aid, quotes. ADDS byline. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Germany-Soviet Aid
DOC.TEXT: The German Red Cross trucked 5,000 food packages to Moscow today in a growing worldwide effort led by the Germans to try to stave off winter starvation in the Soviet Union. The aid left this morning from the Red Cross's central warehouse in nearby Meckenheim in a convoy of trucks, trailers and small buses. The president of Germany's Red Cross, Botho zu Sayn-Wittgenstein, said he expected the food - individual packages prepared and donated by German citizens - to arrive in the Soviet capital in about four days. It is the first land transport of German-organized food to leave for the Soviet Union. Another truck convoy organized by the Catholic relief organization, Caritas, is to leave on Saturday. On Thursday, a plane carrying 25,000 pre-packaged meals for children's hospitals and orphanages arrived in Moscow in the first shipment by German charities aimed at easing the chaotic food situation in the Soviet Union. Also Thursday, the government decided to give the Soviets foodstuffs and medical supplies built up against a repeat of the 1948-49 Berlin Blockade, in which Josef Stalin tried to starve the West's isolated island in Berlin. Those reserves include 66,000 tons of rye, 26,000 tons of canned meat and 7,500 tons of butter. Berlin officials estimate the supplies could feed 10 million Soviets for a month and value the reserve at $340 million. There is rapidly increasing concern that food shortages this winter in the Soviet Union could lead to unrest and destabilize the government of President Mikhail Gorbachev. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has made aid to the Soviets a top item on his international agenda, arguing that without a stable Soviet Union ongoing reform in eastern Europe could be endangered. His concern culminated this week in a two-day meeting between German experts, led by Kohl's top foreign policy adviser, and Soviet officials to discuss expected shortages and how to prevent similar problems in the future. Government spokesman Hans Klein acknowledged the food donations were stopgap measures aimed at getting the Soviets through the winter. But he said the delegation, led by Kohl adviser Horst Telstchik, ``negotiated long-term cooperation'' between the Soviets and Germans. They discussed how Germany could help improve the Soviet Union's problem-plagued transport system, food production and rundown factories. Leaders of 15 private charitable organizations, meanwhile, met in Bonn today to coordinate donations and logistics. A government committee was formed in the Soviet Union to help insure the private aid initiatives would not be hindered by bureaucracy or transportation problems. And in Moscow, the KGB announced today it was forming a special unit to control distribution and prevent theft of humanitarian aid. Western diplomats had expressed that concern donated food might be stolen by black marketeers, siphoned off by corrupt officials, or simply rot because of inefficient Soviet transportation and storage facilities. The mass-circulation Bild newspaper has started its own campaign - ``A Heart for Russia'' - encouraging the public to assemble aid packets or donate $34 dollars minimum to a special Red Cross fund for Soviet hunger relief. The grass-roots campaign took on an official character Wednesday night, as Kohl went on the national ZDF television network to appeal for donations. Stern magazine, allied with ZDF in the campaign, said Thursday it was donating $340,000. The action is an ironic twist in the history of two former enemies. More than 20 million Russians died fighting the Germans in World War II, and West Berliners nearly starved before the Allies' Berlin Airlift rescued them. These days, Germans, led by Kohl, credit the Soviet Union with clearing the way for reunification, which will culminate Sunday in the first free and united German elections since 1932.

DOC.HEAD: Syria Assures Britain of Efforts to Free Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Syria has assured Britain it will work for the release of Western hostages in Lebanon, London's new envoy to Damascus said today. ``The Syrian government gives us assurances that they will work strenuously for their release, not only for British hostages, but for all Western hostages,'' said Charge d'Affaires Andrew Tesorieri, two days after the countries ended a four-year break in diplomatic relations. ``The Syrian government has regarded its efforts as being done in humanitarian spirit, and we look forward to some results from our joint efforts,'' Tesorieri said at an embassy ceremony. At a news conference on Thursday, Tesorieri said the restoration of ties could help get the four British hostages released. ``With the establishment of relations between Britain and Iran and between Britain and Syria, we would expect this to provide momentum to the efforts to secure their release,'' he said. The pro-Iranian Hezbollah is the umbrella group for the hostage holders in Lebanon. Syria, with 40,000 troops in the country under a 1976 Arab League peace-keeping mandate, is the major power broker there. Britain severed ties with Syria in 1986 after accusing Damascus of sponsoring an abortive attempt to blow up an Israeli jet with 375 people aboard. Tesorieri said Britain restored ties after being assured by Syria that it would not support international terrorism in the future. For the past four years, Australia has handled British interests in Damascus. There are 13 Westerners missing and believed kidnapped by Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon. They include four Britons, six Americans, two Germans and an Italian. The longest held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in March 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Charges Illegal Promotion of Growth Hormone by Dairy Board
DOC.TEXT: The National Dairy Board has been illegally promoting an experimental growth hormone for dairy cows, a critic of the hormone says in in a lawsuit. Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Washington, D.C.-based Foundation on Economic Trends, said he filed the lawsuit Thursday after discovering that the dairy board had contracted with a public relations firm to promote the growth hormone. Rifkin has used various legal maneuvers to try to block the use of bovine growth hormone on the grounds that it is unsafe for humans. The latest action is based on documents he obtained under the Freedom of Information Act that Rifkin says show the dairy board was working in collusion with the growth hormone's makers to promote it. He also petitioned the U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Thursday to ``immediately halt any promotion of this product by FDA officials and to immediately rescind the use of this product in the marketplace until it is approved.'' The FDA is considering whether to approve the hormone for routine use, but it has already allowed milk from experimentally treated cows to be released for human consumption. Yvonne Dock, the dairy board's spokeswoman, said she had no comment on Rifkin's action or his remarks. William Grigg, an FDA spokesman, also had no comment, saying the agency had not yet seen the petition. Grigg defended the decision to allow consumption of milk containing the hormone. ``The safety to human beings is clear,'' Grigg said. He said the hormone has no effect in humans and occurs naturally in milk, ``so we've always consumed it.'' Rifkin and other critics have charged that the hormone could have deleterious effects on human health. Questions have also been raised about the economic consequences of boosting the milk supply and thus presumably lowering milk prices. Rifkin said the dairy board is prevented by law from promoting such substances before they are approved by the FDA. ``The dairy board cannot put out any information regarding efficacy or safety of a product before its approval,'' Rifkin said. ``It is a violation of the law. Nor can they collude and be in meetings with private companies to be in such a campaign.'' The lawsuit seeks to block the board ``from continuing with their campaign to promote this product,'' Rifkin said. The board was set up by Congress to help increase the consumption of dairy products produced in the United States, said Maureen Bergen, the board's director of advertising and promotion programs. The Department of Agriculture oversees and approves its expenses, she said, but the board is funded by dairy farmers, not the government. The documents obtained in Rifkin's Freedom of Information Act request include minutes of an April meeting in which the board agreed to spend $1,085,000 on a public relations firm ``for the management of the BST issue.'' BST stands for bovine somatotropin, the technical term for the hormone. In a March 12 letter obtained by Rifkin, Ernest Miller, chairman ofthe board's industry and public relations committee, said that the law requires that no board funds ``are to be spent to influence legislation on regulation.'' ``If NDB (the National Dairy Board) were to become proactive on BST while it is still under government review, that action could be construed as lobbying on behalf of the pharmaceutical companies,'' the letter continued.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak's Party Headed For Victory; Three Dead In Election Violence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with more election results. Pickup 5th graf, `Winners of...'
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak's party today appeared headed for victory in parliamentary elections boycotted by major opposition groups. Clashes left at least three people dead and dozens wounded. By mid-afternoon today, unofficial tabulations showed Mubarak's National Democrats with 70 seats and independents 18. Officials said runoffs will be held on Thursday to decide 89 seats. Unoffocial results in the other 277 electoral districts were not immediately available. The preliminary results were distributed by the government's Middle East News Agency. Official returns were expected later today or Saturday. Officials said many seats needed a runoff because many candidates entered the faces, meaning no one got a majority of votes. Many Egyptians did not bother to vote because they see the 454-seat People's Assembly as a rubber stamp of the government's policies. Major opposition parties also boycotted them. Winners from the governing party included Cabinet ministers Youssef Wali of agriculture, Ahmed Fat'hi Sorour of education and Maher Abaza of electricity and energy. Fayda Kamel, one of four women among the National Democrats' 444 candidates, also won. More than 16 million of Egypt's 55 million people were eligible to vote, but analysts said the turnout was as low as 30 percent in some Cairo districts. Some voting districts in the countryside, however, reported as many as 70 percent of registered voters cast ballots. The elections were marred by a bloody clash between police and supporters of an independent candidate near the Mediterranean city of Damietta. A security source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said at least three people died and more than 41 were wounded. The state-owned newspaper Al-Ahram put the casualties at one dead and 80 wounded. Al-Wafd, newspaper of the opposition New Wafd party, which boycotted the election, said five died and 51 were wounded. Al-Ahram reported another 19 people wounded in scattered clashes among followers of rival candidates in several provinces. Colorful banners carrying names of candidates fluttered over Cairo's congested streets, vans with loudspeakers campaigned in many districts and people milled around polling stations today to watch or distribute handbills. Mubarak's party, which has held sweeping majorities of more than 75 percent in the three parliaments since he became president in 1981, was sure to maintain if not increase its sway in the parliament. The fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, banned since 1954 but tolerated by the government, and three other parties stayed away from the contest. They are the right-of-center New Wafd, left-of-center Socialist Labor and centrist Liberals. In the disbanded assembly, they comprised the largest opposition ever, almost 100 seats. Mubarak suspended the old parliament after the Supreme Constitutional Court ruled in May that the chamber was elected in 1987 under an unconstitutional law. He decreed a new election law to meet court objections. Under the old law, voters had to choose between voting for independents or voting for party lists. The new law allows votes for individual candidates only.

DOC.HEAD: Philly's AIDS Office Co-ordinator Diagnosed With Disease
DOC.TEXT: After fighting AIDS for years as a public official, the director of the city's AIDS Activities Co-ordinating Office has found out he has the disease. James Hymes, director of the office since June, said he was diagnosed Monday. Hymes, 40, has worked in the city Health Department for 11 years, most of that time as a program analyst. Hymes, now out on leave, said he wasn't sure when he'd resume his job as AIDS director. He said he decided to have a blood test for the virus in October because of an unusual weight loss - 15 pounds in 30 days. Even though he expected the diagnosis, Hymes said, ``when they tell you you're going to die, it's a little difficult.'' Hymes said the test results did not surprise him because ``I just assumed I was positive.'' He told the newspaper 62 of his friends, several of whom were his sexual partners, had died of AIDS. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, leaving it defenseless against disease. Barry Savitz, executive deputy health commissioner, said he expected Hymes to resume working ``when his doctor feels that he's ready to do so.'' ``We look forward to his return, just as we look forward to maintaining the employment of any person with AIDS,'' Savitz said. Ennes Littrell, director of a group called Action AIDS, called Hymes ``incredibly accessible and supportive of our work.''

DOC.HEAD: Tear Gas and Rubber Bullets Used to Disperse Bangladesh Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 12th pvs, `Troops fired..' to UPDATE with government report from Dhaka. Pickup 13th, `In Chittagong...'
DOC.TEXT: In Bangladesh, police fired tear gas and rubber bullets today to drive off thousands of rock-throwing protesters demanding President Hussain Muhammad Ershad resign, according to reports reaching India. About 10,000 people defied bans on processions and poured through the streets of Dhaka to protest the state of emergency imposed Tuesday night, the unofficial reports said. Several people were injured but exact figures were not available, said witnesses who demanded anonymity because of a government-imposed news blackout. Reports by The Associated Press and other news agencies out of Dhaka, the capital, are subject to prior censorship. A government censor today deleted 19 lines from a 32-line AP story from Dhaka. Ershad, a former army general who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982, ordered the emergency after six weeks of increasing political turbulence. The unrest was prompted by Ershad's announcement that a new presidential election would be held in June 1991 and he would run again. The country's top opposition leaders, Sheik Hasina of the Awami League and Khaleda Zia of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, refuse to participate in any elections unless Ershad first lets a caretaker administration take power. The around-the-clock curfew, imposed with the state of emergency, was lifted for seven hours today in Dhaka to enable people to buy food and attend prayer sessions on the weekly Islamic holy day. Crowds streamed out of the Baitul Mukarram mosque in the center of Dhaka, shouting demands for Ershad's resignation. After a half-mile march, their numbers had swelled to about 10,000. Security forces fired tear gas and many of the marchers hurled bricks. A block from the mosque, police used batons to break up another anti-Ershad demonstration, the unofficial reports said. Several thousand women, students, journalists and cultural activists were dispersed by the baton-swinging police. Most people returned home when the curfew was re-imposed at its scheduled time of 3 p.m. (4 a.m. EST). Government troops and police patrolled the city, periodically chasing small crowds that gathered in alleys and narrow lanes. Troops fired rubber bullets in some areas, according to unofficial reports from witnesses. The curfew also was relaxed in Chittagong, Khulna and Rajshahi, state-run radio said in Dhaka. The Bangladeshi government, in a news release late Thursday, said the situation remained largely peaceful. It said, however, that an angry mob tried to attack a power station, a government office and a official's residence in the northeastern town of Sylhet Thursday. Police fired five rounds, wounding one person, the news release said. In Chittagong, Bangladesh's second-largest city, 446 doctors, teachers and staffers at the Chittagong Medical College and Hospital resigned in protest of the emergency declaration, according to reports conveyed by intermediaries. Ershad said the state of emergency was needed to preserve ``internal security and the national economy.'' The government's claims that all was peaceful Thursday were disputed by airline passengers who arrived in neighboring countries. Travelers who reached Bangkok and Calcutta reported hearing periodic gunfire in Dhaka. They said cars were burned and rocks thrown by government opponents. Opposition leaders claimed Ershad's security forces shot and killed 50 people and wounded more than 1,000 in a half-dozen cities Wednesday. The opposition claims, which have sometimes been exaggerated in the past, could not be verified. Diplomatic sources in New Delhi said they had reports that four people were killed and 15 wounded Wednesday. The government has not issued any casualty reports since the state of emergency was imposed. Curfew has been in place in the four biggest cities: Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna and Rajshahi. With a per capital annual income of $160, Bangladesh's 110 million inhabitants are among the poorest in the world. Ershad's eight years in power have brought a measure of stability to this 19-year-old nation born of a war of secession from Pakistan, but his opponents accuse him of staying in power by rigging the 1986 presidential election.

DOC.HEAD: KGB to Watch Over Distribution of Western Aid
With PM-Germany-Soviet Convoy
DOC.TEXT: The KGB announced today it was forming a special unit to control distribution and prevent theft of humanitarian aid from the West. The first planeload of donated food reached the capital Thursday evening and was promptly distributed to children's hospitals, orphanages and homes for the retarded. They began receiving the pre-packaged meals and chocolate today. The first shipment came from German charities. Humanitarian organizations in the United States, Italy and the Nordic countries were also preparing to send milk, flour, canned goods and other staples. Western diplomats expressed concern that donated food might be stolen by black marketeers, siphoned off by corrupt officials or simply rot because of inefficient Soviet transportation and storage facilities. Worried that even a single incident of theft could produce bad publicity and slow the Western aid, the Supreme Soviet legislature voted Nov. 23 to put the KGB in charge of making sure the food goes where it's supposed to. Tass reported today that the security police had set up a new headquarters to ``coordinate measures in the battle against economic sabotage'' and ensure ``the proper use of imported products and humanitarian aid provided by foreign countries.'' The official news agency said KGB officials ``view the fulfillment of the Supreme Soviet's order as one of its most important tasks, dictated by the difficult political situation and economic crisis in the country.'' Food shortages have worsened greatly this fall, leading to rationing of meat, butter, sugar and other necessities in Leningrad and dozens of other cities across Russia and the Ukraine. In Moscow, sugar and cigarettes are rationed, and the list of goods that are hard to find in state stores grows every week. It now includes milk, eggs, sausage, cheese and matches. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak has warned that without Western aid, major cities could face hunger and popular unrest over the winter. Many Soviets now openly blame President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's perestroika reforms for their discomfort. Reasons for the chaotic food situation vary. As the Soviet Union begins the transition to a market economy, many farmers have stopped selling their crops through state stores at low official prices. Instead, they are taking their products to private farmers' markets, where prices are often 10 times as high. In addition, some of the restive Soviet republics, including Georgia, Byelorussia and Lithuania, have cut off shipments of food products outside their borders. Also, black marketeering appears to be on the rise, and many Soviets allege that Communist Party bureaucrats are intentionally creating economic problems to try to stop Gorbachev's reforms and hold onto their privileged positions. Gorbachev said on Thursday that he and other Communists were ``guilty before the working class'' because they have failed to address the concerns of ordinary people.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Opt to End One-Party Rule
DOC.TEXT: The Zambian Parliament passed a bill today allowing the formation of political parties for the first time in 17 years. The 125 lawmakers, more than two-thirds of whom were appointed by President Kenneth Kaunda, passed the bill unanimously after four days of heated debate. The bill, to be presented to Kaunda for final approval on Tuesday, clears the way for multiparty general parliamentary and presidential elections in one of Africa's poorest nations. But opposition supporters are still arguing over a remaining clause in the constitution that bans other parties from contesting by-elections before national polls open next year. ``The clause may end up as a mockery of the entire democratization of the system we are talking about,'' said the former general-secretary for the ruling party, Humprey Mulemba. Mulemba is a staunch supporter of the pro-democracy opposition group, the Movement For Multiparty Democracy. The group was legalized in July following violent food riots and anti-government protests that left at least 27 people dead. Labor leaders have been at the forefront of the group's campaign to end nearly two decades of single party rule in this southern African nation of 7.5 million people. In September, the ruling United National Independence Party bowed to political pressure and said it will reintroduce a Western-style democracy. Kaunda, who led this former British colony to independence in 1964, imposed one-party rule in 1973. Zambia is the latest African nation to officially reintroduce pluralism. On Thursday, the former Marxist Mozambican government permitted multiple political parties for the first time since the southern African nation gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Capture Major Town Where French Troops Are Based
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th pvs, ``The spokesman...' to UPDATE with Chad govt statement. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Chad contends...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebel forces have captured the largest town in eastern Chad, meeting no resistance from a 500-strong French contingent based there, the French Foreign Ministry said today. The troops of rebel leader Idriss Deby marched in and took over Abeche, where 500 French soldiers are based, on Thursday. Chad government forces had reportedly retreated westward, leaving Abeche an open target. ``To our knowledge, the rebel forces are in Abeche,'' said a Foreign Ministry spokesman. ``There was no action against the French soldiers.'' The spokesman said the French did not oppose the rebel takeover. ``The mission of French forces is not to intervene in confrontations between Chadians,'' he said. Chad is a former French colony. The government of President Hissene Habre, meeting this morning in a special session, said it was determined to ``definitively destroy the mercenary hordes'' and predicted ``total victory.'' It made no mention of a rebel takeover at Abeche, a town of 25,000 to 30,000 inhabitants. Chad contends that the rebels, based in neighboring Sudan, are backed by Libya. But France says the fighting is among Chadians. Libya denies involvement in the fighting. The ministry spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, reiterated that ``to our knowledge, there are no non-Chadian elements'' among the rebels. On Thursday, France announced it was sending 150 Foreign Legion parachutists to bolster its 1,000 soldiers in Chad as part of Operation Sparrowhawk, a ``defensive and dissuasive'' force first sent in 1986. The other 500 troops are based in N'Djamena, the capital. France said the Legionnaire's mission was to improve protection of French troops and nationals in Chad. The rebels moved into Abeche as government troops, failing to mount an effective counteroffensive, retreated to Oum Hadjer, 60 miles west on the road to N'Djamena, according to news reports in France. France said on Thursday that the situation was worsening since the start of the rebel offensive Nov. 10. Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement said that France was ``at this moment'' examining requests by the government of President Habre for more arms. ``It's clear the Chadian army could have substantial needs,'' Chevenement said without elaborating. Rebel leader Deby, who received his military training in France, helped bring Habre to power in 1982 and acted as his military adviser. But he fled in April 1989 amid allegations of a coup plot. Chad contends the rebel offensive is a new effort by Libya to take over the country, Libya's southern neighbor. Libya, backing former rebel leader Goukouni Oueddei, occupied northern Chad in 1986, but was chased out in a series of lightning victories. The two countries signed a peace treaty in 1989, but continue to dispute a Libyan-occupied strip of land on Chad's northern border.

DOC.HEAD: Franks Views Contrasts Sharply With Other Black House Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to insert word Republican; picks up 3rd graf, `Franks, who
DOC.TEXT: The first black Republican o win a House seat in two generations comes to Washington with an agenda closer to that of Georgia Rep. Newt Gingrich than his 24 black colleagues across the aisle. Gary Franks, a city alderman from Waterbury, Conn., opposes tax increases, supports the death penalty and says he won't vote for any civil rights bill that contains even a hint of racial quotas. His Nov. 6 election victory over liberal Democrat Toby Moffett in Connecticut's 5th Congressional District makes Franks the highest-ranking black elected Republican in the country. Franks, who is touring Capitol Hill this week for a series of orientation meetings, says he's ready to join the 24 Democrats in the Congressional Black Caucus. ``I qualify. I'm black and I'm a congressman,'' said Franks, a 37-year-old real estate developer. ``I'm a fiscal conservative Republican and I think that in itself will offer a difference between me and the some 25 members of the caucus.'' He will be the caucus' only opponent of this year's civil rights bill and the lone advocate for a brand of conservatism aggressively opposed by many other caucus members. ``He will be one voice that will essentially be, in terms of voting, ineffectual,'' said David Bositis, a senior research associate at the Joint Center for Political Studies, a Washington think tank that focuses on black political issues. The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People says Franks won't attract support by waving the conservative Republican banner. ``We hope that he is not used by the right wing to sing the praises of their position,'' said Edward Hailes, a lawyer in the NAACP's Washington office. But the Republican National Committee does plan to enlist the freshman lawmaker as a magnet for black voters. ``He'll be a national spokesman for the party,'' said Charles Black, the RNC's chief spokesman. ``He'll be a great example for us to recruit other blacks to run for office and to draw black voters into the Republican Party.'' Franks says his first loyalty will be to his district. Nevertheless, he says, ``I would like to do all that I can to help my national party and I will do so if time allows.'' There has been no black Republican in the House since Illinois Rep. Oscar de Priest stepped down after three terms in 1935. The last black in the Senate was Republican Edward Brooke of Massachusetts, who was defeated in 1978. Brooke represented the then-healthy liberal wing of the Republican Party. But Franks describes himself as ``a real conservative and a real Republican.'' Observers say that could be a problem when it comes to recruiting blacks to the GOP fold. ``In terms of his policy positions, they are completely repudiated by the black community,'' Bositis said. ``The idea that a candidate who was sent to Congress by white voters would be embraced around the country by black voters is ridiculous.'' The black caucus has been quiet on the subject of Franks since his election. Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., the senior black member of Congress, said Franks' Republican status won't prevent him from participating.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Accepts White House Christmas Tree
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush accepted the White House Christmas tree today with holiday wishes for peace. The 18-foot Fraser fir from North Carolina arrived at the White House in a horse-drawn wagon bedecked with ribbons and holly. Mrs. Bush said the tree was ``perfect'' and thanked Michael and Bruce Lacey of Newland, N.C., for the tree. Mrs. Bush was asked if she had any special Christmas wishes this season, when holiday preparations are overshadowed by events in the Persian Gulf where U.S. forces are deployed. She answered ``peace'' and said ``I have great faith'' that the United States will not go to war. The tree will be on display in the Blue Room of the White House. For the tenth year in a row, Mrs. Bush late today will place the main ornament on the top of the National Christmas which grows in the Ellipse behind the White House.

DOC.HEAD: Kenyan President Meets South African Foreign Minister
DOC.TEXT: South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha today met with President Daniel arap Moi in the first publicly acknowledged, high-level contact between the two countries in 27 years. The two talked for about 30 minutes at Moi's official Nairobi residence and Botha conveyed a message to the Kenyan leader from President F.W. De Klerk, according to Lee Njiru, Moi's press officer. Njiru said he did not know the contents of the message and declined to say whether Botha had other plans while in the East African nation. South Africa's Foreign Ministry said the men discussed matters of ``mutual interest,'' which apparently included plans to establish air links between Kenya and South Africa, which Moi scuttled last month, according to the South African Press Association. The news agency said a South African Airways flight was ready to leave Jan Smuts International Airport in Johannesburg for Nairobi on Saturday if the talks went well. An airlines spokesman, Leon Els, said an Airbus was ready to go should permission be obtained, according to the South African Press Association. Moi suspended negotiations last month following sharp criticism of the plan by African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, and said flights between Kenya and South Africa would resume only after the apartheid system of racial segregation was dismantled. The ANC is one of the major South African groups negotiating with de Klerk for total abolition of apartheid and a new political order. A Western diplomat in Nairobi described Botha's visit to Kenya as an early pitch for trade with South Africa, the most industrialized nation in the continent. ``Kenya is trying to jump the queue and get trade agreements nailed down before apartheid is lifted and the others crowd in. This is about dollars not politics,'' said the envoy, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Kenya, like most other African nations, officially has no ties of any kind with South Africa because of that nation's apartheid policy. But there have been unconfirmed reports that Kenya continued trading with South Africa through third parties in black-ruled states in southern Africa. Kenya also has continued to provide transit facilities to about half a dozen airlines flying the lucrative London-Johannesburg route.

DOC.HEAD: W.Va. Supreme Court Upholds DRiver's License Law
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court today upheld a state law that allows young school dropouts to be denied or stripped of their driver's license. The court split 3-2 in upholding the nation's first law aimed at denying licenses to 16- and 17-year-old dropouts who fail to complete school. CHIef Justice Richard Neely said the affected student must be offered a hearing before the superintendent of schools or an authorized official before the student quits so he can be notified of the consequences. The law was passed by the LEgislature in 1988 to allow revocation or denial of a license to a student who drops out before completing high school. Christopher Butch, attorney for dropout Michael Means of Charleston, said the court test was a first in the nation. ``The whole world is watching you today,'' Butch had argued when the case was presented. Means lost his license when he quit school in 1988. He turned 16 on March 26, 1988, and dropped out of school the next month but lost his license even though the law was not enacted until that June. Assistant Attorney General Bruce Walker said the law is an incentive to keep students in school. ``I think holding a bazooka at a child's head would work just as well,'' Butch said during earlier court testimony. The court said the Means case is moot since the teen-ager is now 18 and can get a license, but it ruled on the matter anyway. ``A child who has an opportunity to go to school and deliberately chooses not to avail himself or herself of such opportunity, demonstrates a general lack of responsibility,'' Neely wrote. Neely said the law provides that when the withdrawal of a student from school is by mutual consent of school authorities and the child, a waiver of the license revocation may be granted. Justices Thomas B. Miller and Thomas E. McHugh dissented.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Call up Nearly 3,000 More Reservists
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps said today it is ordering 2,996 reservists to report for active duty next weekend in support of Operation Desert Shield. The Navy announced a call-up of 437 reservists, mostly for medical and intelligence support. The Marines said 2,274 reservists were ordered to report Dec. 9 For duty at Camp COurtney in OKinawa, Japan, the home station of the 3rd Marine Expeditionary Force. It did not say why they were needed there, but the call-up could mean parts of the 3rd Marines will be sent to the Persian Gulf area. The Marines also announced that 722 reservists were ordered to report for active duty Dec. 8. About 300 of those will go to Camp Pendleton, Calif., with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, and the rest will be assigned to 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Lejeune, N.C., ``for processing and to await further orders.'' Complete lists of the units being called were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says DeConcini Crossed Bounds of Propriety
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal regulator told the Senate Ethics Committee today that he believed Arizona Sen. Dennis DEConcini crossed the bounds of propriety in trying to help savings and loan owner Charles Keating Jr. The regulator, Michael Patriarca, said the other four ``Keating Five'' senators under investigation may not have crossed that line. Patriarca, a San Francisco-based thrift regulator, made that assessment in summarizing a meeting he and three other regulators held with the five senators on April 9, 1987, when the senators were trying to help Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. ``It's only where the senators attempted to influence, to change the outcome of the examination (of Lincoln), of the regulatory treatment for this specific institution, that impropriety was breached,'' Patriarca said. ``My personal view is SENator DeConcini did that,'' he said. ``It's not clear to me that any of the others did.'' He was responding to questions from the committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Warren RUdman, R-N.H. A day earlier, Patriarca said the regulators faced ``a full court press'' on behalf of Lincoln by the senators. Patriarca also testified that his former boss, Edwin J. Gray, was upset after a meeting he held privately a week before with four of the senators. He said GRay told him that one, Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., had offered him a deal on behalf of Lincoln - that the thrift would make more home loans if the regulators would back off a regulation limiting Lincoln's ability to make speculative equity investments. ``HE was agitated,'' Patriarca said of Gray, who then was head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. ``He was stressed or distressed, and he told me that he was shocked by the meeting,'' he said. Patriarca testified for a second day before the Ethics Committee's hearing into alegations the five senators improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating, a major financial contributor. Patriarca also told Rudman that his own efforts to bend over backwards to be fair to Keating's thrift ultimately resulted in a delay of several months in completion of the regulators' critical examination of Lincoln. Under cross-examination by William Taylor, lawyer for Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Patriarca said Cranston wasn't present in their meeting when the other senators mounted what he had described as ``a full court press'' on behalf of Keating. On Thursday, Patriarca depicted DeConcini as the leader of the senators' efforts. ``It was my impression, quite frankly, that Senator DeConcini was negotiating on behalf of Lincoln ... attempting to get us, the regulators, to change our position on the examination,'' Patriarca said. The five senators are accused of intervening improperly in the regulatory process on behalf of Keating and Lincoln after the lawmakers and their favored causes received $1.3 million in political contributions from the financier. Lincoln's $2 billion collapse has become emblematic of the disaster that engulfed the savings and loan industry. Besides DeConcini and Cranston, the senators under scrutiny are Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. Patriarca, now western regional director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, went beyond the allegations leveled in four days of testimony by his onetime boss. Gray, the five senators' chief accuser, said he felt improperly pressured by four of the senators in a disputed April 2, 1987, meeting. In the session, Gray referred the lawmakers to his West Coast staff. Patriarca described the meeting between the senators and San Francisco regulators, which took place on April 9. ``The tone that the meeting took was that the senators seemed to have made up their minds ... that we were in fact harassing Lincoln, that we were incorrect, wrong, and that basically we got the full-court press,'' he said. But Patriarca said the senators became less aggressive after he revealed that examiners intended to seek a Justice DEpartment criminal investigation of some of Lincoln's practices. Patriarca said the regulators found ``absolutely reckless'' practices at Lincoln, with no credit documentation for 52 loans they examined. He said the thrift was engaged in highly risky practices. He said there was evidence the files had been stuffed with phony underwriting documents. He said Cranston left soon after the April 9 meeting began, saying he shared the concerns of the other lawmakers but had duties on the Senate floor. Cranston accounted for $889,000 of the $1.3 million contributed by Keating and his associates. Much of the money was given to voter registration projects supported by the CAlifornia senator. Cranston said in testimony released Thursday that his involvement with Keating was ``politically stupid.'' The testimony came last April in a closed session with the committee. ``I see nothing ethically, morally or legally wrong with the amounts that were involved,'' Cranston testified. ``I will grant that it turned out to be politically stupid and unwise, because it's caused an uproar that I regret. But being politically stupid or unwise is quite different from being ethically improper.'' Patriarca told the committee that Glenn was ``blunt'' and ``seemed to have also made up his mind that our behavior was somehow wrong.'' He said McCain seemed ``uncomfortable being at the meeting.'' Riegle, he said, conducted ``a cross-examination to really probe the basis for the findings that we were saying we'd reached.''

DOC.HEAD: Pro Golfer Resigns From Club After Withdrawal of Jewish Man's Application
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Different spellings, Bloch and Block, are cq. A version slugged PM-GLF--Watson Resigns moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: PRo golfer Tom Watson severed ties with the country club where he learned to play after an application by the co-founder of H&R Block was reportedly thwarted because he is Jewish. Watson on Thursday said he resigned from the Kansas City Country Club because Henry Bloch, chairman of the nation's largest tax preparation service, had his application withdrawn. ``They put a prominent JEwish person up for membership and his application was withdrawn,'' Watson said. ``It's something I can't personally live with because my family is Jewish.'' Watson is not Jewish, but his wife, Linda, is. They have two children. The five-time winner of the British Open and two-time winner of the U.S. Open became a junior member of the club when he was 21 and has been a full member for six years. ``I would hope the club would significantly change so some good people of any religion, race and sex could be members,'' said Watson. ``That's the way I feel about it.'' Bloch, chairman and co-founder of H&R Block Inc., had been proposed as a member by Donald Hall, chairman of Hallmark Cards Inc. Hall withdrew Bloch's application when the membership committee failed to act on it. Bloch said today that he had no comment, and Hallmark spokesman Charles Hucker said Hall was out of the country and could not be reached. L. Chandler Smith, president of the 94-year-old club, said it had no blacks among its 400 foundation members. Asked if the club has any Jewish members, Smith said, ``To the best of my knowledge, no.'' He declined to explain the club's membership requirements. ``I don't think its proper that I go ahead into the detail of that process,'' he said. ``I just don't think it should be public information.'' But he said the club does not discriminate and Bloch's religion would not have been a factor. Watson said he still believes in the right of private clubs to determine their membership, ``but when they choose to discriminate against your beliefs, you don't have to choose to be a member there.'' Howard Levitan, president of Kehilath Israel Synagogue in KAnsas City, commended Watston's action. Watson mailed in his letter of resignation Wednesday, but had informed the club's president of his intentions to resign three weeks ago after BLoch's application was withdrawn.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Cancels Visit To Moldavia, First Domestic Trip In Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Moldavia saying reason for postponement was unrest, details. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Ethnic tensions...'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev postponed today's scheduled visit to the southern republic of MOldavia, his first domestic trip in three months, because of tensions in the republic, Tass reported. The Moldavian parliament issued a statement after the cancellation was announced, linking the postponement to ``actions by separatists,'' Tass said. The official news agency said a new date for a presidential visit to the strife-torn republic will be announced later. Gorbachev, who faces growing economic problems, food shortages, ethnic unrest and independence drives by most of the 15 Soviet republics, also announced this week he wanted to postpone a December trip to Oslo to pick up his Nobel Peace Prize. He cited his domestic woes. The Nobel committee said the award ceremonies would be held as scheduled Dec. 9-11, but that Gorbachev could deliver the prize winner's traditional speech in May. Tass said Gorbachev had been scheduled to speak to the Moldavian parliament today about the social and political situation in the Soviet Union. It said he was also to have met with intellectuals in the republic's capital, Kishinev. Interfax, an independent news agency, said Moldavian President Mircha Snegur told legislators separatist-minded deputies from the Dniester region in the east refused to attend the session, prompting Gorbachev to cancel. Ethnic tensions turned violent in Moldavia last month when troops clashed with activists in the Dniester region, leaving four dead. Gorbachev's last domestic trip was Aug. 17 when he traveled from his summer home in the Crimean peninsula to speak to soldiers in the Black Sea port of Odessa. In his speech he accused Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein of treachery and said the Soviet Union had a special responsibility to resolve the Gulf crisis because it had been Iraq's main weapons supplier. Since then, Gorbachev has made several trips to Western Europe, most recently to Paris for the COnference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Some Soviet politicians have accused him of not paying enough attention to domestic issues.

DOC.HEAD: Former Intelligence Official Talks Against Waging War With Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; cuts at end to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The United States should continue ``our present defensive position'' in Saudi Arabia rather than wage war with Iraq, a former top-ranking intelligence official told COngress today. Retired Lt. Gen. William E. Odom, who headed the National Security Agency during the Reagan administration, said he had ``no doubt that we could win'' an offensive action against Saddam Hussein's forces. But Odom said attacking Iraqi forces in Kuwait - or Iraq itself could mean an even longer U.S. military presence in the region than envisioned with the defensive posture now established. Odom's testimony came at the end of a week in which members of the Senate Armed Services Committee heard an array of witnesses, including two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, urge caution on the Bush administration as it seeks to end Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. ``Every single witness we've had here with differing views on other things, all of them have felt we've over-deployed,'' committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-GA., said at the conclusion of Thursday's testimony. The Bush administration could have led off the hearings, perhaps setting the tone. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were invited to be the initial witnesses. But they declined and the spotlight has been captured by a series of witnesses who underscored doubts among Democratic senators. CHeney and Powell are slated to testify next week. And Secretary of State James A. Baker III said this morning that he also would testify. Odom stressed in his testimony today that he supports Bush's buildup in the Persian Gulf, but said he was bewildered by the administration's apparent impatience with the results to date. ``I am puzzled by the administration's failure to take the credit for its success on this slow route to its objectives,'' said Odom, joining others in urging more time for economic sanctions to work. ``Some of the administration's rhetoric makes it sound as though we are losing. That is clearly not true,'' said ODom, now a National security expert at the Hudson Institute, a conservative think tank. ``The weight in favor of ... holding our present defensive position in Saudi Arabia seems to be quite large,'' he said. The hearings are proceeding amid published reports that the United States is sending another 300 war planes to the Persian Gulf, increasing the size of America's air fighting force in the region by a third. The Los Angeles Times, quoting unidentified Washington sources, reported in today's editions that the additional aircraft will include a second squadron of F-117 Stealth fighters and additional F-15E ground-attack jets, F-16 fighters, A-16 tank-killers, refueling tankers and RF-4C photo-reconnaissance jets. The Times said the reinforcements will come from 27 Air Force units with about 10,000 personnel. The newspaper said the extra units will be dispatched from Europe and U.S.-based Air National Guard and reserve squadrons. The deployment, which will begin as early as this week, will boost the number of U.S. AIr Force planes in the gulf to 1,200, the Times said. Bush's announcement earlier this month that he was sending 200,000 troops to the gulf region in addition to the 230,000 dispatched since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait drew fire from several Democrats. Among them was Nunn who had earlier supported the president's gulf policy. To blunt the attack, Republicans urged a special session of Congress, an issue on the agenda today for a meeting between Bush and congressional leaders. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., had lunch with Bush on Thursday. Foley said afterward, ``I hope the president doesn't call back the 101st Congress. ... Reports of that may be premature.'' The White House was noncommittal about increasing demands for a special session from lawmakers who had adjourned before the latest deployment. ``Let's wait and see,'' presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He agreed with a questioner who characterized the White House position as ``reluctant.'' Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said he hoped ``we give the president not a blank check but give the president a sense of support that we have confidence in him to make certain decisions.'' But Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said that ``airing all of our differences at this time in an official session of Congress would give heart to Saddam Hussein and doubts to our allies.''

DOC.HEAD: With Bush-Gulf^
