DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's statement and news conference today on the Persian Gulf crisis: I have a statement, an opening statement, that is a little longer than normal and I'd ask your indulgence, and then I will be glad to respond to questions. We're in the Gulf because the world must not and cannot reward aggression. And we're there because our vital interests are at stake. And we're in the Gulf because of the brutality of Saddam Hussein. We're dealing with a dangerous dictator all too willing to use force, who has weapons of mass destruction and is seeking new ones, and who desires to control one of the world's key resources -- all at a time in history when the rules of the post-Cold War world are being written. Our objectives remain what they were since the outset. We seek Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. We seek the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government. We seek the release of all hostages and the free functioning of all embassies. And we seek the stability and security of this critical region of the world. We are not alone in these goals and objectives. THe United Nations, invigorated with a new sense of purpose, is in full agreement. The United Nations Security Council has endorsed 12 resolutions to condemn Iraq's unprovoked invasion and occupation of Kuwait, implement tough economic sanctions to stop all trade in and out of Iraq, and authorize the use of force to compel Saddam to comply. Saddam Hussein has tried every way he knows how to make this a fight between Iraq and the United States and, clearly, he has failed. Forces of 26 other nations are standing shoulder-to-shoulder with our troops in the Gulf. The fact is that it is not the United States against Iraq, it is Iraq against the world, and there's never been a clearer demonstration of a world united against appeasement and aggression. Yesterday's United Nations Security Council resolution was historic. Once again, the Security Council has enhanced the legitimate peacekeeping function of the United Nations. Until yesterday, Saddam may not have understood what he's up against in terms of world opinion, and I am hopeful that now he will realize that he must leave Kuwait immediately. I'm continually asked how effective are the UN sanctions --those put into effect on August 6th -- and I don't know the answer to that question. Clearly, the sanctions are having some effect but I Can't tell you that the sanctions alone will get the job done. And thus I welcome yesterday's United Nations action. The fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe are being severely damaged by the economic effects of Saddam's actions. The developing countries of Africa and in our hemisphere are being victimized by this dictator's rape of his neighbor, Kuwait. Those who feel that there is no down side to waiting months and months must consider the devastating damage being done every day to the fragile economies of those countries that can afford it the least. And, as Chairman Alan Greenspan testified just the other day, the increase in oil prices resulting directly from Saddam's Invasion is hurting our country, too. And our economy, as I said the other day, is at best in a serious slowdown. And if uncertainty remains in the energy markets, the slowdown will ge worse. I've spelled out once again our reasons for sending troops to the Gulf. Let me tell you the things that concern me most. First, I put the immorality of the invasion of Kuwait itself. No nation should rape, pillage and brutalize its neighbor. No nation should be able to wipe a member state of the United Nations and the Arab League off the face of the earth. And I'm deeply concerned about all the hostages, innocent people held against their will in direct contravention of international law. And then there's this cynical and brutal policy, forcing people to beg for their release, parceling out human lives to families and traveling emissaries like so much chattel. I'm deeply concerned about our own embassy in Kuwait. The flag Is still flying there; a handful of beleaguered Americans remain inside the embassy, unable to come and go. This treatment of our embassy violates every civilized principle of diplomacy. And it demeans our people, it demeans our country. And I am determined that this embassy, as called for under Security Council Resolution 674, be fully replenished and our people free to come home.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Panic Despite Prediction of Earthquake
With PM-Quake Protection, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A scientist's forecasts of possible earthquakes as earlyas this weekend have gone largely unnoticed in this quake-prone capital, a striking contrast to the fear created in parts of the United States. New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning created a furor across the Midwest when he said last summer that there was a 50 percent chance of a strong quake on the NEw Madrid Fault within 48 hours on either side of Dec. 3. The fault runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark., about 35 miles east of Memphis. Browning's daughter, Evelyn Browning Garriss, has said that actually the scientist thinks a quake is more likely outside the United States - especially in Japan. Ms. Browning says he based his predictions on his observations of powerful high tides caused by the alignment of the Earth, moon and sun. He says such forces can trigger earthquakes. Tokyo, and there has been no outward sign of concern in Japan during the past week. The yen fell sharply against the dollar today, but dealers attributed the decline to market players seeking a safe investment after the U.N. Security Council adopted a resolution to permit the use of force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Kaneo Ogino, a dealer at Goldman Sachs (Japan), said of the earthquake rumors: ``People overseas are overreacting. I don't know Why stupid people are talking about an earthquake. We're ignoring this bloody nuisance.'' Window-rattling earthquakes are common in Japan, and the country Is obsessed with being properly prepared for the next great temblor. Buildings and infrastructure are all designed with earthquakes in mind. The most destructive shock in modern history was the ``Great Kanto Earthquake'' of Sept. 1, 1923, that destroyed a third of Tokyo and most of neighboring Yokohama, killing 140,000 people. Many perished in fires that raged through the largely wooden cities. The intensity of that quake is estimated at 7.9 on the Richter scale. The strongest recent Japan quake was on March 6, 1984, also registering 7.9 on the Richter scale. It caused only one death and neglibile damage because the epicenter was located deep below the pacific ocean seabed and well offshore.

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets the Blame for Flood Damage in Washington State
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 2nd death reported, add detail on damage estimate. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The consequences...'.
DOC.TEXT: Farmers, homeowners and others recovering from some of the worst flooding in state history learned that Washington's rivers can be channeled only so much before they overflow and reclaim developed land. The federal government Thursday set aside $100 million in disaster relief for roads and bridges damaged during last weekend's flooding, which forced thousands from their homes, killed hundreds of livestock and left two men dead, including a man whose body was not found until Thursday. In earlier days, the Snoqualmie, Skykomish, Snohomish, Stillaguamish, Skagit, NOoksack and Cedar rivers of northwestern Washington splintered into rivulets and channels on the plains below the Cascade Mountains during heavy rain. But farmers, and later manufacturers and homeowners, forced them and other rivers into fewer channels by erecting dikes and levees, said Robert J. Naiman, director of the Center for Streamside Studies at the University of Washington. ``That works until you get a major flow like last week, and then rivers just go where they've always gone,'' NAiman said Thursday. The Red Cross said Thursday the floods destroyed at least 161 homes, mobile homes and apartment units and damaged more than 2,400 others in 13 counties. Figures for three other counties weren't available. The consequences of the flooding were made worse because so many people had built homes in areas downstream that flood maybe once every 50 to 100 years, said Bob Beschta, a hydrology professor at Oregon State University. an area hasn't flooded (since) anybody can remember, it's probably OK,'' he said. Although some blamed forest clear-cutting in the mountains, Naiman and Beschta said the lack of trees was not a major factor. Trees reduce flooding by catching rain, some of which evaporates and some of which is taken in for growth. But Beschta said trees would not be much help at this time of year. ``It's dark, it's humid'' and the forest's capacity to hold water is small, he said. MAnmade surfaces such as logging roads and parking lots also contributed to the flooding. But the greatest damage occurred along the rivers' natural routes. Recognizing that, the U.S. government is considering buying up developed property near some annual flood zones and returning it to open space, said Chuck Steele, in charge of insurance claims for the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Supreme Court Strikes Down Chicago School Reform
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATEadd that councils have hiring-firing powers over principals, other detail; CORRECTS spelling of `principle' in 2nd graf. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `In his...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Illinois Supreme Coanner in which local school councils are elected violated the constitutional principle of ``one person, one vote'' by giving parents more power than other voters. One of the seven high court justices dissented. The ruling came in a lawsuit filed in Cook County Circuit Court in April 1989 by principals, subdistrict superintendents and others upset with the Chicago School Reform Act. THe landmark legislation was intended to decentralize the school system's top-heavy bureaucracy and give parents more control over their children's schools, including a majority on the councils that hire and fire principals. The state Supreme Court said, however, that it was unconstitutional to give more voting power to parents than to other citizens. The Chicago school system, the nation's third-largest, has 604 schools and more than 400,000 students. Joan Slay, acting director of Designs for Change, which helped shape the reform package, said she is certain that the act can be revised to meet the court's objections. ``We can resolve that, we will resolve it,'' said Ms. Slay. ``I don't consider it a blow. What I think it does mean is that we have to go back and craft this carefully.'' Principals, however, praised the ruling. School reform ``seemed to lay the blame for problems in Chicago schools on the shoulders of the principals,'' said Bruce Berndt, president of the Chicago Principals Association. ``Politicizing the principal's position is not going to make kids learn better.'' Under the law, the 11-member local school councils include six members who must be parents of enrolled students and are elected solely by fellow parents. The councils do not set tax rates but do have the power to hire and fire principals. The other members are two people who are not parents of enrolled students, who are elected by the public at large in the school's district, two teachers at the school, and the principal of the school. Last year, the selection of principals by local school councils was hotly contested at many of the city's schools. Some principals charged they were dismissed by their school's council solely on the basis of race. Skirmishes in which police were called broke out at at least two schools where students and parents were dissatisfied with the councils' actions. In his dissent, Justice William G. Clark said the act ``is a unique and creative response to the education problems facing Chicago.'' He said the different treatment of parents and other voters should be evaluated by the court to see if there is a ``rational basis'' for it, rather than just rejected out of hand under a strict reading of the one-person, one-vote rule. Attorneys for the Chicago Board of Education and other defendants in the case had argued that the ``one-person one-vote'' principle doesn't apply to subordinate panels of limited authority such as the local school councils. margin in the House and signed into law by Gov. James R. Thompson. Its passage followed a 19-day teachers' strike in 1987 and was intended to battle the high dropout rate and poor test scores that led then-federal education secretary William Bennett to call Chicago's schools the nation's worst. The high court's decision came on an appeal of Circuit Judge Robert Sklodowski's ruling of Aug. 29, 1989, upholding the law's constitutionality.

DOC.HEAD: American Hostage Relatives Hope Husbands Will Be Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 4-6, President Bush, to include Bush comments.
DOC.TEXT: Two American women say they are optimistic that Saddam Hussein will release their husbands after they arrive in Iraq next week on a trip the State Department has tried to discourage. ``I am so sure he is coming out,'' Kim Edwards, of Carson CIty, Nev., said of her husband, Tony. Mrs. Edwards, the mother of three small children, plans to travel on Monday to Jordan and then Baghdad, Iraq, with a group of more than a dozen other people. Members of the group have husbands or relatives who have been Held in Iraq or Kuwait since Saddam invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. President Bush criticized Saddam for his treatment of the hostages and their families at a news conference today. He condemned Iraq's ``cynical and brutal policy'' of ``forcing people to beg for their (the hostages') release, parceling out human lives to families and traveling emissaries like so much chattel.'' Bush also said he would dispatch Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad in an effort to resolve the PErsian Gulf crisis peacefully. But Bush insisted Saddam must withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait. Mrs. EDwards' husband was working as a planner for a Japanese company in BAghdad at the time of the invasion. She said she has talked with him several times. Barbara Smiley of Los Angeles said she believes the only way Saddam will free hostages is if the relatives ask for them in person. Saddam invited the families to come to Baghdad, saying people who arrive without guns will not leave empty-handed. Mrs. Smiley said she was frustrated by the situation until she decided to travel to Iraq. ``When I made the decision to travel, I was taking control,'' she said. Her husband, Edward, was working for a Kuwaiti company as a database administrator when the invasion occurred. She and the others opted to visit Iraq because they feel the State Department is not working hard enough to free the hostages. The State Department has repeatedly urged American families not to go to Iraq. U.S. officials say it is dangerous and they cannot guarantee security. Moreover, they say the families can expect to be used as ``propaganda pawns'' by Saddam. Nevertheless, at least four American families have traveled to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Woman To Beat Husband Before Granting Divorce
DOC.TEXT: A local court permitted a woman to publicly beat her husband before it granted him a divorce, United News of India reported Friday. The beating occurred Oct. 7 but went unreported until a social organization, apparently outraged by the incident, complained to the government. No further action has been taken. The man, from a town in the western Gujarat state, was seeking a divorce from his first wife to marry another woman, the news agency reported. She agreed, on condition that he first submit to a beating. Under Indian law, Hindus can have only one wife at a time. The law does not apply to Moslems, who are permitted up to four wives. Gujarat is the home state of Mohandas K. Gandhi, who led India's struggle for freedom against English rule and preached ``ahimsa,'' or non-violence.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Kills Man and Three Sons Jailed on Murder Charges
DOC.TEXT: A mob stormed a jail and burned to death a man and his three sons who had been arrested on charges of killing a shopkeeper, police said Friday. About 1,500 people surrounded the jail in La Mana, a village 71 miles southeast of Quito, forcing the guards to flee, police said. The crowd then spread gasoline and set fire to the jail. ``In a few minutes the whole building was ablaze. The four arrested men cried asking help but their cries were ignored by the perpetrators of such terrible crimes,'' the newspaper El Comercio of Quito said Friday. The men inside the jail, Juan Flores and his sons Freddy, German and Nelson, had been arrested the day before under suspicion of robbing and stabbing to death a shopkeeper. According to police, agents searching the Flores' house found many items that had been stolen from the man's shop.

DOC.HEAD: Major Sworn In as Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister John Major was sworn into office Friday by Queen ELizabeth II at a Privy COuncil meeting at Buckingham Palace. During the ceremony, which has taken place since the Middle Ages, Major and the five new members of his 22-Cabinet in charge of government departments kissed the monarch's hand and were made lifetime members of the Privy Council, a body of just under 400 royal councilors. A Privy Councilor, man or woman, is entitled to be called Right Honorable and remains a member for life. The council is now very much a ceremonial body, superseded by the Cabinet, but it was once the monarch's executive, a group of about a dozen people who carried out the monarch's orders. informally, instead of formally with the monarch, and that was the origin of Cabinet government, said Geoffrey de Deney, clerk of the Privy Council. ``But the Privy Council remains as the formal and dignified part of the Constitution - distinguishing between the elective part and the dignified part,'' he said. Major succeeds Margaret Thatcher, who stepped down after failing to defeat a challenge for the leadership of the Conservative Party.

DOC.HEAD: Hunter Fined 180 dollars for Accidentally Killing Man
DOC.TEXT: A court has fined a hunter $180 for killing another hunter he thought was an elk, the Swedish national news agency TT reported Friday. ``I saw something in the woods. I thought it was an elk and Shot,'' the 70-year-old elk hunter told the court. The victim was a Bird hunter. The elk hunter was convicted of causing another person's death. The shooting occurred in a central Sweden forest in September. The court accepted the hunter's testimony that the shooting was accidental. Swedish courts generally impose light sentences in such cases.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Cancels Construction Of Two Submarines
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Friday canceled the construction of two submarines on order at a German shipyard, saying Israel didn't have the money to pay for them. THe two Dolphin-class submarines would have been built for $570 million at the HDW shipyard in Kiel. Construction was to have started in a few months. Israel needs the money for other projects, Arens said. ``The defense budget has been eroded in the past few years, and this at a time when our needs are growing, especially because of the gulf crisis,'' he said. In the 1991 state budget approved by the government this week, $6.2 billion was set aside for defense. In the past, the defense budget was always the largest item in government spending, but this year it is second to the $6.5 million earmarked for the immigration wave from the Soviet Union. Israel has three Vickers 206 submarines, but they soon will be outdated, said Zeev Eitan, a researcher at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University. Eitan said several Arab countries, including Syria, EGypt, Libya And Algeria, owned submarines.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchange Fires Forces Closure
DOC.TEXT: A fire early Friday at the Brussels stock exchange forced officials to cancel trading and close the building until Monday. There were no injuries in the fire, which broke out in a second floor high-power room and reached the roof. Firemen rapidly brought it under control. The exchange's main trading computer did not seem damaged, but a thick smoke left a layer of soot on most of the building's interior, including brokers' desks, screens and telephones. Stock Exchange Prsident Jean Peterbroeck said repair and cleaning would be carried out through the weekend and trading would resume Monday. It was the second time this year that a fire closed the exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Bring Fruit, Vegetables to U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, Bush Says
With PM-Bush-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Americans who have been living off canned tuna and rice at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait have received fruit, vegetables and a case of cigarettes from the Iraqis, President Bush said today. A group of Iraqis who showed up with the goods Thursday said they would return with a second delivery, including soft drinks, on Saturday, Bush said during televised remarks on the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush said the Iraqis told the Americans to make a list of medical supplies they needed, too. He called the Iraqis' move an ``interesting development'' but noted that electricity was still cut off at the AMerican Embassy compound in Iraq-occupied Kuwait, where eight U.S. diplomats and 19 private citizens are holding out. ``This could be a positive sign, but it's so far short of compliance with international law that I can't be rejoicing,'' Bush said. Bush, who said he had received the report of the delivery this morning, said he had been asked what would happen if the Iraqis provoked him regarding the Americans still holding out at the U.S. outpost. ``Consider me provoked when Iand medical equipment,'' Bush said. In the past, Bush has said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was trying to ``starve them out.'' The grounds at the seaside compound are surrounded by Iraqi troops, and no one is permitted to enter or leave. The four men and women picked by the State Department to stay behind have kept the embassy operating despite the lack of electricity and water. In the three weeks between the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the Aug. 24 IRaqi deadline for shutting down all diplomatic facilities in the capital, Americans stocked up on non-perishable food and bottled water. The Americans have been surviving on canned tuna, supplemented by rice and fresh dates that grow on the compound. Their main assignment is to keep in contact with the 600 or so Americans who are still in hiding in Kuwait to avoid being rounded up and added to the ranks of the ``human shield'' Saddam has assembled to protect strategic installations from attack.

DOC.HEAD: Exhibit Implies World War II Torture of COmmunists Linked to Americans
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Beijing schoolchildren are being taken to a museum exhibit that depicts U.S. soldiers watching as Nationalist Chinese police torture Communist prisoners in the 1940s. evidence AMericans had anything to do with mistreatment of prisoners by the NAtionalist CHinese, who were U.S. Allies in World War II. But that is never made clear in the popular ``Exhibit of Historical Facts About the Concentration Camp at the Place of CHinese-U.S. Cooperation,'' which actually tells the story of two prisons in China's wartime capital of Chungking. From the exhibit name to the photographs and statues depicting Americans training Nationalist Chinese police, the implication is that Americans were responsible for the torture and deaths of hundreds of CHinese COmmunists at the hands of Nationalists during the 1930s and 1940s. ``The Nationalists were manipulated by the Americans,'' said Yuan Shigui of the Capital Museum, where the exhibit is being shown for nearly six weeks. Chungking in southwest China has a permanent memorial to the prisons' inmates. The exhibit seems out of step with the current warming trend in U.S.-Chinese relations. The friction triggered by China's June 1989 army attack on pro-democracy demonstrators has eased, and most U.S. sanctions against China have crumbled. Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen was in Washington on FRiday for the first official high-level Chinese visit since Beijing's crackdown. Still, the official Chinese media continues to level frequent criticism at the U.S. political and social system and the U.S. government-run radio station, Voice of America. The Communist Party newspaper, the People's Daily, frequently carries editorials warning against ``hostile forces in the West'' who seek to convert socialist countries to capitalism. Other recent articles have derided U.S. democracy as an illusion perpetrated by the rich upon the working class. With the party urging better ideological training of the young, the exhibit is being used as an educational tool - not just for its criticism of U.S. ties to the Nationalists but for its praise of Communist ``martyrs.'' It includes dozen of photographs of party members tortured or killed by the Nationalists. It says the Nationalists killed 180 prisoners in one night in 1949 as Communist troops prepared to capture Chungking in the final stages of a civil war won by the Communists. ``This is a very important exhibit,'' Yuan said. ``We held it in keeping with the needs of current education in patriotism and internationalism, in order to carry out the excellent tradition'' of the slain Communists. About 33,000 people, mostly schoolchildren and workers on organized trips, visited the exhibit in its opening week. It has been shown in 18 Chinese cities in the past two years. The exhibIt says that U.S. NAval intelligence officers and Nationalist secret police set up a Chinese-U.S. SPecial Technology Cooperation Institute in 1943 to share war intelligence and train Nationalist police. The U.S. participants moved into a building that had been used as a prison since 1939, the exhibit said. With their arrival, the prison was moved to a nearby site. When the Americans left in 1947, the building they had occupied again became a prison. These two prisons are the ``concentration camp'' of the exhibit title. U.S. Embassy spokesman Sheridan W. Bell confirmed there was such a U.S.-Chinese technology group, but said he had no details of its activities. The United States gave substantial loans and arms to the Nationalists during the 1940s, seeking to bolster them in the fight against Japan. The exhibit said the U.S. officers in Chungking also ``acted as accessories to the Nationalists in smashing the (Communist) revolutionary movement.'' Yuan accused them of supporting the establishment of the prisons. However, Li Hua, director of the Chungking memorial, said in a telephone interview that there is no evidence of direct American involvement. He said Americanssaid the exhibit's statues of U.S. officers supervising torture sessions ``do not show something that actually happened in the prison.'' He did not respond when asked the purpose of the statues. Li said the exhibit was not intended to arouse anti-American sentiment or influence current U.S.-Chinese relations. ``The events of history need not affect today,'' he said.

A. Because Baker goes to Baghdad? Q. Aren't you concerned that that would be the position of Saddam Hussein? A. No, I'm not. I'm concerned some might say this is an ultimatum in which it is - all it is is an effort to be sure that he understands the commitment of the United States, that he understands that anything that is done must be done inside the confines of the United Nations resolutions that have been passed, that there will be no contingency. There can be no face saving. That's not what this is about. This is to be sure that he understands how strongly the President of the United States feels about implementing to a tee, without - without concession - the United Nations position. And some have told me that he's not getting the message of how determined we are. And I can't think of any better way to do it at this juncture, in the wake of the UN resolution, than this face-to-face - face-to-face meeting. I'm not sure he'll agree to it. Yes, Ann? Q. Today's press conference seems to amount to, again, more talk of preparation for war. Can you describe what you think your responsibilities are, in terms of Congress, as we head into thi period, since they seem to think that and agree that you're consulting - talking, but not - you seem reluctant to go and get a resolution that mimicks the UN resolution. What do you think your responsibilities are to Congress and to the people that elected them? A. Full consultation. Q. ANy more than telling - A. Get them in on the - huh? Q. Any more than telling them before you do - you do something? A. I'm leveling with them on where I think - think matters are right now, and I - I'm - you've put your interpretation on my remarks. There was plenty of comments in there about hoping that we will have a peaceful resolution; that the best answer to get a peaceful resolution is to have Saddam Hussein know how determined everybody is. You see, I think yesterday's UN resolution was a step towards peace, not a step towards war, because IHussein finally gets the message and understands what he's up against in terms of world opinion and other things, that - that he will do that in Kuwait which he did in - in Iran. Yes?

DOC.HEAD: Drug Dog Killed on Highway
DOC.TEXT: Canine Major, a Florida Highway Patrol German shepherd who sniffed out $100,000 worth of drugs during his career, was killed when he was struck by a car on Interstate 95. ``IT's certainly a sad day for us. Naturally, we feel like we lost a trooper,'' said Lt. Randy Brown of the Florida Highway Patrol. Troopers Mike King and Mike Smith stopped a rented truck on the highway for following a car too closely Thursday afternoon in St. Johns County, Brown said. The truck driver appeared nervous, so troopers asked for permission to search the truck. The troopers found a bag of marijuana and Smith, who worked with and cared for the dog, brought Major in for a more extensive search, Brown said. The 1{-year-old dog had trouble getting into the truck, darted onto the highway and was struck by a car.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Grant Stay for Alleged Serial Killer Lucas
DOC.TEXT: Alleged serial killer Henry LEe Lucas, scheduled to die Monday for a 1979 slaying, won a stay from the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. Lucas was granted a reprieve Thursday, a day after the same court rejected a stay for the one-eyed drifter on other grounds. Lucas, 54, had once claimed to have killed nearly 600 people in 26 states, touching off a flurry of headlines and visits from investigators from across the natiojn. But he later recanted his Confessions to all the slayings except one - that of his mother. The appeals court said Thursday it would consider a claim by Lucas' attorneys that the trial jury should have been able to consider mitigating circumstances before sentencing him to death, said assistant Texas Attorney General Bob Walt. On Wednesday, the court had rejected a claim that the trial COurt did not have the authority to set Lucas' execution date. He said Wednesday that he might have confessed to as many as 4,000 crimes because of threats against him or promises made to him. Lucas was scheduled to die before dawn Monday for the slaying of a woman known only as ``Orange Socks,'' which is all she was wearing when her body was found Oct. 31, 1979, next to a culvert near Interstate 35 north of Georgetown. Lucas contends he was in Florida at the time of the Orange SOcks slaying and was forced by police to confess. The Orange Socks conviction is Lucas' only death sentence although he has at least six other life terms, two 75-year sentences and a 60-year term for other Texas convictions. He also is wanted in FLorida on three first-degree murder charges for slayings in 1980 and 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Make Food DEliveries to U.S. Diplomats in Kuwait
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The handful of U.S. diplomats holding out in the U.S. Embassy in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait are receiving food deliveries from Iraqis and have been promised medical supplies, President Bush said Friday. BUsh described the report as ``very interesting'' and said it could be a positive sign. The president discussed the development at a news conference in which he invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to Washington and said he would send Secretary of State James A Baker III to Baghdad in an effort to end the crisis peacefully and still get Iraq out of Kuwait. ``There is a very interesting report that we got in this morning saying that some Iraqis showed up at ... our embassy in Kuwait and had delivered fruit, vegetables, and a case of Iraqi cigarettes,'' Bush said. The eight U.S. diplomats and 19 private citizens holed up at the seaside compound have been surviving on canned tuna, rice and fresh dates that grow there. Bush said the embassy was to provide a list of needed medical supplies, and another delivery was expected on Saturday to include soft drinks. Earlier in the news conference Bush cited the treatment of the embassy as one reason for a tough stance against Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. ``The flag is still flying there. A handful of beleaguered Americans remain inside the embassy, unable to come and go. This treatment of our embassy violates every civilized principle of diplomacy,'' the president said, adding that he was determined to replenish the embassy. ``What kind of precedent will these actions set for the future if Saddam's violation of international law goes unchallenged?'' Bush asked. In response to a later question, he described the delivery. ``So this is kind of an interesting little development,'' he said. `` ... Let's try to be optimistic and say this is ... this could be a positive sign. But it's so far short of compliance with International law that I can't be rejoicing. But it is a very interesting development.''

DOC.HEAD: CB Minister Preaches From Truck Stop
DOC.TEXT: Broadcasting from his citizen's band radio pulpit, a barber-turned-preacher dispenses guidance for the soul and directions for the road to his congregation of truckers. They call the Rev. S. Anthony BAttaglia The Chaplain Man. BAttaglia, 60, found a new calling when the Baltimore Port Truck Plaza wanted to hire a citizen's band radio buff to guide tired, hungry and lost drivers on the busy Interstate 95 corridor. ``He's a right responsible fellow. He's kind of a caretaker around here. He helpsgguys who get into a bind,'' said Steve NEwton, a former driver who is now a trucking agent in Baltimore. Sandwiched between a gift shop - complete with mud flap ornaments including the popular chrome reclining nude - and a coin-operated laundry, Battaglia mans his radio pulpit in the security office of the truck stop's motel. Every weekday from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., Battaglia sits with his imitation leather Bible at a desk piled with a 40-channel CB radio, police scanners, atlases and phone books. Battaglia, an ordained Baptist minister, is a chaplain at a suburban Baltimore church and a volunteer chaplain for the Baltimore County police and fire departments. HE wears his fire department uniform to the truck stop in case he gets a call. He spent 30 years as a barber, then switched directions and worked as a real estate agent. Now, his congregation includes drivers with handles such as ``The Rubber Duck,'' ``Low Rider,'' and ``The DEstroyer.'' ``How 'bout that Chaplain Man?,'' one driver calls out. ``We got an abandoned trailer. IT's an Evergreen.'' Another driver leaving the Fort McHenry Tunnel wants directions to EAstern Avenue. ``That driver coming out of the hole, that exit is 5-9,'' Battaglia replies. ``This is the Baltimore Port Truck Plaza welcoming you to Baltimore.'' That greeting is about as much as he is allowed to say on the air waves about the truck stop, because Federal Communications Commission regulations forbid advertisements over the radio. ``Basically we're here to help the drivers. When they come into Baltimore its one big maze of streets,'' Battaglia said. ``Truckers are lonely, too. They have marital problems. They can feel free to come in for counsel,'' he said. ``I tell them, `SOmetimes you just have to make a decision to go out on your own with your own truck.' Or if things are slow, they Need someone to encourage them, to tell them to just hang on.''

DOC.HEAD: UN Gives Iraq Ultimatum; Bush Offers to Send Baker to Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with diplomats saying Iraqi leadership went immediately into meeting after Bush speech. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `Speaking in...'
With LaserPhotos NY9, NY15, NY16
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today rejected the use-of-force resolution approved by the Security Council, but an IRaqi ambassador welcomed President Bush's offer to send his secretary of state to Baghdad for talks. In a nationally televised news conference today, Bush said he is willing to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad on a diplomatic mission to negotiate Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Bush said, however, that if military conflict does break out, ``It will not be another Vietnam, this will not be another protracted, drawn-out war.'' In Baghdad, the Iraqi leadership was taken by surprise by BUsh's announcement about BAker and went immediately into a meeting to discuss the development, diplomats said. It was not known who attended the meeting. However, Iraq's ambassador to France, Abdul Razzack al Hashimi, spke positively of the proposed Baker visit. ``This is a very important step, really, toward peace, and we hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for, negotiations instead of beating the drums of war. ... I consider it very good news,'' he said. Speaking in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp., the Iraqi ambassador said: ``The point is not Kuwait. The problem is much much bigger than that. The whole security of the world is in jeopardy in the region today. ... So let's talk about it in that sense. That's what is important.'' ``We are not accepting pre-condition negoatiations,'' he told the BBC in Paris. ``Let's wait and see, and let's be optimistic, and see what Mr. Baker has in mind, and not to speculate about such an important event.'' BusH's news conference came one day after the U.N. Security Council voted 12 to 2 Thursday to authorize the United States and its allies to use force to drive Iraq from Kuwait if Saddam Hussein has not withdrawn his troops by Jan. 15. China abstained; Yemen and Cuba voted against. It was only the second time in the 45-year history of the United Nations that the council authorized the use of force to counter aggression. The first time was in 1950 during the Korean conflict. Saddam's ruling Revolutionary Command Council today called the U.N. measure ``illegal, null and void,'' saying it was imposed by the United States. ``It is first and foremost an American decision in which certain powers participated only under American pressure,'' it said. ``The United States practiced all forms of pressure, terrorism and bribes'' to pass the resolution. The statement, broadcast on state-run Baghdad Radio, said Iraq would teach the United States and its allies a ``hard lesson, unprecedented in history.'' IN Tokyo today, MIsoji Sakamoto, the top government spokesman, voiced support for the resolution, and in Madrid, government spokeswoman, Rosa Conde, said Spain also backed the measure. The German government said today that peace in the Mideast was ``in Iraq's hands.'' Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, would be welcome in Washington for talks the week of Dec. 10. Bush said Baker would travel to Baghdad between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15. Bush said, however, that he would not waiver in demanding a total Iraqi withdrawal, restoration of the Kuwaiti government and release of all hostages. Th president combined his surprise diplomatic overture with words of warning for Saddam. He said that if hostilities occur, ``I promise you there will not be any murky ending. I will never agree to a halfway effort.'' ``I don't think there has ever been a question that the United States is going to blink'' in this situation, Bush said. Oil prices tumbled this morning after Bush held out the possibility of a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis. Oil dropped $2.11 per barrel to $30.80 on the NEw York Mercantile Exchange. Thirteen foreign ministers attended Thursday's extraordinary Security Council session, with Baker presiding, making it one of the highest-level meetings in council history. The resolution, however, did not address whether the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf could take action in the event of an Iraqi provocation prior to Jan. 15, such as harming the Western hostages it is holding. It also made no mention of a U.N. military command or any U.N. role in overseeing any military operation. The Soviet Union has said Soviet forces only would be committed to a military operation under U.N. auspices. But in New York Thursday, Soviet Foreign MInister Eduard Shevardnadze said the only thing that could force Moscow to intervene in the conflict would be ``a threat to the lives and security of Soviet citizens in Iraq.'' ``We will take all the necessary steps in this case. Everybody should know that we will not hesitate to use force to protect our citizens,'' Shevardnadze told the Soviet news agency Tass in an interview from New York. The council resolution strengthens Bush's hand with Congress and the American people in calling for offensive action against Baghdad. But hearings on the gulf crisis continued on Capitol Hill today with a former top-ranking intelligence official saying the United States should maintain a defensive posture in Saudi Arabia rather than wage war with Iraq. Retired Lt. Gen. William E. Odom, who headed the National Security Agency during the Reagan administration, said attacking Iraqi forces in Kuwait - or Iraq itself - could mean a long U.S. military presence in the region. On Thursday, former Navy Secretary James Webb added his voice to those questioning Bush's plan to send 200,000 more troops to Saudi Arabia to back up the 240,000 already there. The LOs Angeles Times said today the additional aircraft will include a second squadron of F-117 Stealth fighters and additional F-15E ground-attack jets, F-16 fighters, A-16 tank-killers, refueling tankers and RF-4C photo-reconnaissance jets. The deployment, which will begin as early as this week, will boost the number of U.S. AIr Force planes in the gulf to 1,200, the Times said.

So we want to make the case to him, direcTly, for complying with the United Nations resolutions; make the case to him, from a Secretary of State who's incessantly worked to get this resolution through, of the strength of the commitment of the international community. ANd then try to persuade him that - to reconsider his position and to take the steps necessary for a peaceful resolution of the crisis. But it isn't, you know, a trip of concession. When you've done what he's done, I don't - I don't see that there's - there's room for concession, there's room for giving something to save face. They can criticize me for moving force, and if we've got one kid that's apt to be in harm's way, I want him backed up to the hilt by American firepower and others as well. And that's why I'm working as hard as I am, not only to hold this coalition together, but to strengthen it. And the best way to safeguard the lives of Americans is for Saddam Hussein to do that which he should have done long ago. And if force has to be used, the best way to safeguard lives is to see that you've got the best And you're willing to use it. And that's my posture. Now, let's see, Sarah. Fire away. Q. Sir, why do you seem to be avoiding the people's representatives having an opportunity to talk on this and to express their opinion? You know Congress, and yet you're avoiding it. And you know that the Constitution gives them power not only to declare war, to provide the money and to say other things about what shall be done with troops. That's the Constitution. Yet you seem to be avoiding that. The experts on Capitol Hill say that what you have done by pre-notification, calling two or three members and saying to them, ``We're on the way,'' you've already made the decision, you're just notifying them, that's pre-notification; that's not consulting with Congress. They say you should sit down and have a back-and-forth with them - A. Yes, but - Q. - and I will remind you that when Foley speaks as Speaker of the HOuse, he may be Speaker of the House, but he sure as hell doesn't represent Florida or Texas. A.
