THey have the power under the resolution of adjournment to come back 20 seconds from now, and to take a voice, to stand, to take a common position. If they want to come back here and endorse what the President of the United States has done and what the United Nations Security Council has done - come on, we're ready. I'd like to see it happen. But what I don't want to do is have it come back and end up where you have 435 voices in one House and 100 on the other saying what not to do, and saying - kind of a hand-wringing operation that would send bad signals. I welcome these hearings. We are having hearings. We are consulting. I've told you I'm consulting. Ill be honest with you. I cannot consult with 535 strong-willed individuals. I can't do it, nor does my responsibility under the Constitution compel me to do that. And I think everyone would agree that we have had more Consultations than - than previous administrations. Q. Sir, we have a majority rule in this country, and you seem to be afraid of it. of government, and I know my - I know my strengths and I know the limitations on the presidency. This is an interesting debate, Sarah. (Laughter) And - (chuckles) - and I - and I know my limitations. And I know what I can do, and I know what previous presidents have done. And I am still determined to consult the extra mile. Do you want to continue to debate? You've - Q. Well, sir, you seem to give - you and Jim Baker give the other countries a chance to talk, and you give the United Nations a chance to talk, but you won't give tHe United STates people a chance to debate with you. Q. Is there a question in there somewhere? A. Well, now, that's an absurd comment, Sarah, from a bright person like you. That is absolutely absurd. They're holding hearings. They're talking. They have the power under the adjournment resolution to reconvene this minute. Some in the House want to come back now. Some want to talk about it later on. Some in the Senate want to come right back now and immediately endorse what the President has done and what the Security Council resolution is, and I'm for that. But some don't. And so consultation is going on. Please do not assign to me improper motives. We're -- they're talking right now. They're having endless hearings by endless experts up there, each one with a slightly different view. And that's the American way. And that's fine. And I know what the responsibilities of the president are, and I am fulfilling those responsibilities. Q. Thank you. Q. Thank you. Q. What about China? What happened with China? Q. Thank you.

DOC.HEAD: Transcripts Detail Cash, Drinks, Golf BAgs for Legislators
DOC.TEXT: Lobbyists dubbed ``angels'' secretly provided cash, meals, and other gifts to legislators during a free-wheeling political era led by a senator who is now a state Supreme Court justice, documents allege. prohibits lobbyists from providing, and lawmakers from accepting, any gifts, including even a cup of coffee. Documents released Thursday detailed allegations by Lobbyist Gary R. Goyke and others that Justice William A. BAblitch was the ``inventor'' of a practice in the 1970s and 1980s that coerced lobbyists to pay for lawmakers' food and liquor. Lobbyists would often be called at home and asked to be ``angels,'' meaning they were expected to pay for lawmakers' food, drinks or lodging, Goyke told investigators. After Bablitch began the practice, lawmakers sought such gifts as free meals and drinks, $100 golf bags, sporting event tickets, lodging, art pieces and even financial assistance for a movie deal, the documents said. Bablitch, a Democrat who served as majority leader of the Wisconsin Senate from 1977 to 1981 before being elected to the state's highes court, denied the allegations. majority leader) there was not a hint of scandal.'' released Thursday by the state Justice DEpartment with the completion of a two-year investigation into influence peddling at the Capitol. THe probe resulted in more than $35,000 in fines against two dozen lawmakers and lobbyists. Only one person, a state senator, was sent to jail. Prosecutors have said some of the lobbyists and lawmakers implicated in the documents were not charged because the wrongdoing occurred too long ago to be prosecuted. Goyke, who served in the SEnate before becoming a lobbyist, was among those fined for providing illegal gifts to lawmakers. He said he first became familiar with Bablitch's practices as a freshman senator in 1974, when he and another lawmaker had dinner with Bablitch and were told the bill would be covered by a coffee fund. Goyke said he later learned the fund was bankrolled by lobbyists. Goyke said after becoming a lobbyist he was frequently asked to be an ``angel'' and would agree to allow lawmakers to use his credit cards for bills. weened his successor as Senate majority leader, Timothy Cullen, to perpetuate the practice, Goyke said. Cullen, who later became secretary of the Department of Health and Social Services, now works for an insurance company. A secretary in his office in Evansville said he was unavailable for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Nun Wins $13,000 Sports Car in School Raffle
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic nun won a $13,000, fire-engine-red sports car in a raffle to benefit her school. Sister Rebecca Berghoff, 65, said Thursday she was aghast when she was declared the winner in the raffle for the St. Joseph-Marquette School, where she is principal. She said she bought 30 $1 tickets for Saturday's drawing. About 32,000 tickets were sold for the school, which has 300 pupils in kindergarten through eighth grade. She returned the Geo Storm to the dealer and said the refund will help ease the school's budget problems. Besides, she said it wasn't appropriate ``for a nun to be streaking around in a car like that.'' Sister Berghoff has been a lucky gambler before. She said she travels to Reno, Nev., to play slot machines every year and has won as much as $500. ``I do enjoy it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Developments At A Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis: --- President Bush on Friday said that he is dispatching Secretary of State James Baker III to Baghdad to discuss an ending to the Gulf crisis, and that the Iraqi foreign minister would be welcome in Washington for consultations the week of Dec. 10. He said Baker would be available to travel to Iraq between Dec. 15 and the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. --- Saddam's ruling Revolutionary Command Council on Friday called the U.N. measure authorizing the United States and its allies to use force to drive Iraq from Kuwait ``illegal, null and void,'' saying it was imposed by the United States. ``It is first and foremost an American decision in which certain powers participated only under American pressure,'' it said. ``The United States practiced all forms of pressure, terrorism and bribes'' to pass the resolution. --- Abdul Razzack al Hashimi, Iraq's ambassador to France, speaking in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. said of the proposed Baker visit: ``This is a very important step, really, toward peace, and we hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for, negotiations instead of beating the drums of war. ... I consider it very good news.'' --- In Tokyo on Friday, Misoji Sakamoto, the top government spokesman, voiced support for the resolution, and in Madrid, government spokeswoman, Rosa Conde, said Spain also backed the measure. The German government said on Friday that peace in the Mideast was ``in Iraq's hands.'' --- The handful of U.S. diplomats holding out in the U.S. Embassy in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait are receiving food deliveries from Iraqis and have been promised medical supplies, President Bush said on Friday. ``There is a very interesting report that we got in this morning saying that some Iraqis showed up at ... our embassy in Kuwait and had delivered fruit, vegetables, and a case of Iraqi cigarettes,'' Bush said. The eight U.S. diplomats and 19 priate citizens holed up at the seaside compound have been surviving on canned tuna, rice and fresh dates that grow there. --- Oil prices tumbled Friday morning after President Bush held out the possibility of a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Light sweet crude oil, which had been down about 80 cents a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange before Bush began his news conference, fell sharply while the president was still on television. Crude dropped to $30.80 per barrel, down $2.11, on contracts for delivery in January. --- Retired Lt. Gen. William E. Odom, who headed the National Security Agency during the Reagan administration, told Congress on Friday he had ``no doubt that we could win'' an offensive action against Saddam Hussein's forces. But Odom said attacking Iraqi forces in Kuwait - or Iraq itself - could mean an even longer U.S. military presence in the region than envisioned with the defensive posture now established.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Reprimands Seattle Radio Station In Listener Contest
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission reprimanded a Seattle radio station Friday for failing to tell listeners they could be disqualified from a $10,000 contest for flooding the station with duplicate entries. At issue was a complaint by Patricia McBride-Nelson, a Seattle real estate broker and mortgage loan officer who had sent in more than 800 entries in a bid to win a contest in which listeners named four songs played in a row without interruption. McBride-Nelson, who was disqualified before last spring's drawing, said she bought an electric typewriter to speed up her entries and listened to KSEA-FM ``continuously, sometimes until 2:30 a.m.'' ``I carried my radio everywhere with me. I called in several times a day to the deejays to confirm song titles that I wasn't sure about,'' she said. ``I intended to do nothing else until the day of the drawing. I intended to flood the barrel to give me the highest possible odds of winning ... I was made to feel like a fool for even participating in such an intense degree.'' The FCC said the station repeatedly violated federal regulations when it failed to ``fully and accurately disclose'' rules prohibiting listeners from mailing in duplicate postcards that listed the same set of songs. The commission decided a formal admonition was sufficient, partly because KSEA offered to compensate the woman for postage and stationary expenses she incurred entering the contest more than 800 times. Bruce Reese, a lawyer for the radio station's parent company, said the FCC's ruling was appropriate. ``Short of throwing out the complaint, we view this as the lowest rung on the ladder in disciplinary action the commission could give us,'' Reese said. KSEA hoped the complaint would be dismissed because the station took ``corrective steps'' and began broadcasting the rules more fully a week after the contest began March 30, Reese said. McBride-Nelson, who has an unlisted telephone number, could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Genetically Engineered Rats Help Doctors Understand a Human Arthritis
DOC.TEXT: Researchers studying spinal arthritis and related diseases report they have bred genetically engineered rats that mimic the maladies in an important step toward developing treatments. ``This is a significant piece of science,'' said Dr. Maxwell Cowan, vice president and chief scientific officer of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute at Bethesda, Md. ``The only reason that the diseases could be understood is by developing an animal model.'' The institute and the Harold C. Simmons Arthritis Research Center funded the work by scientists at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas. The findings were reported Friday in the journal Cell. The rats were bred with human genes for a protein molecule called HLA-B27. It has been known since 1973 as a marker for a group of arthritic diseases called spondyloarthropathies, said Dr. Lawrence Shuman, director of the National Institute of Arthritis, Musculoskeletal and Skin Disorders. When the rats given the genes got the symptoms, researchers said they had confirmation HLA-B27 was a cause, not just a marker, of the diseases, which affect about 200,000 mostly younger Americans. No new treatments for people have been developed from the research, but the future is bright, said Dr. Joel D. Taurog, who developed the genetic link with Dr. Robert Hammer, senior associate at the Hughes institute. ``You can look for gold, but you can't plan to always find it,'' Taurog said. ``We can only hope that the lines of research that lead from this development help prevent the diseases in the future.'' Among those optimistic about the research is the U.S. secretary of health and human services. ``This convincing animal model will help reveal the mechanisms that cause these arthritic disorders, which affect hundreds of thousands of our young people,'' Dr. Louis W. Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Considers Waiving Trade Restrictions On Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he would consider waiving U.S. trade restrictions and provide the Soviet Union with export credits to help reduce food shortages this winter. Bush, speaking at a news conference on the Persian Gulf crisis, was asked whether recent Soviet support for his gulf policies had made him more likely to offer food assistance to the Soviets. The president sad the two matters were ``totally separate and unrelated.'' But he expressed a ``willingness to entertain proposals for food, especially if the reports prove to be accurate in terms of the severe winter and the hardship that this will inflict on the Soviet people.'' Bush said he has asked top aides for recommendations by next week on how to deal with a 1974 law that denies the Soviets coveted most-favored-nation trade status because of their restrictions on emigration. The president said he was undecided on whether to waive the so-called Jackson-Vanik amendment and then offer the Soviets export credits through the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corp. ``It's an evolving ... question here. I don't know exactly what I am going to do,'' he said. The Jackson-Vanik law barred all export credits or credit guarantees to Soviet bloc countries that restricted emigration. It also imposed tariffs on their exports to the United States. ``It has been my position that the Soviets should pass the necessary emigration legislation,'' Bush said. ``That has not taken place. But some are saying that I now have a clearer waiver authority than I thought.'' A credit package for Moscow would not be unprecedented. Former President Nixon in 1972 unveiled a $750 million credit deal so the Soviets could buy U.S. grain over three years. Moscow used about $550 million of the credit line before the Jackson-Vanik requirement halted further credit. On Friday, Bush said he felt that the U.S. trade restrictions had been influential in increasing the emigration of Soviet Jews. ``We've been steadfast in encouraging the exodus of Soviet Jews, so that will weigh on my consideration when I get down to have to make this final decision on whether to waive Jackson-Vanik,'' the president said. Bush said there were other, unspecified agricultural programs to help the Soviets that could go forward which are unaffected by the trade restrictions. The United States already sells the Soviets large amounts of wheat under a 1985 ``export enhancement program'' that subsidizes sales of some U.S. commodities to certain foreign buyers. Under the so-called EEP arrangement, as of Nov. 15 Moscow had bought more than 21.3 million metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria's Premier Steps Down, But Problems Remain
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The resignation of Bulgaria's Socialist premier calmed raging anti-Communist sentiment, but it hasn't done anything to solve the country's deep economic and political crisis. Unrelenting pressure from the opposition in Parliament and from strikes and street demonstrations forced Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government of former Communists to leave office on Thursday. Tens of thousands of people cheered in the streets of Sofia, an opposition stronghold. But Lukanov's demise may prove a Pyrrhic victory. The main opposition group, the Union of Democratic Forces, must now prove it can help solve Bulgaria's social and economic woes. ``Not even Jesus can fill Bulgarian stores,'' Lukanov said in a recent speech. A new coalition government probably will be announced next week. So far, nothing has been revealed about who will head it, whether it will be a collection of nonpolitical experts or draw in equal numbers on opposition parties and the still-powerful Socialists. The Union of Democratic Forces opposition had long criticized Lukanov for mismanagement, demanding that he step down. But it is questionable whether anybody could manage Bulgaria's economy, which is so dependent on the collapsing Soviet bloc that it can only reflect the chaos of that disintegrating alliance. The opposition case against Lukanov always seemed to rest more on a desire to get the former Communists out of office. The opposition, and many of its Western supporters, seemed convinced it would win June elections. When the Socialists won, the opposition formally accepted the result, but has seemed unable to live with it since. Street demonstrations got under way almost immediately, with students around the country occupying universities to force the resignation of Socialist President Petar Mladenov. Mladenov bowed to the pressure in early July. Then it took three weeks of Byzantine political wrangling to get Zhelyu Zhelev, formerly the opposition leader, appointed president. Lukanov, seen by observers as one of the few capable politicians in Bulgaria, was widely credited with persuading the Socialists to accept Zhelev. But the opposition never came through with the tacitly implied second part of the deal: agreement to join the former Communists in Lukanov's government. Backed by some Western diplomats, the opposition apparently felt the Socialists were a spent political force bound to disintegrate. For his part, Lukanov refused to break with the Socialist Party, arguing that it stood for his social democratic ideals. Lukanov eventually appointed an all-Socialist government but continued to battle for broad support, arguing this was vital to a vague but sweeping program of economic reform. Meanwhile, the economy and society slid into chaos. Electricity and food rationing began in Sofia and other cities in September. Stores have grown barer since. Power is now shut off two hours in every four in the capital. The worst outburst of violence came in late August, when an angry crowd invaded Socialist Party headquarters, burning and pillaging several offices. Last week, the opposition took the decisive step of walking out of Parliament. A general strike by the main opposition union this week proved the final blow to the Socialist government. Although the political parties are said to have agreed on a transition government until new elections are held in May, there is virtually no evidence of political unity. The Socialist Party draws on 100 years of tradition and is even older than the Soviet Communist movement, but remains severely split. The unwieldy opposition coalition of 16 parties also is deeply divided, and boasts few figures of Lukanov's caliber. On Friday, Sofia returned to its bitter reality. The shoppers glumly queuing for food know the new government is unlikely to make life much better. ``Even though I am stepping down, my economic and social program has no alternative,'' Lukanov told the Grand National Assembly in his farewell speech Friday. In his last weeks before resigning, Lukanov pushed for radical market-oriented reforms including an austerity budget that would jack up many state-controlled prices, close down unprofitable firms and introduce guarantees for foreign investments. If Bulgaria does not carry out radical reforms soon, it could find itself lagging far behind ``the European train'' of change, Lukanov told reporters. ``I'm afraid we have already missed the train,'' he added. --- EDITORS: Veselin Toshkov, AP correspondent in Sofia, has worked in posts in Bulgaria and abroad for 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Acquittal Of Former Gestapo Chief
DOC.TEXT: A top-level German court on Friday upheld the acquittal of a former Nazi Gestapo chief accused ff complicity in the murder of French Jews sent to the Auschwitz death camp. Count Modest von Korff, now 81, had been accused of ordering the deportations of Jews from the Chalons-sur-Marne region of northeastern France, where he served as the Nazi Gestapo chief in 1942 and 1943. He was accused in the deaths of 177 deportees. The Karlsruhe-based Federal Court of Justice said it had reviewed the evidence and could not find any legal errors. Korff's case had attracted international attention, and Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld was among the spectators when a trial court acquitted the Gestapo boss two years ago in Bonn. During his trial, Korff claimed he did not know about the extermination of Jews when he served as the secret police boss. The Nazis killed millions, including an estimated 6 million Jews, between 1933 and 1945. Auschwitz, located in modern-day Poland, was the most infamous of the Nazi concentration camps set up by Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. Klarsfeld, the French Nazi hunter, had led prosecutors to Korff, who had held a rank equivalent to captain during the war. The defendant served as an adviser to the West German Economics Ministry until his retirement in the early 1970s. He lives in the the Bonn suburb of Koenigswinter. About 20 relatives of the victims joined Klarsfeld in the courtroom when the verdict was delivered in November 1988. Some of them cried out ``this is a Nazi court!'' and ``Nazi murderer!'' when Judge Martin Lickfett read out the acquittal. It was based on a finding that Korff did not know the reason for the deportations and therefore was not guilty of the murder-relatd charges. However, the victims' families had argued that Korff's assertion that he thought the Jewish deportees were only being sent to work details was simply not credible. To back up that claim, they told the court that Korff had also deported children who were too young to be part of any work crews.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Department Figures Indicate Recession Has Arrived
DOC.TEXT: The government's economic forecasting gauge on Friday belatedly signaled the likelihood of a recession that most economists believe already has begun. The Commerce Department reported its Index of Leading Economic Indicators plunged 1.2 percent in October on top of three previous monthly declines including July when the index was first reported to have been flat. Three consecutive declines in the index have been viewed as a fairly reliable - although not infallible - sign that a recession is approaching. President Bush, speaking at a news conference, confirmed the bad news and attributed at least part of the economic weakness to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent disruption of world oil supplies. ``Our economy, as I said the other day, is at best in a serious slowdown. And if uncertainty remains in the energy makets, the slowdown will get worse.'' Elliott Platt, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a New York securities dealer, said the leading indicators ``should remove any lingering doubts about whether the economy is in a recession,'' Economist Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. said the report was ``another reminder that the economy is unravelling and sliding into a recession.'' The gauge is designed to forecast economic conditions six to nine months in advance. However, recent surveys show that most economists believe the economy already was in a downturn. ``It looks like the leading indicators are catching up with the economy,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``The basic message is that we are in a recession'' and that the economy will continue to decline. William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, agreed. ``Instead of foretelling a recession that is a few months away, those indicators show that it already has started'' and ``suggest that the economy will get even worse before recovering,'' he said. Many analysts had expected the October decline. But the department surprised some observers by revising the July index, which originally was said to be unchanged, to a 0.1 percent decline. The gauge dropped 0.8 percent in September and 1.2 percent in August, the steepest decline since a 1.4 percent plunge in the month following the October 1987 stock market crash. Eight of the 11 forward-looking components were negative in October - consumer confidence fell for the third straight month, weekly unemployment claims rose for the fifth month, the average workweek shortened and building permits declined for the fourth month. At the same time, the money supply shrunk for the sixth month, stock prices were off for the fourth month, the price of raw materials dropped, meaning less demand, and business deliveries sped up indicating fewer orders. The only positive contributors were increases in orders for consumer goods and for new plants and equipment and in unfilled orders. Nevertheless, Dederick found a ``silver lining'' in the positive contributions. He said they suggested that businesses apparently were not cutting back dramatically which would indicate a relatively mild downturn. Platt also predicted the recession would be mild, saying the gross national product would decline no more than 1 percent before the recession ended next summer. Sinai said it could end by spring. MacReynolds, on the other hand, said the overall economy is falling rapidly on the heels of declines in the housing and construction industries and poor performance in the industrial sector. ``Predictions that the recession will be short-lived are based more on wishful thinking than sound economic analysis,'' he said. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive declines in the GNP - the total output of the nation's goods and services. The various changes left the index at 141.6 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 1.9 percent from its level a year ago. The index has fallen during six of the 10 months so far this year. There has not been a recession since World War II without the index turning down for at least three consecutive months. On the other hand, the gauge was negative for six months in 1984 and again for four months following the 1987 crash. Both times, the economy escaped a recession.

DOC.HEAD: Student Says Coaches Threatened To Hang, Shoot Him
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old student said two high school football coaches trying to persuade him to improve his grades threatened to hang him, shoot him and tie him up. The coaches were suspended with pay after the boy's mother filed a complain with the sheriff's department and the justice of the peace, school board president Alton Adams said Thursday. Sheriff's officials said they were investigating the allegations against New Waverly High School's second-year coach Larry Spacek and assistant coach Steve Ramsey, in his first year. New Waverly Middle School student Josh Clark said he was in the high school gymnasium Tuesday when the coaches asked to see him about the possibility of him playing football next year when he's supposed to enter high school. ``Coach Spacek got to talking with me about my grades and then Coach Ramsey said he was tired of me,'' Josh said. He said Spacek threatened to tie him up with an extension cord and hang him from the ceiling. Then Ramsey went ouside to his truck saying he had something better, Josh said. He returned with the starter's pistol - which Josh said he thought was a real gun. Starter's pistols fire blanks. ``I was hollering,'' Josh said. ``I thought he was going to shoot me, but Coach Spacek told him not to.'' Ramsey said his attorney told him not to comment and Spacek would only say he had hired an attorney. Thea Clark, Josh's mother, said her son had nightmares Tuesday night and has refused to go to school since the incident. She said the coaches told her they were ``just playing around'' and meant no harm to her son. ``I don't care if it was just a starter gun,'' she said. ``You don't play with a kid that way.'' School Superintendent Alvin Davis would only say Spacek and Ramsey were disciplined. Davis said the school board would consider the matter at its next meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Women Say Going To Iraq Only Way To Rescue Husbands
DOC.TEXT: Two women who are traveling to Iraq against the U.S. government's advice said Friday their trip is the only way they will secure their husbands' freedom. ``We're caught in the middle,'' said Barbara Smiley of Los Angeles. ``The U.S. government says we are interfering in foreign policy. But what is the foreign policy?'' she said in an interview. The women are part of a larger group of more than a dozen intending to fly from New York to Jordan on Monday before going to Iraq. Saddam has invited the families of hostages to travel to Iraq. Mrs. Smiley and Kim Edwards of Carson City, Nevada, said they have ignored the State Department's warnings about traveling to Iraq because they are confident their trip will achieve their objective: their husbands. ``This is the only way we are going to get them,'' Mrs. Smiley said. ``Saddam has said those who come without guns will not leave empty-handed.'' Her husband, Edward, 42, had been in Kuwait on a new job for three days when Saddam invaded on Aug. 2. Smiley, who was working as a database manager for a Kuwaiti company, has been held as a ``human shield'' at an undisclosed place in Iraq. She and the others opted to visit Iraq because they feel the State Department is not working hard enough to free the hostages. Aside from losing his glasses, Mrs. Smiley said her husband was faring alright in captivity. But he wants his freedom. At a news conference Friday, President Bush said he was ``deeply concerned'' about the roughly 1,000 hostages in Kuwait and Iraq. He condemned Saddam for ``cynical and brutal policy'' in inviting families to see their loved ones. Iraq is ``forcing people to beg for their (the hostages) release, parceling out human lives to families and traveling emissaries like so much chattel,'' he said. Bush also said he is dispatching Secretary of State James Baker III to Baghdad to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis with an eye toward resolving it peacefully. ``I am so sure he is coming out,'' Mrs. Edwards said of her husband, Tony. She said her 52-year-old husband, Tony, a planner with a Japanese firm, was trapped in Baghdad at the time of the invasion. While some members of the group intend to stay for only two weeks, Mrs. Edwards said her plans are to remain in Iraq, where she had lived previously with her husband, until he is released. The State Department has repeatedly urged American families not to go to Iraq. U.S. officials say the families are being used as pawns in Iraq's propaganda war and they cannot guarantee their security. Nevertheless, three Americans were released this week after their relatives traveled to Iraq to personally appeal to Saddam Hussein. Boxer Mohammed Ali is now in Iraq and said he will return to the United States with 14 hostages. The State Department said it could not confirm the figure. Coming Home, a group formed in Champaign, Ill., by businessman Michael Saba, helped coordinate the visit. Saba fled from Iraq in a taxi on Aug. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Pursue Diplomacy, But Embraces Force Resolution
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts one graf after 11th graf, `` - Disputed critics ...,'' with today's market reaction.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced today he was sending Secretary of State James Baker III to Iraq, but blended the last-ditch diplomatic overture with a stern warning to Saddam Hussein that there would ``not be any murky ending'' if war breaks out in the Middle East. Bush welcomed a United Nations resolution that would allow for the use of force after Jan. 15 if Iraq has not withdrawn its troops from Kuwait. ``I don't think there has ever been a question that the United States is going to blink'' in this situation, he said. In televised remarks from the White House, Bush said he hoped that Saddam would receive Baker ``at a mutually convenient time'' between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15. He also invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to Washington for consultations during the week of Dec. 10. Shortly after Bush's remarks, the Iraqi embassy said it had no reaction from Baghdad to Bush's surprise diplomatic move. However, Iraqi Ambassador to France Abdul Razzack al Hashimi told BBC radio in London: ``This is a very important step, really, toward peace, and we hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for, negotiations instead of beating the drums of war ... I consider it very good news.'' But he added, ``We are not accepting pre-condition negoatiations. Let's wait and see, and let's be optimistic, and see what Mr. Baker has in mind.'' Bush said Baker's trip would underscore for Saddam America's determination. ``The best way to get that across is one on one, Baker looking him in the eye. It isn't a trip of concession.'' The United States is increasing its troop commitment in the Gulf to more than 400,000. He said Baker would be prepared ``to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis,'' but said the United States would not waiver in his objectives of total Iraqi withdrawal, restoration of the Kuwaiti government and release of all hostages. In his speech and news conference afterwards, Bush also: - Disclosed that Iraqis have recently appeared unexpectedly at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait with deliveries of cigarettes, fruits and vegetables. He said he understood there was another delivery on Saturday including soda pop. - Said he would not summon Congress into special session to debate the Persian Gulf crisis. He said he would not object to one, but the Democratic leaders of the House and Senate have shown little interest in reconvening. Bush said he wanted to see Congress pass a resolution enthusiastically endorsing the U.N. vote. - Disputed critics who have minimized the potential Iraqi nuclear threat. He said Sen. Al Gore might not be concerned about it, ``but I am not going to err on the side of underestimation.'' In New York, oil prices tumbled more than $3 a barrel to just below $30 in the first hours after Bush spoke, including a drop of more than $1 a barrel in a span of several minutes while Bush appered on television. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up nearly 40 points at 2 p.m. EST. Bush acknowledged some American misgivings about the prospects of war and vowed that if hostilities erupt: ``This will not be another Vietnam. This will not be a protracted, drawn out war.'' He said he saw no need for an American military draft. He said allied forces ``will have the power to get the job done,'' if prompted to confront the Iraqi military. Bush's speech and news conference came against a backdrop of rising criticism of his policy. He announced three weeks ago a further buildup of the 230,000 American troops already in the region. A roster of former government officials told Senate hearings this week the president should exercise caution and give ecionomic sanctions a chance to work befoire committing the United States to military action. A prominent congressional Republican, Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, said the diplomatic avenue would provide ``wiggle room'' for Saddam, and said, ``Anything the president can do to keep the focus of the crisis on diplomacy and not on war is all to the good.'' Bush said there could no compromise on his demands that Iraq withdraw completely, restore the Kuwaiti government to power and release all hostages being held in the crisis. He hailed the U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq doesn't withdraw by Jan. 15, and pointedly observed that economic sanctions alone might not be sufficient to force Saddam to withdraw his troops. If hostilities break out, he said, allied troops ``will have the power to get the job done.'' Speaking of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, Bush said, ``I am hopeful that now he will realize he must leave Kuwait immediately.'' At the same time, he stressed that he has no optimism that Baker's mission will have any ``big results.'' Instead, he said the overture demonstrated his desire to ``go the extra mile'' for a peaceful settlement of the crisis. ``Never has there been a clearer demonstration of a world united against appeasement and aggression,'' the president said, referring to a mulititude of U.N. resolutions demanding Iraq's withdrawal. Said Bush: ``I remain hopeful we can achieve a peaceful solution to this crisis. But if force is required ... we have enough power to get the job done.'' He cautioned Iraq not to misread his motives in pursuing the diplomatic approach. ``I don't think there has ever been a question that the United States is going to blink'' in this situation, he said. Bush's comments appeared designed in part to raise the military stakes with Saddam, but also to respond to critics in Congress who have said he should exercise patience and diplomacy. Allies, especially the Soviet Union and China, have pointedly emphasized the diplomatic approach. He said there is talk of Saddam of not fully understanding his determination to see that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait. He said he wants to see the U.N. resolutions ``implemented to a T.'' That means Iraqi withdrawl from Kuwait, restoration of the Kuwaiti government and release of all hostages beind held in Kuwait, including those used as human shields to discourage military strikes against vital installations. Bush was asked about the potential toll of human lives in a Gulf war. He sighed and said he knew many people wondered, ``How many lives is it worth? ... I will do my level best to bring those kids home without one single shot being fired in anger.'' Bush said, ``those who see no downside to waiting months and months'' must consider ``the damage being done every day'' to the fragile economies of the countries in the region.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Madonna was excused from appearing Friday in court, where a neighbor is suing to force the entertainer to trim her trees and hedges. Superior Court Judge Sally Disco said a deposition Madonna gave earlier could be used instead of testimony after her lawyers said she had received various threats. They did not elabortte. Donald Robinson, Madonna's neighbor in the Hollywood Hills, said she violated a written agreement to keep her hedges and trees trimmed so they wouldn't interfere with the view from Robinson's multimillion-dollar mansion. He said she planted more trees and totally obscured his view of the city. ``My intention was to protect my property value, my view and to enjoy my home,'' said Robinson, a real estate broker. ``I'm seeking damages for the loss of value to my home,'' he said. He estimated that loss at $1 million. Madonna's lawyer, Meghan Serwin, said the star has complied with the agreement and claims Robinson allowed his guests to peer through the hedges to spy on her. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Actor Lorenzo Lamas of television's ``Falcon Crest'' was punched in the face when he tried to break up a fight at a movie theater, authorities said. Lamas, 32, sustained a small cut on his forehead in the Thursday night scuffle at the Cineplex Odeon in suburban Universal City, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Roger Hom. Lamas and his wife, actress Kathleen Kinmont, were watching a movie at the theater when two men sitting in front of them began fighting, Hom said. Lamas tried to break up the fight, but the men turned on him. Lamas was taken to St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank, where he was treated and released, Hom said. Hom said he didn't know what started the fight, adding that the men, who apparently were friends, were both booked for investigation of battery and each released on $250 bail. Lamas is the son of the late actor Fernando Lamas and actress Arlene Dahl. He portrayed Lance Cumson, the playboy heir to a winery empire on the long-running CBS-TV series ``Falcon Crest.'' --- INTERNATIONAL FALLS, Minn. (AP) - Four bar patrons in this Canadian border city helped David Letterman make a recent episode of his New York City-based television show international. Letterman, host of NBC-TV's ``Late Night With David Letterman,'' called the Outpost bar to find someone to make the short drive over the border into Canada and call him at his studio. He gave bartender Laurie Hansen the number and hung up. ``Anybody want to call David Letterman?'' she yelled to the few customers in the bar late Tuesday afternoon. There were a few guffaws, but she convinced a party of four to drive the mile to the border, where Jerry Vohler called Letterman from a Canadian customs office just before the show's taping ended. Hansen said she thought the call was a joke at first, but she could hear the audience laughing and had seen the show enough times to know that it would be like Letterman to arrange such a stunt. The show was broadcast early Wednesday morning. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Musicians Waylon Jennings, his wife Jessi Colter, Charlie Daniels and Rodney Crowell will add some life to the displays and memorabilia at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum during the holidays. Crowell is to read ``The Polar Express,'' a children's Christmas story by Chris Van Allsburg, for museum visitors Dec. 7. Daniels is to perform songs from his new album, ``Christmas Time Down South,'' and read a holiday story Dec. 13. Jennings and Colter are to perform acoustic music and Christmas carols Dec. 21. More than 400,000 people visit the 21-year-old museum each year.

DOC.HEAD: Solider Refusing Middle East Deployment Faces Court Martial
DOC.TEXT: Military officials have recommended a court-martial for a soldier who refused to go to the Persian Gulf, saying he believed ``with all my heart, war is wrong.'' Sgt. George Morse, 25, was charged with refusing orders to prepare equipment for transport to Saudi Arabia. Army officials on Thursday recommended the court-martial for Morse, who plays trumpet in the 1st Infantry Division band. He was to have been assigned to division headquarters as a military police officer, said Mike Zucca, Fort Riley spokesman. ``We have not had a chance to talk to our client and formulate what our next action is,'' said Joanne Brooke, an assistant to Morse's attorney, Robert Littrell. Morse, a six-year veteran, was confined to the post Wednesday after the charges were filed, Ms. Brooke said. He has been assigned a military defense lawyer, but has retained Littrell. President Bush has sent 430,000 troops to the Persian Gulf following Iraq's invasion of oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United Nations Security ouncil voted 12-2 Thursday to allow force to be used if Iraq doesn't withdraw by Jan. 15. ``I now believe with all my heart, war is wrong,'' Morse wrote in his Nov. 23 request for conscientious objector status. ``Not just in the Middle East, but in any case. I cannot have any part in the senseless killing of war.'' ``I will not participate in a war effort or a military effort, no matter if it has started yet, or not,'' Morse said earlier this week. Morse, of Grayling, Mich., was scheduled to be discharged Dec. 20. The Army denied his application for conscientious objector status on Saturday. The 1st Infantry was activated Nov. 8. He was reassigned to a unit not being sent to the Middle East. His case is similar to others that have resulted from the troop deployment. In Albuquerque, N.M., a soldier who sought conscientious objector status was demoted last week and confined to his barracks for refusing an order to bear arms during training. Earlier this month, Illinois Army reservist, Spc. Stephanie Atkinson, was discharged in Louisville, Ky., and excused from duty in the Persian Gulf after saying she was a conscientious objector. In Hawaii, the Marine Corps has rejected Cpl. Jeffery Paterson's application for concientious objector status. His court-martial has been scheduled for Dec. 3. If the Fort Riley commander accepts the recommendation for a court-martial, Morse can choose a trial by jury or military judge, Ms. Brooke said. Maximum punishment could include a term in the Army Disciplinary Barracks at Fort Leavenworth and a dishonorable discharge.

DOC.HEAD: China's Envoy Meets with Baker
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 6 grafs new with bush meeting Chinese envoy; picks up 5th graf pvs, But Qian.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met today with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, here for the first time since China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators, and said they hoped to reduce differences between the two countries. With Qian at his side as they posed for photographers, Bush acknowledged that he has ``some differences'' with China on human rights but added that there are ``many positive and very important aspects'' to the relationship. ``One purpose of this kind of meeting is to reduce the differences,'' Bush said. Bush and Qian met after prolonged confusion over whether the meeting actually would take place. The State Department announced the meeting, then issued a revised schedule suggesting it had been canceled. But the meeting was held after Qian met for more than two hours with Secretary of State James A. Baker. Qian made the visit amid signs of new strains in Sino-American relations. Chinese officials had led the Bush administration to believe that Qian would support the U.S.-backed resolution approved Thursday in the U.N. Security Council. The resolution authorizes the use of force against Iraq. But Qian opted instead to abstain, causing surprise and disappointment at the State Department. Qian revealed he was not prepared to support the resolution as he was leaving Beijing for New York. He left the impression among some that his government was annoyed with speculation that the United States was inviting Qian to Washington to reward him for China's support in the Persian Gulf crisis. Hours before the vote, the Chinese Foreign Ministry denied there was any link between China's stand on the resolution and Qian's invitation to visit Washington. Baker had wanted as lopsided a vote as possible to send a clear signal to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein of international resolve on the gulf situation. China had supported all 10 previous Security Council resolutions on that issue. Excluding China's vote, the tally Thursday was 12-2 in support of the resolution. There also are clear signs that human rights questions continue to be a sore point between the two countries since the crackdown on demonstrators in China a year and a half ago. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing said in Beijing, ``It is not appropriate to interfere in some developing countries' internal affairs with an excuse of human rights.'' The Bush administration has barred high-level exchanges with China as a show of displeasure over its crackdown on demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. It has said Qian's visit does not violate that policy because his discussions in Washington are regarded as ``contacts,'' which are permitted. Meetings in the category of ``large ceremonial exchanges'' are barred. The State Department has noted that Baker has met on a number of previous occasions with Qian since the events at Tiananmen Square. Three of the meetings were in New York and the others were in Paris and Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: First Foreign Food Aid Reaches Moscow Children's Homes, Hospitals
LaserPhotos MOSB1-3
DOC.TEXT: ``What do you make from flour?'' the teacher at Children's Boarding School No. 24 asked her two dozen pupils on Friday, hoisting a kilogram sack from the first shipment of Western food aid to arrive in Moscow. ``Blini!'' they chorused, smiling at the prospect of sweet Russian pancakes for dinner. ``And what do you say?'' their teacher continued. ``Thank you!'' they responded. As the first planeload of donated food from Germany was distributed to orphanages and children's hospitals, the generosity spread in other Western nations. Vienna promised 100,000 food parcels for Moscow children, and organizations in the United States, Italy and the Nordic countries prepared shipments of milk, flour, canned goods and other staples. In Leningrad, Pravda reported, ambulances have been collecting victims of fainting from hunger, heart attacks and broken ribs from the lines outside shops. The price of carrots doubled as citizens braced for Saturday's start of Leningrad's first rationing program since World War II. Then, it was besieged by Nazi forces for 900 days and hundreds of thousands died, many from hunger. The Moscow newspaper Vechernaya Moskva printed a plaintive appeal from a caller on Friday. ``My child is crying with hunger. Where can I buy just a little butter, cereal and eggs?'' a parent asked. At Children's Hospital No. 3 in Moscow, warehouse clerk Yulia Bodganova gratefully received a German gift of beans, chicken soup and flour - even though the hospital has been better supplied than the city at large. It was only this week that its food supplier warned that the young patients could no longer be spared the shortages. ``We've received no sour cream or cottage cheese for three days,'' she said. By Friday, the usual deliveries of cheese and eggs also had evaporated. A few blocks away, engineer Kim Melkonian was the 170th person in a line for butter in the gathering dusk at 4 p.m. Calculating one minute per customer, he figured he would be waiting three hours in the darkened street before even entering the store. He blamed the shortages on sabotage by bureaucrats struggling to hold onto their power in the face of growing democracy. Soviet officials have said the country has produced no less food this year than last, despite the barren shelves that have panicked shoppers into hoarding and exacerbating the shortages. But Western governments are worried that frightened consumers could destabilize the government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has made aid to the Soviets a top item on his international agenda, arguing that without a stable Soviet Union, reforms in eastern Europe could be endangered. ``We need the Western aid,'' Melkonian said. ``There is enough food, but people are afraid. We have to calm them down.'' ``When Gorbachev came to power, people said, `Mikhail Sergeyevich, we can do without butter, just as long as there is no war.' Now, there's no longer any danger of war, and everyone is saying, `Give us bread,''' Melkonian said. ``We do have wheat and bread in this country, we do have the necessary food, but where is it?'' asked Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov at a briefing Friday. ``It's hidden by the state-owned farms, collective farms. Which ones? The best ones, because the worst ones do not have anything.'' ``They understand (that) when the land will be privatized there will be no place for them,'' he said. Several republics and regions have cut off shipments of food beyond their borders, leaving major cities like Moscow with diminished supplies of milk and meat - which have never been plentiful. Many farmers have stopped selling their crops through state stores at low official prices and switched to private farmers' markets, where prices are often 10 times as high. Theft is also rising, prompting the national parliament to order the KGB to protect incoming shipments of humanitarian aid. On Friday, the secretive police agency said it was forming a special unit for the task. Popov said Muscovites will soon be given passes allowing them to purchase goods in specific stores at specific times, to help people who complain that the shelves are empty when they get off work. Permits will specify the store, date, time and amount of money an individual can spend. Vienna Mayor Helmut Zilk, who announced his city's $2-million aid program at the news conference in Moscow with Popov, said this food ``should be given to the retirees, to the most vulnerable groups of people, the people who went through the war.'' ``After the second world war, all the allies helped us ... so we must now help you,'' Zilk said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Department Must Bargain With Unions Over Smoking Ban
DOC.TEXT: The government department that is leading the federal fight against cigarette smoking was ordered Friday to bargain with unionized employees over whether they may puff away on the job. The Department of Health and Human Services, which in 1987 banned smoking by its 118,000 employees in all of the agency's offices nationwide, was ordered by the court to bargain with three union locals whose members want a place to smoke. A Federal Labor Relations Authority order that HHS bargain with the three union locals was unanimously upheld in the decision by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. There was no immediate comment from HHS. But union attorney David F. Klein said the decision upholds an important principle that federal agencies must bargain with employees over working conditions unless they have a compelling reason not to negotiate. HHS's ``compelling reason not to was to set an example for the general public and the court didn't buy that,'' Klein said. He said the decision will serve as a precedent for any other union locals that wish to challenge the HHS smoking ban. After HHS promulgated the no-smoking rules in 1987, the three local chapters of the National Treasury Employees Union sought to bargain over what the union argued was a change in working conditions. The locals, representing employees at the agency's Washington headquarters, the Family Support Administration, and the Kansas City regional office, proposed setting up designated smoking areas similar to those in other government agencies. But HHS, said it was not compelled to bargain with the union because the smoking ban was a crucialpart of its mission to persuade private companies to create smoke-free environments for all workers. The agency cited a 1986 report by the U.S. surgeon general about the health risks to non-smoking employees who breath the cigarette smoke of co-workers. ``Nothing less than a policy of a smoke-free environment can assure adequate protection of the occupants in department-controlled building space,'' HHS said at the time. But the appeals court noted a government-wide regulation promulgated by the General Services Administration allows smoking in designated areas ``and also recognizes the collective bargaining obligations of government agencies on the question.'' HHS's ``health-based argument is consequently a collateral attack on the government-wide GSA regulation'' which, the court noted, ``requires that agencies accommodate the needs of smokers where feasible.'' The court didn't dispute what it recognized as the agency's legitimate concern for the health of employees. ``It is hard to see how it can be argued, however, that HHS's concern for its employees can be qualitatively different from that of other government agencies,'' the court said in an opinion by Circuit Judge Laurence Silberman. The court upheld the federal labor panel's determination that HHS had failed to prove a ``compelling need'' to declare its smoking rules off-limits to collective bargaining.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Vote Supporting Bush in Gulf Unlikely for Now
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he'd ``love to see'' Congress formally back the U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq, but some on Capitol Hill say the lawmakers are much less receptive than the diplomats. In any case, Bush said Friday he has no plans to call Congress into special session to address the issue. And his announcement that he'll send Secretary of State James A. Baker III on a diplomatic mission to Baghdad seemed to make congressional action in the meantime all the less likely. If Congress were to take on the issue soon, said House Speaker Thomas Foley, ``obviously, it's very difficult to tell what the response would be.'' ``Congress could amend it, put conditions on it, pass it by a narrow margin, or defeat it by a narrow margin. That's a matter the president will have to consider, said Foley, D-Wash. Still, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, renewing his call for a special session, said there would be bipartisan backing for a resolution of support if it could be brought to a vote. Bush went on television declaring a willingness to ``go the extra mile'' in the quest for peace. He offered to swap high-level visits with Iraq, and was meeting later with senior members of Congress to consult on his gulf policy. One senior Democratic aide said it would be ``pointless'' to hold a formal debate until after Baker and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz hold talks in each others capitals between now and Jan. 15. Some leading Republicans on Capitol Hill have suggested that Bush quickly seek ratification by Congress of the resolution approved by the United Nations Security Council on Thursday, authorizing military action to liberate Kuwait if Iraq does not withdraw by Jan. 15. Such a move, they say, would demonstrate to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that the United States was united and determined that his aggression against Kuwait would not be rewarded. They want Bush to act while his international momentum is high. ``I'd love to see Congress pass a resolution enthusiastically endorsing what the United Nations has done,'' Bush said at a White House news conference. ``What I don't want to do is have it come back and end up where you have 435 voices in one house and 100 in the other, saying what NOT to do,'' he said, adding that he hopes to avoid a ``hand-wringing operation that would send bad signals.'' ``I know my strengths, and I know the limitations on the presidency,'' Bush said. Democrats in Congress, and some Republicans, are saying the president should not take support for granted. All week, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has paraded former military officials before his Armed Services Committee criticizing Bush's gulf policy. Congressional critics say Bush still has not provided a coherent rationale for the latest escalation in U.S. troop deployment and for the apparent shift to an offensive stance that it signals. ``At this point I would not support it,'' Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said of a possible resolution, speaking in advance of the president's speech. ``We could see an extraordinarily messy situation created by a congressional vote,'' one which portrays not the unity that Bush seeks, but division, he said. ``He must go and sell the American public as to why it's necessary.'' And Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the Foreign Affairs Committee, cautioned Bush to wait to develop a better consensus before asking Congress to rule on his policy. At its core, the problem is relatively simple: How does Congress help Bush amplify his threats to use force against Iraq in the hope of forcing Saddam to back down, without at the same time giving up its right to decide whether ultimately to go to war? Many lawmakers fear that they would, in voting for a resolution approving military action, be giving Bush a blank check for whatever moves he may choose. An endorsement by Congress would not be simply a vote of confidence in the same manner as the U.N. resolution, said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``It ups the ante,'' he said. ``Then you have changed the policy and force can happen.'' Gephardt welcomed Bush's moves Friday as a use of the U.N. vote to give new life to diplomacy. ``There is broad support in this country for moving in this direction, and Saddam Hussein should know that America is united in our determination to see him end his brutal occupation,'' Gephardt said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., suggested that Congress could pass a resolution that puts on the record what many Democrats have been saying all week at Senate hearings on the gulf crisis: that economic sanctions should be allowed time to work, even if it takes a year or more. ``Going to war now or in the next few months would be a mistake that could cost the lives of thousands of Americans for no justifiable reason,'' Kennedy said. But if there are risks for Bush, there are risks for Congress as well in seeking to fence the president's actions. ``How can you vote against a resolution if you've got your boys on the front line shooting or being shot at?'' said Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass. ``We should be brought into the situation'' before that, he said.

DOC.HEAD: World Almanac Says Symington is Governor
DOC.TEXT: The World Almanac appears to have jumped the gun regarding the outcome of Arizona's gubernatorial election. According to The 1991 World Almanac and Book of Facts, Fife Symington is the new governor. However, after the Nov. 6 general election votes were counted, neither Republican Symington nor his Democratic opponent, Terry Goddard, received a majority and a runoff election was declared for Feb. 26. Two million copies of the almanac are hitting the bookstore shelves this week containing the wrong information. ``We go to press practically as soon as the results are in on Election Day night,'' said Martha Clarke, publicity manager for Pharos Books, a subsidiary of Scripps Howard, which has published the almanac since 1986. ``The governors of the states, except in your case, apparently, are correct,'' Ms. Clarke said. ``Literally, the editor in chief is writing down the results on his way to the printing press.'' Although there is no mention of a runoff, a section titled ``The Race for Governor: 1990'' mentions that the results are ``preliminary.'' The almanac shows Symington with 519,558 votes to Goddard's 515,999. After all precincts were counted, official election results show Symington with 523,984 to Goddard's 519,691 votes out of more than 1.09 million votes cast. ``They got it wrong and they'll have to change it in February,'' Goddard said. ``They'll have to buy a lot of white-out.'' Symington, who has referred to the runoff campaign as a ``re-election'' bid, said, ``I think it's very amusing, and hopefully, it's a good omen,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Who Dined With Bush on Thanksgiving Welcome U.N. Resolution
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The soldiers who shared Thanksgiving dinner with President Bush said Friday they welcomed the ultimatum set by the U.N. Security Council as the only way to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. ``He better let the hostages go and he better leave, or we're coming to get him,'' said Sgt. William R. Blocker, 7, of Sylacauga, Ala., who chatted with Barbara Bush as he ate his turkey and trimmings. A week after their commander-in-chief told them he would not let Saddam remain in Kuwait indefinitely, soldiers from the 197th Infantry Brigade gathered in their dusty desert camp to voice support for his latest success at the United Nations. Several said the resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq fails to leave conquered Kuwait by Jan. 15 should have been adopted months ago. It was passed Thursday. ``I think it's about 90 days too late, but I can live with Jan. 15,'' said Sgt. Mark Channer, 25, of New York City, who was Mrs. Bush's escort. His advice to Saddam: ``Pack up and move out quick.'' Sgt. James Landreth, 29, of New Boston, Ohio, who ate turkey with Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, echoed Channer saying, ``it should have happened a while back. As we got here, they should already have figured that out.'' For months, Blocker said, the troops have ``been in limbo'' not knowing if they were going to stay here or go home. ``Now we know we're going to be here 'til the end - 'til he either leaves or we force him out. It's a good relief to hear something like that because basically they opened the door and let us out of the dark and they let us know what was going on,'' Blocker said. Cpl. Thomas Cook, 32, of Granite City, Ill., like the rest of the brigade has spent three months in a desolate patch of desert, about an hour's ride from the nearest paved highway in a four-wheel drive vehicle down a bumpy sand trail. Bush wants to put an end to the stalemate, he said. ``We can't just sit out here and just keep yelling at each other so somebody's got to do something,'' Cook said. Sgt. 1st Class Steven Campbell, 37, of Ft. Benning, Ga., where the brigade is headquartered, said: ``It's an indication again that we're not going to back down from Hussein. I think it needed to be done and we did it, and the U.N. is the forum to do it.'' ``I'd like to get home sooner to my wife and children, but I'm not packing my bags yet,'' said the 19-year Army veteran who introduced the president to the 1,250 soldiers and politicians at Thanksgiving dinner. Spec. Robert Terry, 23, of Rehoboth Beach, Del., said Bush's visit helped morale and the U.N. resolution would also be a boost. ``I think the guys out here - now that they have a positive date that something will happen, I think that'll help 'em out,'' he said. ``But truthfully, I think Hussein'll pull out before that. He's got more brains than that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Suggest They Would Use Force To Protect Citizens In Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union would not hesitate to use military force to protect its 3,300 nationals held in Iraq, officials said Friday, edging away from their previous refusal to send troops to the region. ``Everybody should know that we will not hesitate to use force to protect our citizens,'' Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze told the official Tass news agency. ``It's high time to end inaction in situations when human life, dignity and fate become expendable currency in an immoral political game,'' he said in an interview in New York. The Kremlin has said Iraq would face ``serious consequences'' if Soviet citizens were harmed. But until now, it had not said specifically that its response could include military force. Shevardnadze's tough talk came a day after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hardened his stand in the Persian Gulf crisis, calling for military pressure to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Concern about Soviet citizens was also expressed by Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky, who returned to Moscow early Friday following a 36-hour visit to Iran, Iraq's neighbor and enemy during their eight-year gulf war. ``It is obvious that we would be prepared to take the most drastic measures to protect the life of every individual Soviet citizen if the need arises,'' Petrovsky told a news briefing. Moscow sent two warships to the gulf soon after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait to protect commercial ships, but has repeatedly maintained it would not participate in a multinational force or naval blockade unless it were under the auspices of the United Nations. The Soviet Union voted Thursday in favor of the U.N. Security Council resolution giving Iraq a Jan. 15 deadline to withdraw from Kuwait and release all foreign hostages or risk military action. Asked whether that meant the Soviet Union now was prepared to send troops, both Shevardnadze and Petrovsky couched their answers in terms of possible threats to Soviet citizens stranded there. The Soviet nationals are not known to be held as human shields at potential military targets. Petrovsky said a decision to dispatch troops would require additional consultations and deliberations. He did not elaborate. Petrovsky also warned Iraq not to underestimate the global determination to dislodge him from Kuwait. ``Iraq should not misinterpret the will of international security and should have no doubt that the world community is ready to act,'' he said. ``This choice is up to Baghdad and it will shape the action of the world communityin the future.'' Petrovsky said he hoped Thursday's U.N. vote ``may serve as a serious signal to help Iraq to understand the seriousness of the situation. I would like to hope that Iraq has not said its last word.''

DOC.HEAD: Outgoing Florida Governor Nominated as Drug Policy Coordinator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with nomination
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush named Florida Gov. Bob Martinez today to run the Office of National Drug Control Policy and designated William J. Bennett to become chairman of the Republican National Committee. Bush called Martinez, defeated for re-election earlier this month, ``a leader who's earned his stripes on the front-lines of the drug war.'' Bennett left office today as head of the drug policy agency where he had served for 19 months. With Bush's endorsement, Bennett is assured of election to the party post when the Republican National Committee meets in January. Bennett will succeed Lee Atwater, who was sidelined last spring by a malignant brain tumor. Bush said he was recommending that Atwater be named ``general chairman'' of the party, a post that does not currently exist. ``I'm delighted that Lee Atwater will continue to provide valued counsel as general chairman of the party,'' said the president. ``He has been, as you all know, a close adviser and political strategist - chief political strategist - and a good friend.'' Bennett began his government career as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities during the Reagan administration and then served as secretary of education. Martinez served one term as governor of Florida and was defeated on Nov. 6 by former Sen. Lawton Chiles. Bush said that Martinez, as the National Governors' Association's leader in fighting substance abuse, ``has been contributing to our national drug control strategy for over two years.'' His new job requires Senate confirmation, and Martinez was planning to visit with congressional leaders before returning to Florida for the weekend. Bennett, a former Democrat who also was an outspoken conservative, served as drug policy coordinator since Bush became president. During his four years as governor of Florida, Martinez initiated several high-profile anti-drug policies and even took a drug test himself to set an example for state workers. Martinez also pushed through the state legislature a law mandating the death penalty for drug kingpins in certain cases and a measure requiring tougher penalties for drug-dealing near schools. The governor is chairman of the National Governors' Association task force on substance abuse and drug trafficking. He visited Bolivia and Colombia in 1988 with the National Guard on a drug fact-finding mission.

DOC.HEAD: President Says New Elections in May
With AM-Bulgaria-Challenge, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria will hold elections in six months to replace Parliament, which has been dominated by former Premier Andrei Lukanov's unpopular governing Socialist Party, according to news reports Friday. The trade union newspaper Trud quoted President Zhelyu Zhelev as saying a May date for elections was set as part of an agreement reached between Lukanov and other political leaders prior to Lukanov's resignation on Thursday. ``During these consultations it was the common opinion that the Grand National Assembly should be retained until March,'' Zhelev said. ``Afterward it should disband and the elections should take place in May.'' Legislators on Friday accepted Lukanov's resignation, which was provoked by weeks of anti-government strikes and protests. There was no evidence in Sofia on Friday of the strikes organized by the Podkrepa trade union and other widespread protests that had disrupted the capital for weeks. High-placed officials said a new premier probably would be named next week. Speaking on condition of anonymity, they said top contenders were Ginyo Ganev, the deputy chairman of parliament, and Krastyo Petkov, head of the main Confederation of Independent Trade Unions. Speaking to Parliament, Lukanov said the agreement under which he stepped down offered this Balkan nation of 9 million people a chance to end its worst postwar crisis. That opportunity ``if missed, may prove the last one,'' he said. ``Even though I am stepping down, my economic and social progra has no alternative,'' Lukanov told the Grand National Assembly. In his last week as premier, Lukanov pushed through Parliament an austerity budget calling for steep price increases. The current Parliament, dominated by Lukonov's Socialist Party, was elected in June during Bulgaria's first free elections in decades. At the time, it was agreed the elected legislators would serve for a minimum of one year. But the popularity of the Socialists has fallen steadily since then, and the opposition coalition Union of Democratic Forces says it would win any new elections. Many Bulgarians associate Lukanov, a reformed former Communist, with four decades of communism, and tens of thousands of people gathered Thursday night to cheer his resignation. But he was one of the few Bulgarian politicians with the government experience and stature for the premiership. He had urged the Socialist Party under Chairman Alexander Lilov to reform itself. But Lukanov apparently was unable to press changes on the party or to break entirely with it, and ended up sharing the party's unpopularity. A new government of largely inexperienced leaders will face daunting problems that have grown steadily worse in months of political inaction because of the stalemate between the Socialists and the opposition. Electricity is rationed in Sofia and elsewhere. Foodstuffs and many basic consumer items are either rationed or unavailable, and the country cannot make payments on its $11 billion foreign debt. Lukanov said political leaders had agreed that a new coalition government would be formed soon and that his successor should not belong to his own party or the opposition alliance. Lukanov told a news conference that his resignation would ``not be fatal'' for the Socialists, but said changes were needed in the party. ``Now that we are not a governing party, it gives us a chance to solve our internal problems and determine the collective and individual responsibility within the party'' for the country's problems, he said. Lukanov was one of a group of reformed Communists who helped oust longtime Communist leader Todor Zhivkov last November. He was appointed premier in early February and then presided over the country's increasing polarization, deteriorating living standards and growing public anger.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Dispatching More Warplanes to Gulf; More Reservists Called
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force is sending more warplanes, including at least one additional squadron of F-111 tactical fighter-bombers, to the Persian Gulf area to expand America's offensive air power, officials said Friday. Separately the Air Force, Marine Corps and Navy announced call-ups of more than 3,500 reservists from 36 states and the District of Columbia for Operation Desert Shield. The total number of American reservists on active duty in Desert Shield is now approaching 100,000, the biggest activation since the 1961 Berlin crisis. Capt. Betsy Well of the Air Force public affairs office at the Pentagon said F-111s from the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing at Royal Air Force Station Lakenheath in Britain began deploying to Saudi Arabia on Thursday. Citing security rules, she declined to say how many planes and Air Force personnel were going. Ms. Well said an unspecified number of maintenance and combat support personnel also deployed to Saudi Arabia from the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing earlier this week. The Air Force sent F-111s to the Arabian Peninsula from Lakenheath in late August and early September as part of the initial U.S. military buildup in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The latest deployment is a result of President Bush's decision, announced Nov. 8, to send large reinforcements to provide a greater offensive capability against the Iraqi forces. The F-111 is a swing-wing supersonic bomber capable of carrying either nuclear or conventional arms and able to operate from treetop level to altitudes above 60,000 feet. F-111s from Lakenheath were used in the U.S. bombing of Libya in 1986. Air Force officials said plans are under way to dispatch a variety of other aircraft to Saudi Arabia, but they declined to provide details. Last week the Air Force announced that an unspecified number of OA-10 low-level observation aircraft were being sent to the gulf from Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, Ariz. The Los Angeles Times, citing unidentified defense sources, reported in Friday's editions that the Pentagon is sending 300 more warplanes to the gulf to increase the total Air Force deployments in the region to about 1,200 planes. The Times said the new deployments will include a second squadron of F-117 Stealth fighter-bombers, additional F-15E ground-attack planes, F-16 fighters, A-10 tank-killers, refueling tankers and RF-4C photo-reconnaissance aircraft. The newspaper report said 27 Air Force units with about 10,000 additional personnel will be sent to the region. Some will deploy from Europe and others will come from U.S.-based Air National Guard and Air Force Reserve units, it said. Col. Joseph Purka, an Air Force spokesman, said he could not comment on the Times report. In another sign that the Air Force is building up further in the gulf, service officials announced that 89 members of the Air National Guard were ordered to active duty. The Air Force reservists include 27 members of the 169th Services Flight, 169th Tactical Fighter Group at McEntire Air National Guard Base in South Carolina; 18 members of the 174th Services Flight, 174th Tactical Fighter Wing at Syracuse, N.Y.; and 44 members of the 140th Security Police, 140th Tactical Fighter Wing, Buckley Air National Guard Base in Colorado. The Marine Corps announced that it is ordering 2,996 reservists to report for active duty next weekend in support of Desert Shield. Of that total, 2,274 men from infantry and artillery units were ordered to report Dec. 9 for duty at Camp Courtney in Okinawa, Japan, the home station of the 3rd Marine Expeditionary Force. The Marines said 722 reservists were ordered to report for active duty Dec. 8. About 300 of those will go to Camp Pendleton, Calif., with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force, and the rest will be assigned to 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Lejeune, N.C., ``for processing and to await further orders.'' The Navy called up 437 reservists, mainly for medical and intelligence support.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Sees Talks Within 2 Months on Short-Range Nuclear Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The chief Soviet negotiator at talks on reducing conventional arms in Europe said Friday he believes new negotiations to reduce tactical nuclear weapons on the continent can start within two months. His comment was believed to be the first time an official from either the Warsaw Pact or the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had publicly mentioned a time frame for such negotiations. The Kremlin has long pushed for talks on reducing short-range, or tactical, nuclear weapons, the only nuclear arms in Europe not so far reduced by treaty or under negotiation. Such weapons have a range of less than 300 miles. The West's short-range weapons, most based in what was West Germany, would hit targets in what are now considered friendly East European countries. Until recently, the West resisted negotiating away what NATO has viewed as a vital element in its nuclear deterrence to counter the Warsaw Pact's massive ground forces in Eastern Europe.
