In Paris this month, the leaders of the 22 nations in NATO and the Warsaw Pact took historic steps toward reducing the danger of a surprise attack by those ground forces, signing an accord that slashed tanks and other conventional arms in Europe by 100,000 units and a formal declaration of non-aggression. A second phase of negotiations, aimed primarily at reducing the number of soldiers in Europe, opened in Vienna Nov. 26. However, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev stressed at the Paris summit that Moscow wants naval forces and tactical nuclear weapons included either in the Vienna talks or negotiated elsewhere. ``I think that, within two months, we will be in a position to start such negotiations,'' Oleg Grinevsky, Soviet ambassador to the Vienna arms reduction talks, told a new conference when asked about negotiations on tactical nuclear weapons. He declined to be more specific. Another Soviet negotiator, Oleg Khlestov, said: ``The situation is only in the process of defining ideas.'' NATO agreed last summer that talks on reducing tactical nuclear weapons could begin ``shortly'' after the treaty signed in Paris was wrapped up, but has not given a more specific date or place. Khlestov reiterated the Kremlin view that naval forces should be included in Vienna talks, arguing that confrontation has moved to the naval arena now that substantial reductions have been negotiated in ground and air forces. The West has resisted including naval forces, saying this would require complex global talks rather than ones confined to North America and Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Reject U.N. Security Council Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Iraq rejects the U.N. Security Council ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait and will fight to keep the conquered emirate if necessary, the ruling Revolutionary Command Council said Friday. The seven-man council led by President Saddam Hussein said the U.N. resolution authorizing military force if Iraq doesn't leave Kuwait by Jan. 15 is ``illegal, null and void'' because it was imposed by the United States. ``Should the forces of evil launch aggression, this nation of impossible missions will teach all those a hard lesson unprecedented in history,'' the council said, one day after the resolution was adopted by the Security Council. However, the Revolutionary Command Council repeated a call for dialogue with the United States to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis and the Palestinian question on ``the basis of equality and mutual respect.'' Saddam has repeatedly tried to link a resolution of the gulf crisis with a resolution of the Palestinian uprising in Israel. The United States has repeatedly rejected such a linkage, demanding an unconditional withdrawal. On Friday President Bush unexpectedly offered to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad to discuss the crisis. In Baghdad, the Iraqi leadership was taken by surprise by Bush's announcement about Baker and immediately went back into session to discuss the development, diplomats said. It was not known who attended the meeting. On Thursday, Saddam said Iraq would not be intimidated by the U.N. Security Council resolution. He insisted his armed forces had the technology to defeat sophisticated American weapons such as stealth aircraft. ``The Americans are still influenced by Rambo movies but this is not a Rambo movie. This is something different,'' he said. Friday's Revolutionary Command Council statement said the Iraqi people ``reject ultimatums and threats and will never bow to tyranny and terrorism.'' The resolution, it said, was ``first and foremost an American decision in which certain powers participated only under American pressure.'' ``The United States mobilized all its resources in an unprecedented move to practice all forms pressure and terrorism and pay, together with its agents, the bribes to secure the votes,'' the statement said. Cuba and Yemen, the only Arab member on the 15-member Security Council, voted against the resolution on Thursday. China abstained. ``It is a shameful resolution, tarnished with the scandals that have transformed the Security Council into a cover for U.S. hegemony and a theater for its dirty deals,'' the Revolutionary Command Council said. It noted that the council had failed to end Israeli occupation of Arab territories, and because of this Arab masses would reject the latest resolution against Iraq. ``These nations which voted to give legitimacy to America's aggression against Iraq, made no move to confront the Israeli aggression against Palestine,'' the statement said. ``Instead, they maneuvered to slow down any effort against the rape of Jerusalem and against the premeditated crimes committed by the Zionist occupation forces,'' it said. ``The double standards these powers have become crystal clear after the latest resolution,'' the Iraqi leaders said.

DOC.HEAD: Actor David White, Larry Tate on `Bewitched,' Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Imposter, 5th graf, is cq
DOC.TEXT: Actor David White, who played the long-suffering advertising executive Larry Tate on ABC-TV's ``Bewitched,'' has died of a heart attack. He was 74. White died Tuesday at the Medical Center of North Hollywood. White was best known for portraying Darrin Stephens' clumsy, demanding boss at McMann and Tate on the comedy series ``Bewitched.'' The show, which starred Elizabeth Montgomery and her twitching nose, ran from 1964 to 1972. White also appeared in such popular television series as ``Cagney & Lacey,'' ``Remington Steele,'' ``Quincy, M.E.,'' ``The Love Boat'' and ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show.'' His film credits included ``Sweet Smell of Success,'' ``The Apartment,'' ``The Great Imposter,'' ``Madison Avenue'' and ``Sunrise at Campobello.'' He had Broadway roles in ``Leaf and Bough,'' ``Affairs of State,'' ``The Bird Cage,'' ``Anniversary Waltz'' and ``One Foot in the Door.'' White is survived by a daughter, Alexandra, and a nephew.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Leaders Liable to be Judged For War Crimes, Allies Say
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi leaders will be tried for war crimes just as the Nazis were after World War II, a senior U.S. official said Friday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the foreign ministers of Britain, France and the Soviet Union all stressed the individual liability of Iraq's leaders in their addresses before the U.N. Security Council on Friday. A senior U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Geneva Conventions of 1949 on the protection of civilians and the 1925 Geneva Accords barring the use in war of chemical or biological weapons provide the legal basis for culpability. Iraq is a party to both agreements. Kuwaiti exiles horrified the Security Council on Tuesday with their personal accounts of torture, rape, murder, and other atrocities perpetrated by Iraqi troops occupying Kuwait. Their stories were backed with lurid color photographs of alleged torture victims, and videotapes, including a sequence in which Iraqi troops appeared to fire on peaceful protesters. Iraq has denied reports of any systematic abuse by its soldiers. No resolution dealing with the issue of war crimes is planned in the immediate future, said the U.S. senior official and a Soviet diplomat, partly because the Geneva agreements cover the situation. Also, they said, under the ``use of force'' resolution adopted by the Security Council on Thursday, the world community pledged to take no new steps against Baghdad until Jan. 15 as a ``pause of good will.'' After that date, nations allied with Kuwait's government-in-exile are authorized by the resolution to ``use all necessary means'' to liberate the emirate and free the hostages held by Baghdad. ``All necessary means'' covers diplomatic efforts as well as a military strike to dislodge Iraq and recover the hostages. However, the U.S.-led multinational forces massing in the gulf will not be ready to launch an attack until late January or February, U.S. officials say. About 200,000 U.S. reinforcements are on their way to Saudi Arabia. A senior Soviet diplomat said there was ``logic'' in the concept of a resolution after Jan. 15 emphasizing the individual liability of the Iraqi leaders if the allied nations do not wish to go to war immediately. Shevardnadze warned Thursday that Saddam would be held ``personally responsible'' for any use of chemical or biological weapons and breaches of the Fourth Geneva Convention guaranteeing the rights of civilians in time of war. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas emphasized the individual responsibility of Iraq's leaders for war crimes, hinting at instituting a Nuremberg-style tribunal. ``All persons who would be inclined to use biological and chemical weapons will be personally responsible for that act. That means we'll take other measures in that direction,'' Dumas said. ``I think we'll meet in the next day and see what we can do in that direction. It was an agreement among ourselves,'' he aid. The Nuremberg trials of Nazi war criminals, held between 1945-49, were the first time under international law that the leaders of a nation were tried for starting an aggressive war. Nineteen Nazi leaders were sentenced to death by hanging. The Council members have now put Iraq on notice that its leaders will be held liable, the senior U.S. official said. A previous Security Council resolution invites nations to collect evidence of war crimes and submit it to the Council.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Demonstrations in Bangladesh in Defiance of State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people defied state-of-emergency restrictions in Bangladesh's two largest cities Friday, holding mass protests demanding that President Hussein Muhammad Ershad quit, witness accounts said. Security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets at protesters armed with small bombs in Dhaka, the capital, and the port city of Chittagong, according to other unofficial reports reaching India. Government-controlled Bangladesh Radio said five people were killed since Tuesday night when Ershad decreed a state of emergency suspending civil liberties and imposed a curfew. His action followed six weeks of unrest against his government. The official radio, monitored in the eastern Indian city of Calcutta, said two curfew violators were killed by police on Wednesday, and two more people were shot dead in clashes between rival opposition groups the same day. Another was killed Thursday, also in a fight between rival groups, the radio said. Opposition groups said on Thursday that 50 people were killed. Independent verification was unobtainable because of a news blackout enforced by government censorship. Bangladesh Radio accused foreign media of exaggerating the casualty reports. It warned that ``stern action will be taken against any violation of the curfew.'' Opposition parties, supported by university students, demand that Ershad resign in favor of a neutral government to supervise new elections. Ershad, a former army general who seized power in a bloodless 1982 coup, has refused to step aside. Defense analysts and diplomatic sources in India said they believe Ershad could weather the crisis as long as the army remains loyal. There has been no sign of revolt from the military in the latest protests, they said. The curfew was lifted for seven hours Friday to allow people to buy food and attend prayers at mosques on the weekly Islamic holy day. About 10,000 people poured out of mosques in both Dhaka and Chittagong and staged protest marches, despite orders banning rallies or large assemblies. In Chittagong, pro-government crowds burned the office of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party, while govenment troops combed the city center following a bomb attack on one of their vehicles, according to unofficial accounts. No injuries were reported in the bombing. The major opposition parties called for a dawn-to-dusk, nationwide strike on Saturday. Bangladesh Radio reported, meanwhile, that the curfew would be relaxed from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturday in Dhaka, Chittagong and two other cities. In Dhaka, the capital of 7 million people, crowds streamed out of the Baitul Mukarram mosque in the city center, denouncing the state of emergency and hurling bricks and stones at security forces, said witness accounts reaching New Delhi. Most people dispersed when the curfew was resumed at 3 p.m. Police used bamboo staves to beat demonstrators who darted in small groups from side streets to taunt the authorities. Earlier, police smashed batons on a group of 200 women who gathered outside the National Press Club in Dhaka, a favorite spot for public protests. A few male journalists observing the scene also received blows. No reports were available from Khulna and Rajshahi, two other large cities where the curfew was lifted for seven hours. Newspaper editors, who were summoned by a senior official of Ershad's government, refused to suspend an indefinite strike called on Tuesday to protest a decree that all news items about the unrest be submitted for prior censorship. No newspapers have appeared since the emergency was imposed. The latest anti-government campaign began last month when two rival opposition groups, the Bangladesh National Party and the Awami League, called a truce between themselves to challenge Ershad's announcement that he will run for re-election next year. The opposition claims Ershad rigged previous presidential and parliamentary elections. They vowed to boycott the vote called for June unless he resigns. Ershad came to power following a succession of military-installed governments which ruled Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, since it broke away from West Pakistan in a 1971 civil war. Analysts say he has stayed in office by balancing civilian bureaucrats against army generals and frequently shuffling the military command to block the emergence of any power centers within the establishment.

DOC.HEAD: Man Under House Arrest Charged With Murder, Armed Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Samuel Santiago couldn't leave his apartment without setting off an electronic ankle bracelet keeping him under house arrest. But that didn't stop him from committing murder and armed robbery, police said Friday. Santiago, 18, was being held without bond in Cook County Jail on charges that he shot and killed a man one day, and robbed a pizza delivery man at gunpoint the next. Police say the crimes occurred within 100 feet of Santiago's home. The electronic monitoring device attached to Santiago's ankle would have alerted authorities only if he were to go farther than 100 feet from a telephone receiver in his apartment, police said. ``He knew just how far he could go without setting off the alarm,'' said Police Sgt. Ron Rewers. Santiago had served about a year of a three-year prison term for auto theft. Because his record in prison was good, he was assigned to the home monitoring program in October, said Nic Howell, a spokesman for the Illinois corrections department. Authorities say Santiago and Federico Conde, 19, on Monday lured Rudy del Castillo to a passageway outside Santiago's home on the pretense of selling him cocaine. They robbed the 18-year-old victim of several gold chains and about $1,300 in cash and then shot him, Rewers said. Police suspected Santiago in the crime but did not arrest him until the next evening, after he robed a pizza delivery man of $70 and investigators searched his apartment, Rewers said. They also arrested Conde, who was last seen with the shooting victim, and charged him with murder. He was being held in lieu of $270,000 bond, a jail official said. Santiago is the first of 1,800 inmates assigned to home monitoring since June 1989 to be charged with a serious offense, Howell said. Eleven people under home monitoring have been charged with lesser crimes, and only two were convicted, he said. ``We do a lot of watching of these guys. Our concern is for the safety of the public, and we're not going to put someone on this program that we think is going to get into trouble,'' Howell said. ``This one incident should not bear on the rest of the program,'' he said, noting that Illinois prisons already are overcrowded with nearly 10,000 more inmates than the maximum-capacity 18,857. A spokeswoman for Gov. James Thompson also defended the home monitoring program, saying it is necessary to relieve the state's badly overcrowded prisons. ``It's a great system. It's just not a perfect system,'' said spokeswoman Jill Fowler. A recent federal report said Illinois' prison population rose more rapidly than any other state in the nation last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sending Baker to Iraq but Ready for All-Out War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced Friday he's sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Iraq in a last-ditch diplomatic effort to persuade Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait. But the president, armed with a new U.N. resolution authorizing force, also said he's ready to wage war if the mission fails, and with ``enough power to get the job done.'' He declared, ``There will not be any murky ending.'' In addition to sending Baker to meet with Saddam, Bush said he has invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz for a mid-December White House meeting on the Persian Gulf crisis. He said the two-part diplomatic overture was an attempt to present the U.S. case directly to Iraq's leader. ``I hope what it does is demonstrate that we are prepared to go face-to-face and tell him how committed we are to the United Nations resolutions'' insisting Iraqi troops leave occupied Kuwait. Bush, announcing the decision in a statement from the White House briefing room at the opening of a news conference, said Baker's mission would be at a ``mutually convenient time'' between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15. ``It isn't a trip of concession,'' Bush asserted, even though it reverses the administration's previous opposition to sending emissaries to Iraq. There was no immediate word from Baghdad on the development. But the Iraqi Ambassador to France, Abdul Razzack al Hashimi, called Bush's announcement ``a very important step toward peace.'' In an interview with BBC radio, the Iraqi official said, ``We hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for, negotiations instead of beating the drums of war. And this is really, I consider it very good news.'' Bush hailed Thursday's United Nations Security Council vote authorizing force and setting a deadline of Jan. 15 for Iraq's troops to leave Kuwait. ``I remain hopeful that we can achieve a peaceful solution to this crisis. But if force is required, we and the other 26 countries who have troops in the area will have enough power to get the job done,'' he said. The president added that any such battle ``will not be another Vietnam. This will not be a protracted, drawn-out war. ... I pledge to you there will not be any murky ending.'' Bush said he would continue to consult with congressional leaders but had no plans to convene a special session of Congress. Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said the proposed diplomatic contacts would provide ``wiggle room'' for Saddam, and said, ``Anything the president can do to keep the focus of the crisis on diplomacy and not on war is all to the good.'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Bush's opening of a high-level diplomatic channel was a ``positive step.'' ``I think it's another indication that the president wants a peaceable settlement,'' Dole said. Bush defended anew his decision to send 430,000 U.S. troops into the region. ``I want peace, not war. But if there must be a war, we will not permit our troops to have their hands tied behind their backs,'' he said. The president removed his glasses and his eyes were moist as he was asked if, as a father of four children, he felt the need to drive Iraq from Kuwait was important enough to ask parents to sacrifice the lives of sons and daughters in the armed services. ``People say to me, how many lives? How many lives can you expend? Each one is precious. ... I know what it's like to have fallen comrades and see young kids die in battle,'' he said. But, he added, if a shot is fired in anger, ``I want to guarantee each person that their kid, whose life is in harm's way, will have the maximum support, will have their best chance to come home alive, and will be backed up to the hilt.'' In the past, administration officials have opposed the sending of emissaries to Baghdad to meet with Saddam, and Bush was asked what made him change his mind. ``The United Nations resolution I think has a good chance of making Saddam Hussein understand what it is he's up against. I have not felt that he got the message. ... So it's just going the extra step, that's what it is. and it's a decision that I personally made.'' Bush said that his own meeting with Aziz, Iraq's foreign minister, would occur the week of Dec. 10 and that he would also invite foreign ministers from U.S. allies in the gulf to attend. He said he - and Baker at the later meeting with Saddam - ``will be prepared ... to discuss all aspects of the gulf crisis.'' A number of Democrats - and some Republicans - in Congress have criticized Bush's gulf policy, and former military officials also have questioned his Mideast buildup in hearings that continued Friday. But Bush said if Congress wanted a special session, it would have to call one itself. ``They have the power ... to come back 20 seconds from now,'' he said. ``If they want to come back here and endorse what the president of the United States has done and what the United Nations Secrity Council has done, come on, we're ready,'' he said. After his news conference, Bush telephoned Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Turkey's President Turgot Ozal and the exiled emir of Kuwait. Asked their reaction to his announcement, he said later, ``It's all been very very positive.'' In his speech and news conference afterward, Bush also: - Disclosed that Iraqis have recently appeared unexpectedly at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait with deliveries of cigarettes, fruits and vegetables. He said he understood there would be another delivery on Saturday including soft drinks. - Disputed critics who have minimized the potential Iraqi nuclear threat, saying ``I am not going to err on the side of underestimation.''

DOC.HEAD: How Much Does A Seat on A Soviet Space Capsule Cost?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-13, `TBS is ...' to restore dropped first name of Kaifu and to correct height of rocket to 161 feet; Picks up 14th graf, `The deputy ...'
DOC.TEXT: Next to the two front seats in the cramped Soviet space capsule heading into orbit Sunday is an extra chair that's turning out to be the Kremlin's ticket to cosmic profits. The seat on the Soyuz capsule has held pure, space-grown crystals worth millions of dollars and valuable products of space experiments, as well as cosmonauts from other countries. On Sunday, the seat will carry the first journalist - and first Japanese - to space under a commercial agreement that officials hope will turn new profits for the Soviet space program. Toyohiro Akiyama, of Japan's biggest television company TBS, will ride on the Soyuz TM-11 under a contract between the company and the Soviet Union. The network is paying about $11 million for the honor, and is working out other agreements with agencies that are emerging as profit-making arms of the Soviet space industry. The flight is part of a push to make the Soviet space program more self-sufficient, as the United States also has tried to do. An overburdened national budget and a critically ailing economy have put tremendous pressure on Soviet officials. Last year, they suspended the Soyuz flights and left the orbiting Mir space station unoccupied for four months to save money. The eight-day Soyuz TM-11 flight will be the eighth to hook up with the Mir space station since it was put up in 1986. Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Victor Afanasyev have been designated to replace Gennady Manakov and Gennady Strekalov in the Mir, while Akiyama delivers live, exclusive radio and TV reports of his experience. Although Soviet scientists and 14 foreign astronauts have ridden in the third seat, Akiyama will be the first non-scientific, paying passenger. He is scheduled to conduct experiments on Japanese Tree Frogs, an idea proposed by the Japanese to see how they cope in the gravity-free environment. Back on Earth, he'll deliver speeches and travel to talk about the experience, which TBS has billed as a celebration of its 40th year on the air. TBS is sending about 120 reporters, cameramen and technicians to document the flight from Baikonur Cosmodrome, a once-secret complex 1,560 miles from Moscow in the Kazakhstan desert. At least one top official, a former aide to Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, will also witness the midday launch. On Friday, the 161-foot-tall Soyuz rocket was rolled out to the launch pad in front of Soviet, Japanese and other foreign journalists. Scores of space technicians, in black coveralls and orange helmets, scurried around the rocket to raise it to a standing position and prepare it for liftoff. The deputy chief of testing, Maj. Gen. Alexei A. Shumilin, told reporters the flight will have great political significance by setting a precedent for Soviet cooperation with other countries. ``The flight will make a profit, although we are not sure how much,'' he said. ``But interest in this launch ... will give us a chance to see how profitable the flights can be.'' Standing in below-freezing weather, the Soyuz rocket stood tall on the launch pad at the 35-year-old space complex, opened over two years ago to foreign visitors. The complex, where most Soviet satellites and spaceships are launched, is also the site of the country's worst space disasters, including an explosion that destroyed a satellite just seconds after liftoff in early October. The Japanese government has no official connection with Sunday's launch, a TBS official in Baikonur said. But, executive producer Ichiro Sasaki said: ``the Japanese people will have a better understanding of this country ... and we hope the Soviets will understand us better.'' TBS has declined to officially say how much Akiyama's space flight is costing them, but Sasaki confirmed that the amount is roughly $11 million, the figure quoted in the media. He said disarray in the Soviet space industry, caused by economic reforms and government restructuring, has complicated the joint project. ``This is one of their (the space industry's) first attempts at business with foreigners, but they are still using Soviet ways of doing business,'' Sasaki said. The Soviets now are talking with China, Spain, Turkey and Iran to send up paying passengers. Britain, Austria, Germany and France already are planning to pay for seats on a Soviet capsule, according to U.S. space expert James Oberg.

DOC.HEAD: Drought Reveals Old California Town Site Flooded To Create Lake
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: An old bridge has risen from the water as the inundated town of Monticello re-emerges from a man-made lake that's receding after four years of drought. With each dry day, receding Lake Berryessa reveals more remains of the town, once a thriving farming community before the government claimed it for a dam and reservoir in the 1950s. ``There was almost nothing left when they got through,'' remembered Harold Moskowitz, 64, who was raised in Monticello and now lives near the dwindling lake. ``They paid us off, gave buildings away, tore some down and burned some. What they couldn't burn they buried. ``The only thing left would be some streets and foundations. They didn't leave anything over 6 inches high, even the trees. It was a sad thing to lose that town.'' Now, hundreds of tourists and former residents are trekking to the lake, about 50 miles northeast of San Francisco, to glimpse the past and remember the town's century of life. ``I was born in the valley and was about 10 years old when it went under,'' said Ronnie McGuinnis, a maintenance worker for the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, which manages the lake and recreational area. ``I think people are coming back because they are still distressed and remember being uprooted. They couldn't believe it was possible that this gigantic government could come in a tell them to get out. It's almost like we were Indians and they wanted our land.'' The valley originally was inhabited by Indians - Pomo, Miwok and Wappo tribes - who retreated as Europeans settled. The valley and lake were named for Jose and Sisto Berryessa, brothers from Spain who began the La Putas Rancho in 1943 in the area soon known for raising grain and cattle. About 500 people lived in the valley but dwindled to about 125 by the 1950s when water was getting scarce as Northern California grew. The federal government formed a plan with Solano County to dam Putah River to create a reservoir in the valley, which sits mostly in adjacent Napa County. The 1,000-foot-long, 304-foot-high Monticello Dam created a reservoir that supplies Solano County and serves as a for seven resorts. Berryessa normally is three miles across at its widest point and 26 miles long, but is about one-third that size after losing 60 percent of its water. This week, the lake surface fell to 377 feet above sea level - nearly 12 feet lower than during the drought of 1976-77 and 63 feet below normal. The average 30 inches of rain a year at Berryessa has dropped by half since the 1986 floods, causing the lake level to fall 15-20 feet annually. ``If it doesn't rain, this lake could dry up in a few years, then you'll really get to see the whole town,'' said Jim Peterson, maintenance foreman for the reclamation bureau. Downtown Monticello remains under 50 to 60 feet of water, but outlying areas are being revealed as the lake dries up - a foundation here, an old swimming pool there along with sunken boats, motors, fishing poles and tennis shoes. Indian artifacts also have been found. Roads unused for three decades have fresh tire tracks from explorers while a 1941 bridge, under water until this summer, is marked by muddy footprints as the span sits 6 feet above the lake's surface. ``People can walk across if they want, but it doesn't go anywhere,'' Peterson said. ``For some reason, though, we're getting a lot of visitors even though there's not much to see except a few concrete slabs.'' Park ranger Arnold Roessler, who's busy these days telling visitors how to find the emerging bits of the past, said people are searching for more. ``It's too bad about the drought, but some people are hoping that it continues just so we can see what's really down there,'' said ranger Arnold Roessler. ``It's like a developing mystery.''

DOC.HEAD: China's Envoy Meets with Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met Friday with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and said differences over human rights continue to affect relations with Beijing 18 months after the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. Bush also said there are ``many positive and very important aspects'' in relations between the two countries. It was Qian's first visit to Washington since China snuffed out the pro-democracy movement at Tiananmen Square in June 1989. Qian spent more than two hours with Secretary of State James A. Baker III before calling on Bush at the White House. ``I think the Chinese government knows we have some differences on this whole broad question of human rights,'' Bush said as he and Qian posed for photographers. ``But we have many things in common.'' ``One purpose of this kind of meeting is to reduce the differences,'' Bush said. He said the U.S. government has a ``very frank relationship'' with Qian and the ability to discuss differences openly. Qian offered no public remarks, but on Thursday a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing said he felt that any discussion of human rights at Friday's meetings was inappropriate interference in China's internal affairs. Qian came here from New York, where he cast an abstention Thursday on the Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. State Department officials were surprised and disappointed because Chinese officials had led them to believe that Qian would support the resolution. Nonetheless, Bush praised China's willingness to ``stand up to aggression'' by Iraq in Kuwait, an apparent reference to China's support for all previous Security Council resolutions on Iraq. For unexplained reasons, the State Department announced the Bush-Qian meeting Friday morning, then indicated it had been cancelled. But Qian turned up at the White House at the time initially announced by the State Department and spent a little more than a half hour with Bush. In announcing Qian's visit here, the State Department insisted that the administration's policy of no high-level exchanges with China was still in effect. Officials pointed out that Baker has met with Qian three times in New York and once each in Cairo and Paris. The State Department explained that ``contacts'' with Chinese officials are permitted but not ``large ceremonial exchanges.'' That prohibition was imposed after Chinese authorities unleashed military forces against the Tiananmen Square demonstrators. Military sales also are banned. As a permanent member of the Security Council, China has been deeply involved in Persian Gulf diplomacy, enabling it to overcome somewhat the relative diplomatic isolation it experienced in the aftermath of the suppression of the Tiananmen Square movement.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Blames Resolution on U.S. `Terror'; Bush Makes Diplomatic Move
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Oil prices ...' to UPDATE oil prices; INSERTS 1 graf after 20th graf, ``I am ...' with Saudi-Kuwaiti reax; ADDS 4 grafs with Iraqis taking goods to U.S. Embassy in Kuwait.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHR4,5, DHG1,3
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday blamed passage of the U.N. use-of-force resolution on ``pressure, terrorism and bribes'' from Washington. President Bush made a surprise diplomatic overture to Saddam Hussein but also issued a warning. If military conflict does break out, Bush said, ``it will not be another Vietnam, this will not be another protracted, drawn-out war.'' In the fourth day of Senate hearings on the Persian Gulf crisis, a former U.S. intelligence official urged Washington not to rush toward war with Iraq. Oil prices tumbled more than $3 a barrel - to $29.90 - on the New York Mercantile Exchange after Bush suggested sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad to seek an end to the crisis. Before Bush's remarks cooled temperatures, Saddam's ruling Revolutionary Command Council called the U.N. Security Council resolution passed Thursday ``illegal, null and void,'' saying it was imposed by the United States. ``It is first and foremost an American decision in which certain powers participated only under American pressure,'' it said. ``The United States practiced all forms of pressure, terrorism and bribes'' to pass the measure. The statement, broadcast on state-run Baghdad Radio, said that if forced to fight, Iraq would teach the United States and its allies a ``hard lesson, unprecedented in history.'' The U.N. resolution authorizes the United States and its allies to use force to drive Iraq from Kuwait unless Saddam withdraws his troops by Jan. 15. Iraq invaded the emirate on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. In a nationally televised speech, Bush said he was willing to send Baker to Baghdad to negotiate Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. If Iraq agrees, Baker would travel to Baghdad between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, Bush said. Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, would be welcome in Washington for talks the week of Dec. 10, he said. Bush said he was ``going the extra mile'' for peace. The move does not mean, however, the United States is waivering in its demand for a total Iraqi withdrawal, restoration of the Kuwaiti government and release of all Western hostages from Iraq and Kuwait, Bush said. The surprise diplomatic olive branch, however, was combined with a stern new warning for Saddam. ``I promise you there will not be any murky ending. I will never agree to a halfway effort,'' Bush said. ``I don't think there has ever been a question that the United States is going to blink.'' Iraq's leadership was taken by surprise by Bush's announcement and immediately went into a meeting for consultations, diplomats said in Baghdad. There were no immediate details on who attended the meeting. But there was reaction to the proposed Baker visit from Abdul Razzack al Hashimi, Iraq's ambassador to France, who spoke in an interview in Paris with the British Broadcasting Corp. ``This is a very important step, really, toward peace, and we hope it is going to achieve what we are all striving for, negotiations instead of beating the drums of war. ... I consider it very good news,'' he said. ``Let's wait and see, and let's be optimistic, and see what Mr. Baker has in mind, and not to speculate about such an important event.'' At the United Nations, Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar welcomed Bush's call for diplomatic contact with Iraq. ``I am persuaded that if these contacts take place, they will be really, really leading to a peaceful solution,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters. And in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabian and exiled Kuwaiti officials applauded Bush's last-ditch effort. Bush's diplomatic move came amid growing criticism on Capitol Hill for the Bush administration's gulf policy. During the week, a series of witnesses, including two former Joint Chiefs of Staff, have underscored doubts among Democratic senators about going to war with Iraq. On Friday, retired Lt. Gen. William E. Odom, who headed the National Security Agency during the Reagan administration, said Washington should continue its present defensive posture rather than wage war with Iraq. He said that attacking Iraqi forces in Kuwait - or Iraq itself - could mean a long U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf region. About 240,000 U.S. troops are deployed in Saudi Arabia as part of the 340,000-strong multinational force arrayed against Iraq. Bush has promised to add 200,000 more to the largest deployment abroad since the Vietnam war. The multinational force faces 430,000 Iraqi troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait. In an another apparent conciliatory move Friday, a group of Iraqis took fruit, vegetables and a case of cigarettes to the besieged American Embassy in Kuwait, Bush said. The Americans were also told by the Iraqis, who were not identified, to make a list of medical supplies they needed, he said. ``This could be a positive sign,'' Bush said. Shortly after the invasion, Saddam ordered all missions closed in Kuwait, which Iraq considers its 19th province. The embassies that refused to shut were surrounded by troops and utilities were cut. Only the U.S. and British embassies still remain open, but with much-reduced staffs. At the U.S. Embassy, the eight remaining personnel have been surviving on canned tuna and rice, Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Message Perceived Differently in East and West
DOC.TEXT: They've been seeing the same posters and hearing the same speeches, but the campaign for Sunday's all-German elections strikes different chords among voters east and west. For former West Germans, the candidates are familiar, the vote itself routine and the major issue is just how severe the expected tax increases to finance unity will be. In what used to be East Germany, the plethora of parties ranging from the right-wing Republicans to the leftist Greens is still a novelty for voters who lived in a one-party Communist state. Eastern Germans need help in rebuilding their shattered economy, and are looking for the best leaders to do it. ``The elections are important for the future development of East Germany,'' said Bodo Hahnet, director of a job retraining program in Potsdam. A voice from former West Germany puts it differently. ``These elections aren't so important. They won't change anything,'' said Helmut Hilbig, a doctor from the Ruhr industrial area city of Moenchengladbach. Just over a year ago, Hahnet and Hilbig lived in separate worlds in separate countries. Now they are part of a pool of 60 million German voters to go to the polls Sunday, 12 million in the five new states in eastern Germany and 48 million from former West Germany. They will choose a 656-member Parliament and a new chancellor in the first free elections in a united Germany since 1932. Helmut Kohl, the incumbent chancellor who guided the two German states to unity after the Berlin Wall collapsed on Nov. 9, 1989, is the clear favorite. His campaign workers have slathered the country with large portraits of the beefy, prosperous-looking leader that simply proclaims: ``Chancellor for Germany.'' That image is appealing in eastern Germany where Kohl is more popular than among his countrymen in the west, who are sometimes embarrassed by the chancellor's folksy ways. A recent poll in the weekly Der Spiegel magazine showed that 20 percent of eastern Germans thought Kohl was the greatest postwar chancellor against 10 percent of western Germans. Overall, Kohl's reception at campaign rallies in eastern Germany has been warmer than in the west. Supporters of Oskar Lafontaine, Kohl's Social Democratic rival have also been busy bringing the image of the youthful challenger to voters. Lafontaine, 47, stands among a group of young people, peering off into the distance under the slogan: ``The new way'' in his main poster. Many eastern Germans just seem to want a way that works. For Hilbig, the western German, Kohl and Lafontaine are old faces on a familiar political scene. But even though he doesn't expect much to change as a result of the election, he expects unification to have a serious impact on his income. ``We're going to end up paying like crazy,'' he said, a reference to expected tax increases needed to bring the backward east up to the standards of the west. Talks with other western Germans at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin revealed similar concerns about the country's finances. Kohl, portraying himself as the kind of solid, hardworking leader who can bring western prosperity to the east, says no new taxes will be needed. Nonsense, argues Lafontaine, who has pounded away with charges of hypocrisy. He says the Christian Democrats have deceived voters by underestimating the real costs of unity. ``Nobody is telling the truth,'' growled Hahnet, the eastern German. ``The Christian Democrats don't really say what is happening.'' Politicians from the broad palette of opposition parties have a lot to say, but many are so small their voices get lost despite access for all parties to television. The Free Democrats are counting on Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to pull in votes in his native eastern Germany where he is extremely popular. Other parties push platforms rather than people, with the Greens for ecology and the right-wing Republicans for restricting asylum rules. Although the messages differ, for the first time in 58 years Germans will choose freely their leaders in a safe and secure democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Regulator Says Deconcini Acted Improperly, But Not Other Four
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs to UPDATE, picks up 11th graf pvs, `All the...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. thrift regulator testified Friday that Sen. Dennis DeConcini broke the bounds of propriety - but four other senators did not - when they intervened on behalf of savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. Regulator Michael Patriarca, addressing the Senate Ethics Committee, drew the line between the behavior of DeConcini, D-Ariz. and four colleagues: John McCain, R-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Patriarca said it was wrong for a senator to attempt to ``influence, to change the outcome'' of an examination that was highly critical of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. ``My personal view is Senator DeConcini did that,'' he said. ``It's not clear to me that any of the others did.'' The regulator was referring to the senators' conduct at an April 9, 1987 meeting with four San Francisco-based regulators - including Patriarca - who were responsible for the Lincoln investigation. Patriarca also said he would fault the senators generally, because they ``appeared to have made up their minds in advance'' that Keating was right and the regulators were wrong in finding serious problems at Lincoln. Patriarca's two days of testimony backed the assertion of his ex-boss, former Federal Home Loan Bank Board Chairman Edwin J. Gray, that DeConcini took the lead in trying to negotiate a deal on Keating's behalf. DeConcini denied that he sought a waiver for Lincoln of a rule prohibiting risky investments, in return for the thrift establishing a home mortgage loan program. Patriarca was questioned by Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., one of six Ethics Committee members who will judge whether the five senators improperly intervened for Keating. Keating and associates donated $1.3 million to the campaigns and political causes of the five senators. The committee has held nine days of hearings in an effort to determine whether the money influenced the intervention. The hearing adjourned until Monday after a former member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board testified he received calls from Cranston and DeConcini in April 1989 - immediately before the government takeover of Lincoln. In those calls, said Roger Martin, both senators urged the board to approve a sale of Lincoln rather than its seizure. The requests were rejected. All the senators except Riegle met on Keating's behalf with Gray on April 2, 1987 in DeConcini's office. When the chief regulator said he lacked details of the Lincoln investigation, the four San Francisco-based regulators including Patriarca, were summoned to the April 9 meeting. That also was in DeConcini's office and this time Riegle joined the group. Rudman asked Patriarca whether he thought DeConcini was ``out of line'' in the April 9 meeting, when he sought the waiver for Lincoln. ``Yes I did, senator,'' the regulator responded. He said that the proper way to challenge the regulation was through the courts and Lincoln ``had a retainer with every significant law firm in the country'' to do so. Lincoln in fact did, shortly before the meetings with regulators, file a court suit challenging the rule. The suit was not successful. Patriarca said McCain showed the ``least prejudice'' toward regulators at the April 9 meeting; DeConcini and ``perhaps Sen. Glenn seemed to have their minds made up pretty substantially'' and Riegle was ``in the middle.'' Another member of the committee, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., asked if the senators were hostile at the meeting. ``I think it was hostile,'' Patriarca said. ``We were being dressed down.'' Helms then asked whether the senators expressed ``surprise or shock'' after the regulators informed them that serious problems - and possible criminality - were found at Lincoln, of Irvine, Calif. ``We didn't seem to be getting through to the senators,'' the regulator said. ``They did not seem to appreciate the seriousness of the situation that we were trying to convey to them.'' On Thursday, Patriarca said the senators became less aggressive when regulators said they would make criminal referrals to the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: Browning Says Yes to Quake; Ted the Rooster Says No
DOC.TEXT: Iben Browning gets all the attention, but he isn't the only one with notions about when a big earthquake will shake the Midwest. Ted the Rooster says it won't happen next week. Raymond Cole's radio says it might. Browning's theory that a quake is likely along the New Madrid Fault zone early next week has sent emotional shock waves from Illinois to Arkansas. The uproar also brought new popularity to backyard prophets who base their predictions on such things as lost dogs, radio waves and a prognosticating rooster. The attempts to predict an earthquake have one thing in common - scientists say they are worthless. ``Earthquakes are unpredictable,'' said Jill Stevens, spokeswoman for the Center for Earthquake Research and Information at Memphis (Tenn.) State University. ``They are one of the most mysterious natural events we have to deal with.'' Scientists have searched unsuccessfully for decades for reliable signs that a temblor is due. The public is eager to join the hunt, Ms. Stevens said. ``Every year we hear from people with pet theories about earthquakes,'' Ms. Stevens said. ``One woman in Ohio says she has a television set that gets different patterns of `snow' before an earthquake,'' she said. ``There's a woman in Memphis who monitors the classified ads to see if the number of lost pets is up because she thinks that means a quake is coming.'' She said the number of people calling the center to offer or seek advice has skyrocketed since Browning, a self-proclaimed climatologist from New Mexico, projected of a 50-50 chance for a Midwest quake around Dec. 3. Browning, 72, bases his theory on the gravitational pull of the sun and moon, which he says will be particularly strong during the period. Ted the rooster is getting a lot of calls, too. The rooster, locally famous for forecasting weather and the outcome of presidential elections, says there will be no earthquake, according to his owner, Dick Frymire of Irvington, Ky. ``I've had hundreds of calls about it from all over the United States,'' Frymire said. ``People are scared to death.'' Raymond Cole of Cape Girardeau, Mo., makes his quake predictions by charting slight changes in the location of AM signals on his radio dial. He believes The Big One is coming soon. Because of interest stirred by Browning, Cole makes his forecasts available free 24 hours a day on a special phone line connected to an answering machine at his home. ``That answering machine goes constantly, as fast as it can rewind,'' Cole said. ``I've worn out four tapes in two months.'' Ms. Stevens said quake quackery is fueled by scientists' inability to predict earthquakes, combined with the accepted theory that a damaging quake will someday occur along the New Madrid. The fault, which stretches from New Madrid, Mo., to Marked Tree, Ark., produces numerous quakes a year, including huge temblors in 1811 and 1812. The best scientists can do is chart probabilities based on statistical analysis of seismic activity along the fault since 1811, she said. And even those methods are uncertain. A widely quoted study done at the Memphis center puts the probability of an earthquake of magnitude 6.3 or greater on the Richter scale within the next 15 years at between 40 percent and 63 percent. An independent study released this year by two scientists who work with the U.S. Geological Survey put the risk lower - setting a 13 percent probability of a New Madrid quake of 6.0 or greater within the next 10 years. ``Both are valid scientific studies using different methods,'' Ms. Stevens said. Still, people along the fault are listening to the predictions. Among them is Austin Peay State University geology professor D.M.S. Bhatia, who is setting up camp along the fault with 25 students to prove Browning wrong. ``We're going to jump up and down on the fault and show there's no reason for all this panic,'' said Bhatia.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Military Goods in South Korea Being Resold on Black Market
DOC.TEXT: Need some oxtail meat? A bottle of Chivas Regal? Or how about hair spray? South Korea is a good place to get them, courtesy of Uncle Sam. A report by the General Accounting Office has found widespread black marketing of goods sold to U.S. military personnel and their dependents at duty-free stores and commissaries in South Korea. A ration control system set up to prevent the goods from being resold on the black market has failed, according to the report by the congressional watchdog agency. The system, it said, costs $12 million annually. Investigators said they could not put a dollar figure on the amount of goods diverted to the black market, but said sales rates for many items could not be accounted for simply by the estimated 70,000 people authorized to buy them. For example, during fiscal year 1989, Army and Air Force commissaries in South Korea received about 1.2 million pounds of oxtail meat for sale. That means about 16 pounds for every woman, man and child authorized to buy commissary items. And while oxtail meat is not a staple in Americans' diet, it's a popular Korean dish used especially in soup. Chivas Regal Scotch, especially 12-year-old bottles, is also a popular item in South Korea, the report found. The investigators compared Chivas sales among U.S. military personnel in Europe and South Korea. While the number of U.S. military personnel in South Korea was only 15 percent that in Europe, commissaries and stores sold more than six times as many bottles. Aqua Net hair spray is also popular - 33 cans per authorized females. Some of the black market sales are conducted by service personnel, others by South Korean employees at U.S. stores and commissaries. Most of the items are paid for and then sold at two or three times the price on the black market. High-ticket items, such as refrigerators and video recorders, diverted to the black market are often obtained with falsified ration cards, the report said. Yet despite the widespread problem, only 66 military personnel were court-martialed for black market abuses in 1988, and an unknown number of others received less serious penalties, the report said. It recommended that the Department of Defense improve the ration control system and encourage the South Korean government to crack down on black marketeers.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Parliaments to Meet to Show `Common Will' to Kremlin
With AM-Soviet-Food Aid, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The parliaments of the three Baltic republics prepared to hold their first joint session Saturday to show a unified front against recent threats from the Soviet government. In an interview, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said the Baltics want their unity of position to be seen ``not only in the form of declarations and documents but in the meeting of lawmakers.'' The parliaments of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were to meet in Vilnius to discuss tough statements by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Defense Minister Dmitry Yazov concerning the Baltics' independence drives. On Friday, talks were held in Moscow between Soviet and Lithuanian representatives on resolving an impasse that began March 11, when the parliament of the Baltic republic declared independence. The talks, however, were unsuccessful, Deputy Lithuanian Prime Minister Romualdus Ozolas told the Baltic News Service. ``Our position is based on international law, and the position of the Soviet side is based on Soviet laws. And our positions are so different, that we could not reach a common formula,'' he said. Ozolas and Soviet Deputy Premier Vitaly Doguzhiyev were unable to set an agenda for more detailed talks, but they did agree to meet next week, according to the Lithuanian news agency, ELTA. Accepting an invitation from Landsbergis, the 220 members of the Lithuanian parliament were to meet with about 200 Latvian and 100 Estonian legislators in the Lithuanian capital. Leaders of all three republics say they will refuse to sign Gorbachev's proposed Union Treaty to unite the 15 Soviet republics and grant broad economic and national security authority to the Gorbachev government. Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Russian Federation - the largest Soviet republic - also refuses to sign the Union Treaty until the republics can assert political autonomy and control over their economic affairs. One Lithuanian official said the Union Treaty was doomed. Algirdas Brazauskas, a deputy prime minister of the republic who also heads the branch of the Lithuanian Communist Party that split with the Soviet Communist Party nearly a year ago, said: ``I think that the Union Treaty will not succeed because it is too conservative. It preserves the current political structure of the Soviet Union and gives too little to the republics.'' ``Lithuania must be independent or at least be a member of the (Soviet) Union by its own choice. That's a minimum,'' Brazauskas said. Mindful of the economic blockade Gorbachev slapped on Lithuania for its independence drive last summer, leaders of Latvia and Estonia have been more cautious. The Estonian Parliament at first balked at taking part in the joint legislative session, the Estonian News Agency ETA reported. But the republic's Parliament voted Friday to send its senior leaders, committee chairmen and other lawmakers to the meeting, ETA reported. Soviet leaders have taken a tough stand against secessionist republics. A week ago, Gorbachev revived his demand that republics wishing to secede must first hold referendums. And Yazov, his defense minister, warned that Soviet soldiers would fire on demonstrators who attack defense installations. Gorbachev and Yazov also warned civilian authorities not to deny social benefits to Soviet soldiers. The warning appeared in part a response to an incident in Vilnius in mid-November in which Soviet soldiers fired over the heads of peaceful demonstrators, said Rita Dapkus, a Lithuanian parliament spokeswoman. Tensions also seemed to be rising over the redeployment in Lithuania of Soviet army units withdrawing from Eastern Europe, Dapkus said. ``Moscow has to understand it cannot just bring in people and demand housing, and not ask or even inform us,'' Dapkus said. Lithuania faces a severe housing shortage for its own citizens. Many Lithuanians fear a military crackdown, although Landsbergis said such action would damage Gorbachev's worldwide prestige as he seeks food and other aid for Moscow and hard-pressed Soviet cities. ``The use of open military force is less of a threat because Mr. Gorbachev is still under the pressure of the international situation,'' Landsbergis said.

DOC.HEAD: Record 28,000 Soviet Jews Arrived In November
DOC.TEXT: A record 28,000 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel in November, up 8,000 from the previous high, a senior Israeli immigration official said Friday. The November influx brought to 150,000 the number of Soviet Jewish immigrants this year. Immigration officials have said that more than 1 million Soviet Jews could arrive by the end of 1992. Simcha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency which brings immigrants to Israel, said 1.2 million Soviet Jews have won approval to leave the Soviet Union. There are no direct flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv, but Dinitz said that even the more cumbersome routes via Warsaw, Budapest and Bucharest could handle 50,000 immigrants a month. The immigration is causing a strain in unemployment, housing and government finances in Israel. In the 1991 state budget approved by the government this week, Israel has set aside $6.5 billion for immigrant absorption. Dinitz estimated it would cost about $35 billion to absorb 1 million Soviet immigrants, and said Israel and the world Jewish community could not carry the burden alone. ``Israel will have to turn to other countries and foreign sources for assistance,'' Dinitiz told industrialists in Tel Aviv on Friday. He said a record 30,000 immigrants from around the world arrived in November, including 28,000 from the Soviet Union. The previous high was in October when 21,000 immigrants came, including 20,000 Soviet Jews. The total number of immigrants from around the world has reached 164,500 so far this year.

DOC.HEAD: Army to Fire Propaganda From Cannons in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Army plans tests in Saudi Arabia of cannon shells that can carry thousands printed messages, a Dugway Proving Ground official said. Each shell, called an XM951 projectile, can be programmed to eject as many as 10,000 messages over a populated area before continuing its flight - which can extend 14 miles - to land in an unpopulated area, project officer John Slater said Thursday. Tests have been going on for nearly two years and have been successful, Slater said. Similar devices were used during the Vietnam War, he said. ``These rounds will primarily be used by Army Special Forces specializing in propaganda operations,'' he said. ``They are designed to be shot into enemy territory and leave a predetermined propaganda message to those behind the lines.''

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Named To Head War On Drugs
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON - President Bush on Friday named outgoing Florida Gov. Bob Martinez to head the nation's war on drugs, selecting a politician who stressed law enforcement in fighting his own state's skyrocketing drug crimes. In announcing his choice for director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, Bush said he was giving Martinez ``a battlefield promotion for a leader who has earned his stripes on the front lines of the drug war. ``Governor Martinez can and will hit the ground running,'' Bush added. In his four years as governor, Martinez's high-profile anti-drug policies emphasized tough penalties, law enforcement and prison construction over treatment and prevention. Meanwhile, drug crimes escalated significantly during his tenure. But Bush praised him as an effective leader in the war on drugs. ``He's been contributing to our national drug control strategy for over two years,'' Bush said. ``He stiffened the Florida code and then added the prison space to enforce it... As a governor who signed more than 130 death warrants he understands tough choices,'' Bush said. If confirmed by the Senate, Martinez will replace William Bennett, the outspoken conservative who has served as ``drug czar'' for 19 months and now is Bush's choice to head the Republican National Committee. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said he was disappointed that Bush selected Martinez but promised to hold confirmation hearings shortly after Congress convenes in January. ``Mr. Martinez lacks the background and record to suggest that he is well-suited for this task,'' Biden said. He said he looks forward to a debate with Martinez on administration policies and whether he is willing to try new approaches. Martinez is expected to bring a more businesslike approach to the job than Bennett, who was noted for his feisty, bully-pulpit rhetoric in bringing national focus on the drug crisis. Martinez told reporters he will continue to emphasize tough enforcement measures. ``The balance is always being debated,'' between enforcement and treatment and prevention dollars, he said. Bush's choice ofMartinez, who lost his re-election bid this month to Democratic former Sen. Lawton Chiles, prompted criticism from some quarters that the president was more interested in giving his friend a job than choosing the best qualified person. Bush and his wife Barbara made several campaign appearances for Martinez in the tightly contested race and Bush's Florida-resident son Jeb Bush served as the governor's campaign chairman. Martinez ``has a great resume when it comes to politics,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, Democratic chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics. ``What experience does he have that qualified him directly and specifically for the post of national drug policy coordinator?'' The Drug Policy Foundation, a non-profit organization, alleged that Bush showed ``he would rather reward his political buddies than solve the drug abuse problem in the United States.'' ``After four years of Martinez' leadership, Florida is awash with drugs, crime, corruption and violence,'' said the organization's president, Arnold Trebach. Martinez, a former mayor of Tampa, became governor in 1987 as Florida's involvement with drug trafficking was escalating and the crack cocaine epidemic became rampant. The number of people imprisoned for drug crimes doubled during Martinez' tenure, to 16,169 in the 1989-90 fiscal year, according to state Department of Correction figures. Overall, drug crimes jumped from close to 57,000 in 1986 to 85,525 in 1989. THe first six months of 1990 had 37,474 drug crimes compared to 32,962 in the first six months of 1989. Martinez advocated drug testing for government employees, and took a test himself to show that he was drug free. He pushed through the legislature laws mandating the death penalty for drug kingpins in certain cases and requiring tougher penalties for drug dealers who traffic near schools. He is chairman of the National Governors Association task force on substance abuse and drug trafficking. He visited Bolivia and Colombia in 1988 with the National Guard on a drug fact-finding mission. While Democrats criticized Martinez for embarking on a huge prison building program, the governor has noted that spending on substance abuse treatment rose from $43 million in 1985-86 to almost $92 million. In a report released earlier this month, Bennett's office listed Florida seventh in the nation on spending per capita for drug treatment. During the gubernatorial campaign, Chiles called Martinez's prison construction program ``a primitive approach'' to the drug problem. ``There are thousands of people on waiting lists for drug treatment and the need far outstrips any programs currently in place,'' Chiles said. Chiles has since said he supports Martinez as drug czar.

DOC.HEAD: `It Is a Tough Question,' Says the President
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: George Bush got the body bag question at his news conference Friday. How many kids would you be willing to have die in the Persian Gulf, Mr. President? Body bags - a fact of war, a Vietnam residue, the black plastic containers into which a corpse is zippered at the battlefield for transfer into a reusable metal case in the first step toward burial at home. Along with the soft drinks, along with the gas masks, the rations, the videos, the paperbacks, the sunglasses and the ammunition that America is shipping to its troops in the desert, body bags are being loaded aboard the transports. ``We all know,'' Bush's questioner said, ``how important your children are to you. Do you feel that this issue is important enough to you that you could conceive of giving up one of their lives for it?'' It was the between-the-eyes question that any president must dread when he is about to put lives at risk, whatever the cause. The question confronts the country now that the U.N., at Bush's request, has set a deadline for Saddam Hussein to pull out of Kuwait. Bush sighed. He grasped the lectern. He fidgeted. He gestured with his glasses. He talked slowly. He spent a few minutes with this question. He said people have asked before: ``People say to me, `How many lives, how many lives can you expend?''' ``It's only the president that should be asked to make the decision, is it worth it? How many lives is it worth? Is it worth it to commit one life, put one life in harm's way to achieve these objectives?'' Somberly he continued in a rambling discourse: -He knows the horror of war; he has been in war. -Every life is precious. If there is a war, he has ordered maximum firepower to be applied to protect the lives of Americans in combat. -Saddam Hussein can avoid war by complying with U.N. demands. -But is it worth the loss of life? ``It's a tough question,'' the president said, but ``these are worldwide principles of moral importance.'' How many lives? Experts make their gulf estimates from past wars and the situation on the ground. The estimates vary widely. On the record, the Pentagon will not say how many American lives it anticipates would be expended to achieve U.S. objectives in a war with Iraq. At a news briefing Thursday, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams repeatedly refused to provide a projection. ``I would dispute anyone's ability now to accurately predict casualties without knowing what the scenario is.'' The New York Times, citing Pentagon sources, reported on Tuesday that ``several thousand'' American deaths would be likely over several weeks of an all-out war. Retired Gen. George Crist, on CBS News, said about 1,000 U.S. soldiers would be killed on the first day. Retired Col. Trevor Dupuy told CBS that casualties would range between 6,000 and 16,000 over the first 10 days of war, but did not differentiate between dead and injured. Retired Adm. Gene LaRocque, director of the Center for Defense Information and an outspoken opponent of Bush's deployment, has told Congress there would be 10,000 U.S. deaths in a six-month war with Iraq. In Vietnam, 47,244 Americans were killed in action, 10,446 were killed in accidents or by disease, 153,329 were hospitalized with wounds, 150,375 received wounds that did not require hospitalization. Said Bush: ``I will do my level best to bring those kids home without one single shot fired in anger.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis, Kuwaitis Welcome Bush Move
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabian and Kuwaiti officials on Friday welcomed President Bush's offer to meet with Iraqi leaders, but stressed they are ready for war. Officials in Britain, Jordan and Italy also indicated support for talks. Bush offered to meet in Washington with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz, and also send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to the Iraqi capital of Baghdad in advance of the Jan. 15 deadline set by the U.N. Security Council for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``It's either heads or tails. Either withdraw completely or be kicked out of Kuwait,'' said Mohamed Khayat, an official with the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Information. Hasan Abdul Aziz, a professor at Kuwait University and a volunteer in the Kuwaiti Information Office in Saudi Arabia, said he doubted that diplomacy would work with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. ``We are convinced this person and his regime understand only force,'' he said. Jordan has attempted to mediate between Iraq and the nations supporting the ousted Kuwaiti government, and Jordanian Foreign Minister Marwan Kassem said Bush's offer was in line with Jordan's proposals for dialogue. ``Through dialogue, there is an opportunity for the whole world to get acquainted with the causes of the crisis,'' Kassem said. In London, the Foreign Office issued a statement saying it welcomed ``anything that would secure full implementation of the Security Council resolutions'' demanding that Iraq vacate Kuwait. ``As President Bush himself has said, nothing less than a complete Iraqi withdrawal would be tolerated,'' the Foreign Office statement said. A Foreign Office spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Britain had been notified in advance of Bush's statement. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis said Bush's initiative ``seems to me a good thing.'' ``The fact that the United States, the most important country in the West, makes a step of this type can only be seen with favor by a country like Italy which in the next six weeks will leave nothing unturned in exploring all means that can lead to a peaceful solution to the crisis,'' De Michelis said. De Michelis, speaking to reporters in Venice, Italy, said he had not been informed in advance of Bush's decision. A German government spokesman said there would be no comment at least until Saturday. Spanish Foreign Office spokesman Juan Lena called Bush's offer positive. The Spanish government supported all initiatives that could lead to a peaceful solution, Lena said in Madrid.

The Security Council has given Iraqi President Saddam Hussein six weeks to pull his troops out of Kuwait before the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf are free to launch a military strike. The council voted 12-2 Thursday evening, with China abstaining and Yemen and Cuba opposed, to give Baghdad ``one final opportunity'' to end its aggression against Kuwait, which began with the Aug. 2 invasion. If Iraq has not withdrawn its army by Jan. 15, restored the emir of Kuwait's government and freed all hostages it holds, the U.S.-led multinational force may use ``all necessary means'' to force Baghdad's compliance. It was the first time in 40 years the council had sanctioned force to counter aggression; the first and last time was when it gave its blessing to U.S.-led allies in Korea. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Drivers will pay as much as 5.1 cents a gallon more for gasoline starting Saturday, and they won't be able to blame Saddam Hussein. A federal tax increase is taking effect, and half of the $25 billion it produces over the next five years will go for deficit reduction. Most of the rest will pay for highway and mass transit improvements. A family that drives 12,000 miles in a car that averages 22 miles per gallon will pay about $28 more a year. Flying and shipping by air also will cost more beginning Saturday. The 8 percent federal tax on airline tickets will rise to 10 percent and the 5 percent levy on air freight will go up to 6.25 percent. Those increases, when combined with higher taxes on noncommercial aviation fuel, will bring in almost $12 billion over five years. ---= HELSINKI, Finland (AP) - Scandinavians have plans to quickly erect refugee camps and reinforce their borders if a predicted harsh winter brings a tide of Soviet refugees, officials say. But the Nordic countries are also readying food aid, with the hope that if the Soviets are well-fed at home, they'll stay there. ``Our policy is to feed them ... so they don't have to come across the border at all,'' said Asko Mattila, a Finnish Foreign Ministry official. ``A worst, worst-case scenario, with a great migration, like wolf packs welling over the border ... is not something we regard as possible,'' said Bjorn Blokhus of the Norwegian Foreign Ministry. ---=

UNDATED - In another sign of a weakening economy, the number of people on welfare rose in all but one state in the past year. An Associated Press survey of welfare rolls in all 50 states found that only Wisconsin had bucked the trend, partly because it enacted pioneering programs to get people off welfare. Although a troubled economy was the villain in many states, it was not the sole reason - or even the most important one - in others. Officials in some states attributed the increase to changes in immigration law or to programs that help poor people apply for welfare. Some mentioned changes in federal Medicaid requirements that have brought more people into the welfare system. ---= SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) - The main opposition leader is hailing ``the true end to Communism in Bulgaria,'' after Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government of former Communists resigned in the face of massive strikes and street protests. Lukanov, who helped engineer the ouster of Communist leader Todor Zhivkov a year ago, stepped down Thursday and said his successor will come from outside his Socialist Party that includes former Communists. Lukanov's resignation immediately prompted cheers from tens of thousands waiting in the streets outside the Grand National Assembly. ``Lukanov KGB spy!'' and ``Down with Communists!'' chanted the jubilant crowd, estimated by police at up to 70,000. Many waved blue flags of the main opposition alliance, while others uncorked champagne bottles. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Smithsonian Institution curators are busy cataloguing a monumental new collection of nearly 200 years of popular American sheet music, including stacks of rare, long-forgotten Broadway melodies by George Gershwin and Irving Berlin. This bonanza from the nation's musical past, a gift from Fort Wayne, Ind., broadcaster Sam deVincent, consists of 130,000 original editions of illustrated sheet music, nearly 20,000 recordings and boxes of posters, concert programs, newspaper clippings and other memorabilia. ``This is one of the great, legendary collections of sheet music in the world,'' said John Edward Hasse, curator of American music at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. ``It contains some of the rarest of the rare.'' The scope of the deVincent collection is staggering. It ranges from yellowing reprints of parlor piano pieces of the 1790s to mournful Civil War ballads, the shameless bigotry of minstrel show music, railroad songs and ragtime, military marches, antiwar protest songs, Beatles favorites and political campaign choruses. ---= MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP) - People from Illinois to Arkansas are divided over whether a climatologist's scientifically shaky forecast of an earthquake during the next few days is cause to party or reason to get all shook up. In some places, schools are closing. Disaster drills are being staged. Sales of bottled water, canned food and earthquake insurance have jumped. ``I think we have everything in place,'' said Elaine Van Horn of Memphis, a believer whose family joined 11 others to put up a stockpile of emergency food and camping gear. ``We've been working on this probably since about August.'' Others are amused. A rock band called the Rhythm Hounds planned a ``Shake, Rattle and Quake'' night Sunday at the P&H Cafe, a Memphis beer hall. A pub called Zinnie's East advertised half-price specials Monday at an ``It's Your Fault Earthquake Party.'' ---=
