DOC.HEAD: PBS Special Marks 15th Anniversary of MacNeil-Lehrer Reports
DOC.TEXT: On Judgment Day, after the angel Gabriel has sounded his horn and the seas are merrily a-boil, some PBS viewers probably will tune in ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' for a sober, reasoned, in-depth report. And there, of course, will be co-anchors Jim Lehrer and Robert MacNeil calmly popping questions at bemused-looking Matthew, Mark and - in Washington - Luke and John. ``Yes,'' the Canadian MacNeil will say with characteristic aplomb, ``but what exactly does this mean in terms of, say, the afterlife?'' Well, maybe not. But tonight's 90-minute PBS special marking the 15th anniversary of ``The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' helps explain how and why the two men became the longest-lived news team on television, winning five Peabody awards, four Emmys and dozens of other awards along the way. It also reveals human sides of two very smart, funny, creative fellows. Lehrer, we learn, is the author of five novels and several plays. MacNeil, the author of four non-fiction books, said he's just finished the rough draft of his first novel. ``Just to keep up with him is something,'' MacNeil said. We also learn that the two men, despite working in a business known for oversized egos and bitter internecine rivalries, are each other's best friend. ``We are in many ways each other's closest friend,'' said MacNeil. ``It is wonderful to have somebody you can tell most everything and be completely candid with. We are business partners and friends.'' MacNeil also noted that each has named the other as guardian of his children. Their nightly news show began here Oct. 20, 1975, as a local program called ``The Robert MacNeil Report.'' It supplemented commercial TV news by covering a single story each night, in depth, with Lehrer as Washington correspondent. By 1976, the show was offered to all PBS stations and became ``The MacNeil-Lehrer Report,'' with Lehrer as co-anchor. In 1983, it became the only hour-long, national nightly newscast. ``When we expanded to the hour, it changed from being a supplement to an alternative,'' Lehrer said. ``Now we take the position that if you're looking for a place to go every 24 hours and find out what's happened and get some in-depth treatment, we're the place,'' he said. MacNeil and Lehrer got to that place from vastly disparate backgrounds. MacNeil, nicknamed ``Robin,'' a former Reuters rewrite man, went to work for the BBC in 1967 after seven years as a NBC correspondent and anchor. He joined the now-defunct National Public Affairs Center for Television in 1971. Lehrer, a longtime Dallas newspaperman and former city editor of the Dallas Times Herald, got into public television as on-air host and editor of Dallas public TV station KERA's nightly news. Lehrer, a public affairs coordinator for PBS, first met MacNeil in Atlanta in 1972. Neither man recalls the particulars of that meeting. ``I think I called him `Bob,' '' Lehrer admits. The man who finally got them together on the air was Richard Nixon. MacNeil and Lehrer's Emmy-winning coverage of the Senate Watergate hearings in 1973 was their first professional collaboration. When that stint ended, they agreed that there was an audience for in-depth television news on PBS. ``It was clear that the American people were depending on television more and more for news and public affairs on which to base their votes and their opinions,'' Lehrer said. ``If they were going to depend on television for that, it was incumbent on those of us who worked in public television to give them that,'' he said. Lehrer said there are plans to refine their 15-year-old nightly news show, including a new fixture called ``Conversations,'' a 12-minute interview segment with a person in the news. Would those refinements include showing more of MacNeil and Lehrer than just the head and shoulders? ``I don't think we're going to go that far,'' Lehrer allowed. ``We think the public has already seen the best we have to offer.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... ``A MOMENT WITHOUT TELEVISION'': A 60-second public service announcement underscoring the worldwide effects of AIDS will be seen today, World AIDS Day, by 100 million television viewers in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and Australia. The spot, produced and distributed by Bravo, cable television's cultural network, will be seen on 28 U.S. cable networks and satellite services. The spot will air during Bravo's second annual telethon for AIDS research and care-giving organizations, Unfinished Stories II: Artists and AIDS, airing today and Dec. 2, from 5 p.m. to 6 a.m. EST.

DOC.HEAD: Stubbornly on the Peripheral
DOC.TEXT: Perry Farrell doesn't want his lyrics to be overanalyzed. HE's adamant about it. In fact, if the hyperkinetic singer of Jane's ADdiction were to have a motto, it would be: ``That's for me to know and you to find out.'' Farrell's evasiveness about the exact subject matter of his material can be exasperating. But whether he is that way because he is trying to maintain artistic integrity or is just trying to be enigmatic is a mystery. their own conclusions without his help. So he reduced the band's seeming complexity to basic terms. ``I write down what gets me off,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``There's very little rational thought. I don't want to come off sounding like a fool or a simpleton, but I don't think that hard on purpose. ``I simply just do it. I jot it down and then if it's good, it's good, and if it's not, I try and fix it. Most of it is subconscious, but I don't want you to think I don't think - maybe I'm more impulsive than I am intellectual.'' have caused controversy since the start of their career. The cover art on the 1988 LP ``Nothing's Shocking'' features two nude lifesize sculptures, joined at the waist, of singer Perry Farrell's girlfriend, Casey. A banal look is painted on their faces and their heads are aflame. Farrell created the sculpture. Eight of the nation's major record distribution chains refused to carry the album. Later that year, all but two agreed to distribute the record. Now, Jane's ADdiction's second release, ``Ritual de lo HAbitual,'' has caused a similar furor. The cover art this time depicts a fetish made up of sculptures of Farrell, CAsey and their late friend, Xiola, all nude, lying on a bed surrounded by various objects including Tarot cards, burning candles and photographs. Again, distributors said they would not put out the album as it was, s Farrell created an alternative - a plain white cover with a lengthy dissertation on freedom of speech. Some record stores carry the original, some carry the white-covered version. But JAne's ADdiction is not explicit for the sake of being so - look beyond the covers and see that Farrell's lyrics are brutally Honest accounts of drug-addicted friends, bigotry and the general deterioration of society set in a base of neo-psychedelic guitar. Farrell's reasons for his album covers are simple: He likes nudity. ``It's just something that I enjoy looking at, basically. I don't think it's very controversial.'' ``Ritual'' is a bit more low-key musically than its predecessor, But its subjects are as biting as ever. The erotic ``Three Days'' is Farrell's discourse on the three natures of sexuality human beings are capable of - bisexuality, homosexuality and heterosexuality. Farrell is always looking to expand his understanding of the human condition. He praises women in ``Classic Girl'' and empathizes the pain an interracial couple can face in ``No One's Leaving.'' In the liner notes on the white-covered ``Ritual,'' he even writes: ``I used to wish sometimes that Igiving of love is fearless.'' ``If I had been born female,'' he said, ``I would feel a little bit like I was starting from somewhat of a disadvantage. Although, on the other side of the coin, there's no one more powerful than a woman. A beautiful woman can just rip a man's heart out.'' Farrell has a striking eye for detail and specifics in his lyrics. IN ``Of Course,'' he tells of his big brother holding onto his hands and ``making me slap my own face.'' Of the incident, he sings: ``He was trying to teach me something.'' ``Most of the songs that are general are simply a style of writing,'' he said. ``It's a great style of writing, but it's very Hard for me to find generalities to write about.'' Farrell, along with guitarist David Navarro, bassist Eric A, and drummer Stephen Perkins, released their first self-titled album in 1987 on the independent XXX label. Jane's Addiction doesn't look back on its past work and try to better it - instead, each album, even each song, is completely unto itself. ``I don't go and interpret that it (a song) needs more of this or that,'' Farrell said. ``EVery song's an original thing. I don't try to change things up for change's sake, because I think that might defeat the purpose of the song.

DOC.HEAD: Philippines Gains Reputation as Hollywood of the FAr EAst
DOC.TEXT: The Philippines is becoming a budget Hollywood, attracting foreign filmmakers despite deteriorating security and more than its share of natural disasters. James Glickenhaus, producer, director and writer of ``McBain,'' said varied locations, a professional local work crew and an English-speaking population also make filming here easier. ``All in all, it was an extremely attractive place for us to shoot,'' GLickenhaus, 40, said. ``I would recommend it to other film makers. It's a great place to shoot.'' ``McBAin,'' scheduled for completion this month, is the latest in a series of foreign movies filmed here. Others include ``Apocalypse Now,'' ``Platoon,'' ``BOrn on the Fourth of July,'' ``The Year of Living Dangerously'' and Chuck Norris' ``DElta Force'' series. The cheap cost of production in the Philippines could become an even more attractive lure for leading moviemakers, particularly because some of the biggest Hollywood film studios are now foreign-owned. Just last week, for example, MCA Inc., parent of UNiversal studios, was purchased by Matsushita, a leading Japanese electronics conglomerate. The Japanese have promised to give MCA creative independence, but are expected to look for economical ways to control production expenses. ``McBain'' stars Christopher Walken, who won an Academy Award in 1973 for ``The Deer Hunter,'' and Venezuelan actress Maria Conchita Alonzo, whose credits include ``Moscow on the Hudson'' with Robin Williams and ``Running Man'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger. Glickenhaus downplayed apprehensions about the security situation in the country, which faces a 21-year-old communist rebellion and the continuing threat from military extremists who have launched seven armed uprisings in the past five years. ``IF you read the papers in New York, you'd think it is unsafe and you're going to be shot and you're gonna be blown up,'' Glickenhaus said. ``Obviously, when you're here, I don't think, I don't feel that I'm going to be shot or blown up.'' as a mutiny led by a renegade army colonel erupted in th southern Philippines, 500 miles south of here. The rebellion fizzled in three days. A series of at least 40 bombing attacks by rightist and leftist extremists have occurred in the Manila area since August. Early in November, Typhoon MIke swept the central Philippines, killing about 470 people. Walken said foreign members of the film were unaffected by these incidents since they took place in areas far away from where they were filming. uneventful here, except for the typhoon,'' Walken said. GLickenhaus said he used several provinces just on the outskirts of Manila to shoot scenes that depict parts of three countries. was turned into the Colombian presidential palace. A forest in nearby Cavite province depicted a Vietnamese prison camp. Just west of MAnila, the film crew built a Jamaican white sand beach resort in the coast of Zambales province. most of whom worked in Hollywood films shot here. The high cost of production back home, especially for independent American film producers working on a tight budget, makes shooting in the Philippines attractive. Glickenhaus said ``McBain,'' if shot in the United States, would have cost at least double its $17 million budget. HEof extras were storming the COlombian presidential palace. That scene would have cost $2 million if shot in Hollywood. Tom Gray, the film's publicist, said the widespread use of English - one of the two official languages - gives the Philippines an advantage over other Southeast Asian countries. He said it is easy to give directions to Filipino actors and crew members because they understand English. ``People still like making movies here,'' Glickenhaus said. ``That's a good thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Trying to Raise Money for a National Monument to Military Women
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Mary Hoffman joined the Army during World War II, she was a serious young woman who thought she'd already missed her chance for a full life. But the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps changed everything. ``I thought I was going to be a spinster,'' she recalled 47 years later. ``Instead, I married my first bedside patient.'' Mrs. Hoffman is one of the 350,000 women who served in World War II. She is also the largest single donor to the foundation that's trying to build a memorial to America's women veterans. Mrs. Hoffman has contributed more than $60,000 to the project, all from disability payments she received after breast cancer forced her to leave the service in 1945. Mrs. Hoffman, now an 83-year-old widow, says women veterans need their own memorial. Male war veterans have their monuments and memorials, but ``we are the last group to unite,'' she said from her home in Hyattsville, Md. ``I do feel it's so well worth it.'' Mrs. Hoffman spent two years in the WAC as an occupational therapist, stationed at Woodrow Wilson Hospital in Staunton, Va. Her job was to go from bedside to bedside, helping injured soldiers make wallets or belts or teaching them to type or knit. ``I didn't have a sense of humor when I first went into the military,'' she remembered. ``I was a little old-fashioned, wearing my hair up. But the Army made me over, believe me.'' Mrs. Hoffman's small story is one of almost 50,000 collected so far for a databank that will be part of the memorial, said retired U.S. Air Force Brig. Gen. Wilma Vaught, president of the Women in the Military Service of America Foundation. Vaught is delighted with Mrs. Hoffman's generosity. But she needs a total of $25 million for the memorial and at the moment, she's about $22.5 million short. ``There are over 1.2 million living women veterans and 400,000 women on active duty and in the Guard and reserve'' who are potential donors, Vaught said in a recent interview at the foundation's Arlington, Va., offices. Part of Vaught's problem is finding those women, as well as the descendants of the thousands of American women who served in every war since the Revolution - as nurses, scouts, suppliers, soldiers and saboteurs. Privacy laws prevent Vaught from getting the addresses of veterans or active-duty military women from the government. She has been relying on some 450 volunteers to find them. The Women in Military Service Memorial also suffered a fund-raising setback this year. The foundation tried to raffle a $1 million house in suburban Centreville, Va., only to see ticket sales fall far below target. ``We saw this as a mechanism that in a really short period of time we could raise a lot of money,'' Vaught said. But the kickoff coincided with the drug trial of D.C. Mayor Marion Barry, and media attention was nominal, she said. When the date for the drawing approached in early November, the foundation had sold only about 24,000 of the one million raffle tickets printed. Vaught was forced to postpone the drawing until Feb. 23. There's been progress in other areas. The site has been chosen: the ceremonial entrance gate to Arlington National Cemetery. The foundation conducted a design competition last year and selected a concept by Marion G. Weiss and Michael Manfredi, partners in a New York architecture firm. Their design sets 10 39-foot glass spires into the top of the semicircular gate, known as the Hemicycle. Inside the entrance walls will be a museum portraying the history of women in the U.S. military, a 225-seat auditorium, and the databank. At night, the spires will be gently lit, giving the effect of candles against the Virginia hillside. Vaught is very conscious that time is essential. Under the law authorizing the memorial, Vaught has until November 1991 to raise the $25 million. ``That date may be a little optimistic,'' she said, adding that she is prepared to go back to Congress to ask for more time. Meanwhile, as she travels the country meeting women veterans and promoting the memorial, she is most impressed by the World War I veterans. ``We still have a few World War I women left who can make it to the dedication,'' she said. ``If we're going to do something to say thank-you to them, it's got to be now.''

DOC.HEAD: Could Paper Stock Certificates Go the Way of Silent Movies, TV Tubes?
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators are exploring ways to streamline the process for getting stocks to the buyer and payment to the seller - including a reform to replace paper stock certificates with computerized listings. But investors who feel more comfortable holding on to those intricately engraved, diploma-sized pieces of paper may not have to swap them for a line on a blinking computer screen. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden says he supports the goal of cutting the completion time of stock trades from five days to three but ``it is my strong desire to preserve'' investors' rights to choose between a tangible stock certificate and an electronic record. At a round-table discussion last week with industry leaders, Breeden and other SEC officials heard several alternatives for accelerating the process of clearance and settlement. Simply put, clearance and settlement is the system for clearing the transfer of securities going in one direction and money moving in the other in an orderly way to settle a transaction. ``Although it typically operates unseen and unnoticed by the average investor, the clearance and settlement system is the essential infrastructure that supports the operation of the more visible elements of our capital markets,'' Breeden said. But he also said that while the U.S. clearance and settlement system processes $469 billion in securities transactions each day, it still takes five business days to settle a transaction here while some foreign markets do it in three days or less. Anyone who's ever had to wait for their bank to clear an out-of-state check knows the problems delay can cause. Stock transactions are complicated by the physical transfer of a check or cash to the seller and the paper stock certificates to the buyer. Multiply that by millions of shares worth billions of dollars on a busy trading day and the risk of delayed clearance and settlement becomes apparent. Three clearinghouses and three depositories handle the money and stock transfers for all of the nation's seven stock exchanges. During the 1987 stock market crash the system was overwhelmed, tying up large amounts of cash that could have kept the trading process more fluid. Experts worry that in a market emergency, the value of securities could rise or fall before trades are completed, causing missed opportunities and losses on a massive scale and possibly leading - if the problems are serious enough - to defaults and a chain reaction collapse in the increasingly interdependent markets. Recent reform legislation passed by Congress and signed by the president calls for the SEC and other federal regulators to work out ways of improving clearance and settlement systems for stock, bonds, futures contracts and options which are now handled separately. The Group of 30, a London-based, private-sector group composed of international business and financial leaders pushing for ways to unify the the clearance and settlement process worldwide. One method discussed at the round table is the replacement of stock certificates with a so-called ``book entry'' in a computer. Some countries, such as Japan, have done away with the use of stock certificates but some retail brokerages fear that without paper documents they might lose the mom and pop investors that are their mainstay. ``Many of our retail customers enjoy the right to take physical possession of their certificates,'' maintains A.G. Edwards & Sons, a St. Louis-based brokerage. ``Some customers tend to distrust any entity holding their certificates.'' Elimination of stock certificates is also opposed, not surprisingly, by the people who make the intricately engraved certificates. A survey commissioned by the United States Banknote Corp., one of the nation's largest private printers of stamps, banknotes and stock certificates, found that four out of five shareholders queried opposed the proposed plan for eliminating stock certificates. The survey of 750 individuals currently investing in th market found that 81 percent opposed replacing stock certificates with a book entry only system of computerized record-keeping. Also opposing the proposal is the United Shareholders Association, a shareholders rights group founded in 1986 by takeover strategist T. Boone Pickens. ``Certificates represent perhaps the most direct link between corporations and their shareholders. By depriving shareholders of this certificate, a book entry only system would create one more gap between management and ownership,'' USA President Ralph V. Whitworth wrote Breeden recently. Breeden said he favored a ``pro-choice'' alternative: allowing investors who want to, to keep their certificates but encouraging the use of speedier electronic methods. But small brokerages fret that giving investors a choice would be too expensive to maintain and could drive them out of business. ``We have heard a great deal from our regional and smaller firms who are very concerned about the cost-benefit analysis,'' said Edward Kwalwasser, a New York Stock Exchange official. George McNamee, chairman of First Albany Corp. said he strongly supported cutting the settlement process to three days but feared the additional cost ``only will be offset if we eliminate the certificates.''

DOC.HEAD: Ranchers and Rubber Tappers Fight Over Rain Forest
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: The death threat was nothing new to the rubber tappers' union in this Amazon town. ``I've been hired to kill you,'' read a scrawled note slipped under the office door in November. It said three union leaders and the local's truck driver ``can't make it to 1991.'' The note was unsigned, but there was little doubt at union headquarters who was behind it: cattle ranchers, the tappers' enemies in a bloody dispute for land rights in Brazil's tropical rain forest. Since the union was founded in 1975, such threats have been common and deadly serious. The local says ``pistoleiros,'' gunmen hired by landowners, have killed more than 150 tappers and Indians. One victim was CHico Mendes, a rubber tapper and union leader who had become an internationally consulted expert on the Amazon. Shotgun fire from ambush cut him down in December 1988 at his home in Xapuri, near the Bolivian border 2,650 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. A local rancher, Darli Alves da Silva, and his son Darci were arrested. Their trial is scheduled to begin Wednesday in Xapuri. ``This is the land where they threaten and do it,'' said Osmarino AMancio Rodrigues, president of the Brasileia union local And one of those on the note's list. ``No one has ever escaped.'' He added, with a laugh: ``Two of my bodyguards were threatened. Now I'll have to get bodyguards for my bodyguards.'' Rodrigues, 34, is widely regarded as the successor to Chico Mendes as the leader of a grass-roots movement against destruction of the rain forest. Jose da SIlva Pereira, another tapper on the death list, said: ``When ranchers want to get rid of a tapper, they come in shooting, kill his livestock and burn his house. If he doesn't leave, he dies.'' A new alliance of rubber tappers and Amazon Indians is challenging the notion that ``developing'' the forest means cutting it down for timber or burning it to make pasture. Uncontrolled slash-and-burn clearing already has destroyed more than 250,000 square miles of rain forest, an area the equal to Texas. A patch of jungle the size of a football field disappears every eight seconds, adding to the greenhouse effect that is warming the planet. Those whose livelihoods come from the forest favor an alternative called ``extractivist reserves,'' a new system of landholding in which the government expropriates rain forest to allow commercial harvesting of fruits, nuts and other renewable products. Such reserves give tappers legal rights to the jungle, where for years they were squatters on the huge feudal estates of cattle barons and big landowners. The government now has 7{ million acres of reserves in AMazonia and plans to set aside 55 million more by 1993. ONe region of nearly 2{ million acres is named for Chico Mendes. ``There won't be peace in the forest without land reform,'' said Rodrigues, a short, swarthy man with a black beard. ``In Amazonia, that means Indian reservations and extractivist reserves.'' The main argument for protecting the forest is simply that it's More profitable alive. Aminded consumers in the United States and Europe. Amazon fruits, nuts, oils and essences are heading north to make everything from ice cream and nut candy to cosmetics. ``We have to prove the economic value of the rain forest and generate income to save it,'' anthropologist Jason Clay said in an interview. Clay is research director of Cultural Survival, a non-profit group based in Cambridge, Mass., and visits Brazil frequently. Cultural SUrvival buys jungle products and resells them to companies abroad, charging a 5 percent ``environmental premium'' used to help forest peoples. Clay said he showed samples of 350 rain forest products and businessmen were interested in 38 of them. He reported orders worth $4 million, and said several companies pledged part of their profits to rain forest projects. Extractivist reserves are ``one of the few environmentally viable alternatives for the Amazon,'' he said. ``We have to make the reserves more economically rewarding. Then we can use them to recover degraded areas and as buffer zones for the genetic hotspots, the really fragile parts of Amazonia that shouldn't be used.'' Brazil has tried for decades to tap the riches of the Amazon, a wilderness of two million square miles that is larger than Europe without the Soviet Union. Amazonia contains 30 percent of the world's rain forest; one-fifth of its fresh water; 5 million species of plants, animals and insects, and rich deposits of gold, diamonds, iron, tin and other minerals. Despite those riches, most of its inhabitants live in grinding poverty. Attempts by the military regime of 1964-1985 to ``open up the Amazon'' were an ecological nightmare. Huge development projects like the Trans-Amazon highway, farm settlements and the Balbina and Tucurui hydroelectric dams wiped out huge tracts of forest and nearly destroyed some native tribes. Government incentives attracted cattle ranchers, who kept burning the jungle off the sandy soil to replace pasture that lasted only two or three years. Experts say their productivity is Secretary Jose Lutzenberger, an internationally respected ecologist, says Brazil is trying to change its image as a destroyer of the environment. ``Extractivist reserves are extremely important,'' he said in an interview. ``We must create many more of them.'' Canada has pledged $10 million to the National Rubber Tappers Council, starting next year, to develop extractivist reserves. THe newest and largest of the special areas is the Chico Mendes REserve, which covers 2.4 million acres in the western Amazon state of Acre, where the most violence has occurred. On the reserves, tappers' associations sign long-term contracts with the government for the ``use and benefit'' of the land. They must obey rules for protecting the environment or forfeit the area. ``This was our great victory,'' said Nelson Custodio da Silva, a rubber tapper. ``We fought four years for this reserve.'' Problems remain. Most reserves have not yet been expropriated and the government foresees a long legal battle with landowners. The Chico Mendes Reserve was created by former President Jose Sarney three days before he left office in March. ``It was a great party, but the bill wasn't paid,'' Marco Antonio Mendes, the Acre state environment secretary, said in an interview. Tappers also have not escaped exploitation by ``marreteiros'' - middlemen who trade commercial goods like salt and cloth for rubber and nuts, and routinely charge three or four times the regular price. Nearly all the profit from jungle produce is made elsewhere. Tappers earn only 3 to 4 cents a pound for Brazil nuts, about 2 percent of the New York wholesale price. Acre state's Technology Foundation is running a unique experiment in forest management on the remote border with Amazonas state. At the 166,000-acre Antimari reserve, technicians are studying how to ``densify'' the forest by planting without upsetting the natural balance. They are concentrating on bamboo, timber and more than 800 types of medicinal plants, as well as rubber and Brazil nuts. ``This is a first for Amazonia,'' said Gilberto Siqueira, the foundation president. ``It will show us the limits of exploitation without disturbing the whole.'' Another experimental project is a cooperative in Xapuri that shells, packs and exports Brazil nuts. It is the first nut-processing plant owned by the tappers. paid a fair price,'' said Rolando Polanco, a worker at the cooperative. ``We're trying to give the tappers a better deal.'' The plant, built with a $25,000 gift from Cultural Survival, employs 78 people and processes 1,100 pounds of nuts a day, barely one-tenth of the production in Xapuri alone. Polanco said expansion depends on donations from environmental groups and businessmen.

DOC.HEAD: Life is Easier for Rubber Tappers On New Reserves
With BC-Fight for the Amazon
BY PETER MUELLO ^Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Joao de Almeida Mello sat on his cabin floor in the rain forest and recalled when he lived in fear of expulsion, or worse, by landowners. ``I was just a squatter,'' he said. ``I was at the mercy of ranchers. I had no security, no guarantees.'' ``Living on your own land makes all the difference,'' he said, and smiled. Mello is a rubber tapper on the Chico Mendes Extractivist Reserve in the western Amazon state of Acre, nearly 3,000 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. Extractivist reserves are a new model of development for the Amazon: The government gives forest dwellers rights to their traditional lands and lets them harvest what the jungle grows. rubber and nuts that provide his income, for wood to build and game to help feed his wife and 10 children. His day starts at 4:00 a.m., when the rubber-tree sap flows freely in the cool of the morning. It slows when the Amazon sun pushes the heat to or through the 90s. ON this morning, he crossed a meadow and entered the forest, walking on a carpet of broad, dark leaves that covered the sandy soil. Bird songs filled the woods, the loudest of them the three-whistle tune of what forest people call the ``twenty-one.'' Walking among 1,500-year-old Brazil-nut and piqui trees towering 130 feet, MELlo approached a shiny-leafed rubber tree, drew his tapping knife and gently cut half a dozen diagonal slashes on the already scarred trunk. Milky white latex began to flow, dripping into a hollowed Brazil-nut pod the size of a softball propped on a three-pronged stick. Mello moved to the next tree. This trail contains about 150 trees, and he will tap them all in a day. Mello has five trails in the forest and works them in turn. He retraces the route later to collect the latex, dumping it into a large, round can he carries in a cloth harness on his back. At the cabin, he empties the contents into a homemade wooden press, where the latex congeals into rubber. sugar-cane liquor and other goods at exorbitant prices. Sugar that costs 20 cents a pound in a store often costs four times that at barter time. ``The bill just keeps growing and you never finish paying,'' said Mello, sitting on a split-log bench in his cabin. The room was bare except for three oiled shotguns hanging by their straps from nails on the wall. COllecting latex is difficult during the rainy season from December to April and tappers gather Brazil nuts instead. Mello collects the pods in a backpack made of vines, cracks them open and leaves the nuts in flour sacks along the rutted dirt road that leads out of the reserve. He and other tappers pool their money to rent a tractor and take the nuts outside the reserve to sell, thus avoiding the middlemen. Tappers deeper in the forest rely on ox cart and burro to get through the mud. Mello said he earned only 50,000 cruzeiros last year, less than $1,000 in Brazil's rapidly devaluating currency. the reserve are less economic than political - land rights and the freedom to unionize. To help feed the family, Mello plants rice, beans and manioc root. He sells what is left over. Meat often means monkey, armadillo or parrot. Now and then, he slaughters a goat or a pig. Government environmental workers plan to build a dam near Mello's cabin so he can raise fish. They also teach those who live in the reserves how to renew degraded parts of the forest by planting avocado, cashew, orange, Tangerine and acai trees. ``We used to ruin a lot of the forest and the second growth wasn't good for anything,'' Mello said. ``Now it's full of fruit trees.'' There still is no school, although Mello's district has 40 school-age children. The reserve has no health station, despite Government promises to build one. ``We get promises, promises and nothing is done,'' said Mello's neighbor, Raimundo Tavares Ribeiro. ``If you get sick, either a group of neighbors carries you out in a hammock to a hospital or you stay there and die.'' STill, he said, the reserve has freed tappers from their greatest fear: the ranchers and big landowners. ``The landowners keep you under their feet,'' Tavares said. ``If you work for them, you're a slave. They pay you what they want and take half of what you grow.'' ``Reserves give poor people conditions to work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Struggles with Legacy of Poverty and Suspicion
DOC.TEXT: Romanians have achieved a fragile democracy a year after the bloody fall of communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, but not the prosperity and calm they hoped it would bring. There is economic misery as the government tries to create a market economy, and suspicion of political leaders who once served Ceausescu. An army of orphaned or abandoned children is warehoused in woeful institutions. There are nagging questions about attitudes toward minority Hungarians here in Transylvania, and toward Jews and Gypsies. Even the revolution, which began in this western city, is under a cloud. Some question whether it was really a revolution or just a communist palace coup. ``The government that has installed itself in Bucharest is neo-communist, using the same people, methods, and even massacres, as the one before,'' said George Serban, an anti-government activist. He displayed a ripped-open envelope to emphasize his claim that someone still reads his mail and taps his telephone. Demonstrators who join weekly street protests apparently see nothing contradictory in accusing the new National Salvation Front government of being a front for unreformed communists and criticizing the market-oriented reforms of Premier Petre Roman. Prices have doubled or tripled, stores are empty, industrial production is down 20 percent and the average monthly paycheck is worth only $20 on the black market. In nationwide protests Nov. 15, more than 100,000 Romanians demanded the government's resignation. The revolution began at a corner building that served as the Hungarian Reformed Church and housed its pastor, Laszlo Tokes. It is about half a mile from where Serban, the 37-year-old president of the anti-government Timisoara Society, spoke recently to a human rights conference. It was Dec. 15, 1989. Hundreds of people gathered outside as Tokes, whose defiant anti-communism had made him a marked man, waited for Ceausescu's police to banish him to the far-off village of Mineu. Communists had been swept from power the previous month in Czechoslovakia. Radical changes were occuring in the other former East bloc countries, but Ceausescu promised only more of the same. ``There was something in the air, a feeling that this could not continue, and it was in that atmosphere that the people gathered outside the church,'' said Lajos Varga, a member of the congregation and a close friend of Tokes. Demonstrators moved to the downtown Communist Party headquarters, smashed windows and set fires inside. Police invaded the church, beat Tokes and took him away. The revolution had begun. ``First, the army fired on demonstrators gathered again outside the party building,'' Varga recalled. ``Several dozen were killed that afternoon as the army pushed demonstrators down the main boulevard, leaving a few dead at each junction.'' Tension spread to Bucharest, and Ceausescu organized a mass rally several days later to condemn the ``hooligans'' in Timisoara. For the first time in his 24 years of power, a booing crowd drowned him out. Police and soldiers began shooting. Bogdan Preda, an Associated Press reporter, was in University Square. ``I jumped into a fountain outside the nearby architecture school building, and that may have saved my life,'' he recalled. ``Eventually, we escaped through the southern end of the main boulevard, which the police and army kept open.'' Ceausescu fled the next day, Dec. 22, but was captured by the army, which had turned against him. He was tried secretly and executed on Christmas Day. The National Salvation Front stepped in, began running the country and rode its promise of painless reform to easy victory in Romania's first free elections in five decades. Many people accuse the front of usurping their revolution. President Ion Iliescu, a top Communist official before falling out with Ceausescu, passionately defended communism in his first television speech after the uprising. Iliescu now insists he no longer believes in it. Last spring, students, intellectuals, former dissidents and others blocked traffic in University Square for 53 days. Six people were killed when police tried to suppress the protest. Iliescu called in pro-government miners from the provinces. They terrorized the capital for days, beating and arresting people suspected of opposing the government. Other countries shunned Romania after the violence, but it has recovered some foreign support by backing U.N. sanctions against Iraq at the cost of billions of dollars in trade. Intellectuals have increased their attacks on Iliescu since the passage of laws placing the army, the new Romanian Intelligence Service and even the government under his direct control and supervision. ``Iliescu is a potential dictator, and he must be stopped,'' said Gabriel Andreescu of the intellectual Group for Social Dialogue, a cornerstone of the nationwide Civic Alliance opposition. The alliance accuses Iliescu and the National Salvation Front of covering up what happened in the revolution. No one is being tried for the random shooting that occurred in Bucharest for several days between Ceausescu's flight and his execution. Most of the more than 1,000 people killed in the revolution lost their lives in that period. About 6,000 members of Ceausescu's Securitate security service have turned up in the new intelligence service. The 9,000 others, along with members of the Communist Party Central Committee, were retired with pensions. Although about 60 Ceausescu aides and Securitate officers have been tried, the charges addressed only Ceausescu's attempt to repress the revolt, not the violence after his flight. Most Romanians appear satisfied with the freedoms introduced last December and are eager to improve their lot after four decades of increasing poverty under communism, but Roman's reforms have begun to bite. Under the economic program's first phase, introduced Nov. 1, many prices have risen by up to 200 percent. Staple foods, energy and rents remain protected, but only temporarily. Money-losing state enterprises have been told they face bankruptcy and the government has said it will stop providing industry with cheap energy while private homes are dark and cold. The program has made enemies in the trade unions, which officials see as potentially the strongest opposition force. In a sign of possible divisions in the Front itself, Iliescu has been lukewarm about Roman's reforms, which the premier says will deliver ``an average European standard of living'' in five years. Doru Mihiti of the Timisoara Society summed up the views of the critics: ``There was a moment in which communism could have been eliminated for good in Romania. In the chaos right after the revolution, the entire system and its personnel could have been overhauled. Instead, we now must fight for the changes, slowly, and one at a time.''

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty About Securitate Clouds Revolution
With BC-Romania's Hard Year
DOC.TEXT: Uncertainty about what happened to the Nicolae Ceausescu's hated secret police, the Securitate, has cast a shadow over the revolution. Despite official accounting for about 9,000 Securitate officers who were retired or transferred to other jobs, many Romanians believe the organization is alive and well, playing its old game of political terror and intrigue for new masters. Virgil Magureanu, chief of the new Romanian Intelligence Service, acknowledges hiring nearly 6,000 ``uncompromised'' Securitate officers for what he termed non-political duties. Many critics of the government claim agents of the new service infiltrate opposition demonstrations, collect information that later leads to arrests, and occasionally try to provoke violence. ``The political police still exists, and we will not have liberty until it is gone,'' Sorin Rosca of the Civic Alliance opposition declared at a recent anti-government demonstration. Anxiety about the Securitate derives partially from the continuing mystery surrounding the revolution of December 1989. More than 1,000 Romanians were killed, most of them after Ceausescu fell Dec. 22 and the National Salvation Front government was installed. Ceausescu loyalists from Securitate fought the army and shot citizens down in the streets. Who ordered and carried out the shootings still is not known, and no one has been tried. The issue is being avoided in the trial of the former Securitate chief, Iulian Vlad. Thousands of people were arrested during violence accompanying the revolution, but officials say they were released in the confusion and there was no record of their names. Sen. Dan Iosif, a front member who led the occupation of Ceausescu's former headquarters in Palace Square, said Securitate agents captured there were either killed by the raiders or eliminated by other Securitate members to keep them quiet. President Ion Iliescu, when asked in interviews, acknowledges the existence of a ``very great mystery'' surrounding the uprising. In a society where decades of government-controlled media transformed word-of-mouth into the only alternative source of information, holes in the official version have been filled by rumors in dazzling variety. Some Romanians believe the new authorities gave the Securitate amnesty in exchange for a cease-fire. Coriolan Sipos, one of those who stormed Ceausescu's headquarters, offered this: ``It was a brilliant coup by the Securitate itself to install Iliescu, pure and simple,'' Sipos, a teacher, claimed many of those who invaded the building had been been killed by plainclothes Securitate agents posing as revolutionaries. ``Among those who survived, only about 10 are left in Romania, the rest having been hounded out in one way or another,'' he said. Gabriel Andreescu of the intellectual Group for Social Dialogue said: ``I do not rule out the possibility that the revolution was entirely staged, however diabolical it seems, but all I can say for certain is that the official story is false.''
