DOC.TEXT: distorted world of Japanese real estate where less is more and more is outrageous. There is no more expensive land per inch in the world unless it might be a South African diamond mine. Here's a visit to Japan's real national treasure. ---

Many a tourist has wandered gape-mouthed through Tokyo's Ginza, the shopping wonderland where such high-priced marvels as $450 neckties confound the senses. Next to it, though, lies a greater treasure. It is a vacant lot. For three years, this 53.4-acre asphalt wasteland in the heart of the most expensive real estate in the world has gone virtually unused. government-owned former rail yard is surrounded by headquarters of mighty banks and corporations. It is a jarring sight, somewhat as Manhattan might look with an empty space where Rockefeller Center now stands. Yet no one can buy it. To find out why entails a Lewis Carroll-like journey through land policies that Western experts say defy economic logic and absurdly inflate Tokyo's land prices, which run 30 to 100 times Higher than in other major cities worldwide. Such government policies have left Japan's huge landholding corporations swimming in assets and many homeowners paper millionaires. But they have also created a large class of have-nots that threatens JApan's prosperity. Government officials say they cannot put the Shiodome rail yard on the market just yet because it is too valuable. The lot is as much as 50 times pricier than the approximately $850 million Japan's mitsubishi Estate Co. paid for a share of the 22-acre Rockefeller Center last year. Its sudden availability to speculators would bid up real estate prices to even more astronomical levels, officials say, although they acknowledge that such a policy runs contrary to the law of supply and demand. ``Normal economic theory doesn't seem to work when it comes to land in Japan, because there is overwhelmingly more demand for land than supply,'' said Hiroshi Yoneda, the Transportation MInistry official in charge of the yard. aghast at such reasoning. ``Raising supply usually lowers prices. Anyone who doesn't know that should go back and take Economics 101,'' scoffed Robert Feldman, an economist at Salomon Bros., a NEw York financial house. But this is Japan, where an alchemy of postwar tax policy, easy money and Japanese ``herd'' behavior has turned land into gold. Like gold's fabled ability to inspire greed, the hunger for land on this small archipelago crowded with 120 million people has created rapacious speculators who've become the stuff of movies and TV dramas. ``Land sharks'' eager to resell properties hire thugs who spend Months banging noisemakers or setting fires to hound families from buildings they've occupied for generations. Real estate executives have been held hostage by extremists outraged over inadequate housing. Worst of all, land fever has divided Japan into two economic classes -- those who own land, usually through an inheritance, and those who can't afford it. Too often, the landless are the younger, baby-producing generation. That looms as a potential disaster. Japan had the world's lowest birthrate last year at 10.2 babies per 1,000 people. In surveys, many women attribute their unwillingness to have children in part to the rented ``rabbit hutch'' apartments they must squeeze into with little room for family. Ultimately, policy-makers worry, this so-called ``child shock'' could undermine the nation's industrial might. Japan, already suffering a labor shortage, could become top-heavy with too many elderly pensioners supported by too few younger workers. Up to now, the long-governing conservative Liberal Democratic PArty has had little motivation to act. High land prices have been popular with its major constituencies: the 60 percent of Japanese who already own homes and the large corporations who have watched their portfolio assets swell. But the catastrophic potential of the boom may nudge government into action. On Oct. 30, a 1 percent tax on land holdings was suggested to gradually to drive down prices. According to one survey, high interest rates and an economic slowdown already have reduced residential land prices by 10 percent to 30 percent in recent months. The government is moving gingerly, fearful falling prices would jolt corporations with large holdings of real estate and stocks. Many are already reeling from the Tokyo Stock Exchange's nosedive this year. In addition, the government must untangle 45 years of often bizarre tax and lending policies that have made Tokyo a sea of two-story homes instead of desperately needed high-rise redevelopment. than small vegetable patches or rice paddies, are exempt from property taxes if they declare their intention to farm for 10 years. Banks offer 100-year mortgages. Current landholding taxes are only as high as 0.2 percent, allowing small owners to sit tight and watch values spiral upward. As a result, real estate experts say, the main reason for the land inflation is probably not a lack of space but simply that so little is traded. Plans are also moving slowly for Shiodome, a remnant of the government's 1987 sell-off of the state-owned railway to private companies. Hiroshi Yoneda, the Transportation Ministry official charged with developing a subdivision plan, said it is to be gradually sold off for commercial use after March 1992. But that timetable may be impossible. ``It is extraordinary. If they had disposed of Shiodome several years ago that land would have soaked up so much speculative money,'' said Gregory CLark, a Sophia University economics professor who has advised the government on the land problem. ``They genuinely believe that by keeping a supply of land off the market they lower prices,'' Clark said. ``If you look at the situation with Western eyes you'd have to assume it was a government plot'' to keep prices high. Some Westerners do. An article in the October issue of The Atlantic Monthly, for example, accuses Japan's government of ``a conscious and even a brilliant strategy'' to maintain sky-high land prices as a means of keeping foreign companies from buying into Japan, suppressing consumption of foreign goods and boosting savings. Most experts conclude, however, there's no evidence for such a scheme. Makoto Utsumi, vice minister of finance for international affairs, looked surprised when asked whether his ministry was behind it all, as some conspiracy theorists contend. ``It's totally wrong to think that Finance Ministry officials are happy to see higher land prices,'' he retorted. Indeed, the ministry has been urging banks to rein in real estate loans, but to little avail. Clark said he would ``never rule out a plot entirely because there are depths of this society we never get to. ``If it's a plot, they're very clever. If not, they're very stupid. And I can't believe the Japanese are so stupid.''
DOC.NOTE: END ADV Sunday, Dec. 9

DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending, the driving force behind eight years of U.S. economic expansion, did not budge in October, the government said in a report analysts contend was further evidence of a recession. Accounting for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, consumer spending was unchanged from September at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.73 trillion, the Commerce Department said Thursday. ``The consumer has retrenched,'' said economist Gilbert Benz of the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``It clearly supports those who say we're in a recession.'' ---

The government has charged 12 people with attempting to distribute more than $500 million in securities stolen from companies in New York and London. Those charged were accused of taking part in a conspiracy to distribute about 291 million British pounds (about $550 million) in treasury bills and certificates of deposit issued by the Bank of England. The bank's employees had been robbed of the money at knife point on May 2, according to the indictment, which was returned by a federal grand jury in Manhattan and unsealed Thursday. ---

CBS Inc. stock climbed for the third consecutive day after a published report said the company was considering a stock buyback. The company said it had no comment on Thursday's report, but its stock jumped $4.87{ a share to $165.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. That followed a $5.87{ a share advance on Wednesday and a $2.25 rise on Tuesday. The media company's stock remains well below its high for the year of $206 a share, however. ---

The European Community has imposed penalties known as anti-dumping duties on U.S. and Japanese imports of aspartame, an artificial sweetener used in soft drinks and food. The EC Commission on Thursday said NutraSweet, the U.S. exporter, charged less than half in Europe for its product than in the United States causing ``material injury'' to Holland Sweetener Co, the EC's only aspartame maker. ---

A biotechnology watchdog has charged in a lawsuit that the National Dairy Board is illegally promoting a growth hormone being used experimentally in cows to increase milk production. Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Washington-based Foundation on Economic Trends, has used a variety of legal maneuvers to try to block the use of bovine growth hormone on the grounds that it is unsafe for human health. Thursday's action is based on documents he obtained under the Freedom of Information Act. ---

The world's biggest food company, Nestle SA, and the largest soft drink concern, The Coca-Cola Co., have signed a deal to set up a joint venture in beverages, the companies said. The statement on Thursday said the two multinationals would be equal partners in the new company which would manufacture and market bases and concentrates for the production of ready-to-drink coffee and tea drinks. ---

The European Community Commission has proposed developing a green-labeling system for consumer goods that would denote products that are environmentally sound. EC Environment Commissioner Carlo Ripa de Meana said Thursday's proposal would put industries under pressure to make ecologically sound products. He said a panel of scientists and other experts from the 12 EC states would identify which products could sport the label showing a daisy encircled by 12 stars. ---

Aerospace giant Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GmbH plans to cut 10 percent of its workforce at its main German production complex at Ottobrunn, the IG Metall labor union said. The company, also known as MBB, is the aerospace subsidiary of Germany's largest industrial group, Daimler-Benz AG. At Ottobrunn, MBB's main production complex, the union said on Thursday the company plans to trim 700 jobs in the aircraft construction sector and another 300 jobs in the defense technology section during 1991. ---

Financial News Network Inc., which operates a business channel on cable television but is embroiled in a financial controversy of its own, says it expects to report a $72.5 million loss for fiscal 1990. The company, whose biggest shareholer is the owner of the United Press International wire service, also said on Thursday it expects to report a loss of $25 million for the first quarter of its current fiscal year. ---

The stock market lost ground Thursday in a seesaw session punctuated by rumors and technical selling. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 16.34 points to close at 2,518.81. Bonds fell. The dollar bounded higher as gold prices gained. Oil prices slipped in volatile trading. Corn and soybean futures prices closed sharply higher.

DOC.HEAD: FNN Owner Expects To Report $72.5 Million Loss for Fiscal 1990
DOC.TEXT: Financial News Network Inc., which operates a busiess channel on cable television but is embroiled in a financial controversy of its own, said it expects to report a $72.5 million loss for fiscal 1990. The company, whose biggest shareholder is the owner of the United Press International wire service, also said Thursday it expects to report a loss of $25 million for the first quarter of its current fiscal year. The company has been unable to report its financial results for the fiscal year ended June 30 because it replaced its auditing firm in a controversy over how FNN was reporting a $28 million investment in a new service. The auditors Deloitte & Touche contended the investment should have been deducted from quarterly earnings while FNN wanted to spread the costs over a few years. Deloitte left as FNN's auditor in October and the firm Coopers & Lybrand was brought in to study the FNN annual financial statements. FNN said Thursday that its new auditors had ``substantially completed their examination'' and said it expects to file its audited financial statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission in early December. FNN said the anticipated net loss for the year would leave it with a ``shareholders' deficit of approximately $33.5 million at June 30.'' The shareholders' deficit represents an excess of liabilities over assets. The company said it would probably file amended quarterly reports for the first nine months of fiscal 1990 to reflect ``material changes deemed appropriate as a result of the audit.'' In addition, it said it expects to report within a few weeks a $25 million loss for the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30. FNN said that more than half of the anticipated losses for the year and the first quarter involves elimination of revenues derived from affiliated businesses. The company did not identify the affiliates, but it is 46 percent owned by Infotechnology Inc., which owns United Press International and an assortment of other media and technology companies. It was disclosed last month that the SEC is investigating Infotechnology for undisclosed reasons. Infotechnology and FNN have each said they do not have enough cash flow to cover operating expenses, and are negotiating with those to whom they owe money. In late October, Alan J. Hirschfield and Allan R. Tessler were brought in to succeed Earl Brian as interim co-chief executives at both Infotechnology and Financial News Network. In early November, they said they were putting the companies' principal operations up for sale, including the FNN cable network and UPI. In Thursday's announcement, Hirschfield and Tessler said FNN's investment banker, Wertheim & Schroder & Co. Inc., is beginning the sale process for FNN. ``A substantial number of inquires have been received from a broad representation of media-related companies and others concerning the proposed sale of FNN,'' the statement said. Ms. Gordon said she could not identify who was interested or how many inquiries had been received. She said the company hopes to conclude negotiations of the contracts for the sales by the end of the year. FNN provides stock quotes, business and financial news and sports information on a cable TV network to more than 35 million homes served by 3,500 cable systems in the United States and Canada. It also operates a business radio network and with Infotechnology, owns 51 percent of the cable network, The Learning Channel.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Tests Mexican Menu Item
DOC.TEXT: If you can test pizzas at McDonald's restaurants in Kentucky and try out a '50s-style diner with waiters, lasagna and Salisbury steak in Tennessee, why not McBurritos in California? McDonald's Corp., always looking for a way to spice up its fast-food menus, is selling egg-filled breakfast burritos for 59 cents at a half-dozen Los Angeles-area outlets, the latest in a series of experiments. ``They're constantly testing new products,'' said Michael Mueller, an industry analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. The fast-food company, pressed by competition, has chewed through a slew of changes recently. It trashed its styrofoam packaging at the urging of environmentalists. It's testing a healthier hamburger in which some of the fat is replaced by an algae derivative. Then came word that McDonald's may cut prices permanently on some menu items to grab a bigger bite of the fast-food pie. Those rumors propelled its stock onto the New York Stock Exchange's most-active list Thursday, falling $1.12{ per share to $28. Investors apparently want profits as fast as their food - but analysts say price cuts might help financial results in the long run. The burritos, similar to ones already sold at several smaller fast-food chains, are a flour tortilla filled with scrambled eggs, sausage and mild salsa. ``It's been selling OK, but there hasn't been a huge demand for it,'' Edward Wilcox, manager of the McDonald's in the Woodland Hills area of the San Fernando Valley, said Wednesday. Over the years, such fare as salads, McDLTs and Chicken McNuggets made the transition from test items to McDonald's staples. But not every experiment made the cut. Among the flops was the Hulaburger: two cheese slices with a slice of grilled pineapple on a toasted bun.

DOC.HEAD: Bondholders Reject Western Union Offer As Executives Job-Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Debt-burdened Western Union Corp. has taken a new tack to keep afloat by offering 50 cents cash on the dollar to its bondholders, who rejected the company's first exchange offer. Meanwhile, Western Union confirmed Thursday that its top officials have been holding job talks with the company's controlling owner. Several major bondholders have threatened to force the communications company into bankruptcy if they don't get certain concessions during the company's restructuring effort. After scrapping plans to extend its original bond exchange offer for a 13th time, Western Union offered Thursday to repurchase its junk bonds for 50 cents on the dollar. The cash to fund the offer will come from the proceeds of Western Union's pending sale of most of its Business Services unit to American Telephone & Telegraph Co., said spokesman Warren Bechtel. By repurchasing the bonds, Western Union would no longer have to pay the high rates of interest on them. ``Take the money and run,'' was the advice to bondholders from C. Richard Lehmann of the Bond Investors Association. ``It's a case of a bird in the hand versus something mysterious in the bush.'' ``There's very little value in the company, and if it goes into bankruptcy the lawyers will suck out most of the value left in the company,'' Lehmann said. Several major bondholders have asked that Bennett S. LeBow, the New York financier whose Brooke Group controls Western Union, refrain from selling - to himself or to his affiliates - businesses that will remain after AT&T buys the Business Services unit. They also asked for LeBow to be prohibited from selling his notes and stock. If such an agreement is not reached by Dec. 5, the bondholders said they begin steps to force the company into involuntary bankruptcy. Western Union told the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing Tuesday that its three top executives - President Robert Amman, Chief Financial Officer Stewart J. Paperin and general counsel John C. Walters - have talked with the the Brooke Group about other jobs within the parent company. Bechtel said that despite the job talks, the three are working full time to solve Western Union's liquidity crisis. When asked why the three were discussing other jobs while the company teetered on the edge of financial collapse, Bechtel replied, ``What do you want me to say?'' The company, based in Upper Saddle River in northern New Jersey, expects the closing of its transaction with AT&T will occur simultaneously with the completion of its bond repurchase offer. In the previous exchange offer, Western Union offered to buy up to $530 million of its high-yield junk bonds for a package of new notes, cash and shares of common stock. The company had sought to exchange at least 95 percent of its 19\ percent notes and 80 percent of its 16 percent notes. The amount tendered was 64 percent of the 19 percent notes and 5 percent of the 16 percent notes. The 19\ percent notes were selling at 21\ cents on the dollar, and the 16 percent notes at 40 cents. Western Union's failure to make a profit since 1984 has apparently not dented the earnings of its top officials. Amman, who took charge in 1988, received a 23 percent raise in 1990, to $525,000. Paperin received a 26 percent raise, to $310,000. Year-end bonuses have not been figured, but in 1989 Amman received a $237,500 bonus and Paperin a $120,000 bonus. In addition, Western Union pays LeBow a $200,000 monthly management fee, or $2.4 million a year. Western Union's woes stem from missed opportunity and the march of technology, Lehmann said. When AT&T split up into regional ``Baby Bells,'' Western Union had a telephone network in place and could have competed with AT&T, MCI Communications Corp. and U.S. Sprint for long-distance services. ``They were a viable contender, but they continued to plod along and focused on telex business and electronic mail,'' Lehmann said. Telex revenues plunged after the fax business exploded. Western Union's Bechtel voiced optimism that the company has a future. But Lehmann said the company has been so busy dismantling itself to raise cash that the chances are slim that a viable company will remain.

DOC.HEAD: GM Predicts 4th-Quarter Operating Loss, Plans More Production Cuts
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. says it will suffer an operating loss in the current quarter, its first quarterly red ink on operations since recession-wracked 1981. While the automaker posted a record net loss of $2 billion in the third quarter, that was due to a $2.1 billion writeoff for plant closings, which overwhelmed a $109 million profit on continuing operations. GM Chairman Robert Stempel told a Fort Wayne, Ind., business group Thursday night that the world's leading automaker expects its fourth-quarter operating results ``will decline significantly'' from the third quarter. Stempel didn't say whether that would mean an operating loss, but GM spokesman Terrence Sullivan in Detroit said, ``It certainly implies a loss in the fourth quarter.'' Sullivan said GM didn't have a prediction on the size of the loss. The company also did not comment on whether it would post a net loss. But analyst Ronald Glantz of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in San Francisco predicted GM would post a net loss of $150 million to $250 million in the quarter. Analyst Arvid Jouppi of Detroit-based Arvid Jouppi Associates Inc. wasn't as pessimistic. ``I think there's still a chance General Motors will make money in the fourth quarter. They and Ford (Motor Co.) to some degree will give up the rebate wars. The fact is, they're not getting enough money for the cars they sell.'' GM's expected poor showing in the latest quarter comes despite a new round of production cutbacks, Stempel told the Greater Fort Wayne Chamber of Commerce. The lower production reflects an erosion of consumer confidence stemming in part from the Persian Gulf crisis, Stempel said. GM said earlier this month that it was cutting fourth-quarter production by 181,000 vehicles. Stempel said Thursday that the automaker was reducing production by an additional 111,000 cars and trucks. Both reductions will leave GM with plans to build 1.07 million cars and trucks at its U.S. and Canadian plants during the quarter, a total below that of the third quarter of 1990 and the fourth quarter of 1989. The cutbacks might extend the Christmas-to-New Year's Day holiday break for some of GM's 280,000 hourly workers. ``What GM is saying is that `We are not going to get caught with a surplus of cars that we have to sell (with) extreme rebates and have to shut the plants down in January and February,' as they did in 1990,'' Jouppi said. ``They're making a more realistic schedule for the 1991s than they did for the 1990s,'' he said. ``This is a much larger cut than I anticipated,'' said analyst Wendy Needham of Smith Barney Harris Upham & Co. ``Basically, they want to get as much of the pain behind them before 1991 starts.'' GM last lost money on automotive operations in the second quarter of 1981 - which, according to Stempel, was roughly the midpoint of the last severe drop in consumer confidence. Other automakers also are affected by crumbling consumer confidence, Stempel said. ``Many people have been taking a `wait and see' attitude toward major purchase decisions. For the auto industry, this has translated into weaker automotive demand that has meant temporary plant shutdowns and layoffs,'' he said. ``While GM's overall U.S. market share continues to show gains, as it has for the entire 1990 calendar year, we are determined to keep our inventories in line with demand.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Preparing for the Unthinkable: Failure of Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, Hills and ... to add dropped first reference to U.S. trade representative Carla Hills; Picks up 7th graf pvs, ``We simply ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is beginning to prepare for what it used to say was unthinkable - the possibility that the four-year effort to overhaul the global trading system could end in failure. The talks, which involve 107 nations, are scheduled to wind up next week with five days of marathon bargaining starting Monday in Brussels. The United States will be represented by a 280-member official delegation, including four members of President Bush's Cabinet. The talks, being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are known as the Uruguay Round, for the Latin American nation where they were launched in 1986. The talks are in danger of failing because of a wide split between the United States and the 12-nation European Community over the farm subsidy question. The EC, with its 10 million farmers, has been unwilling to give up its complex system of subsidies. While the president this week said, ``we must not let the Uruguay Round fail,'' other officials have begun to talk openly of what the United States will do if that occurs. U.S. trade representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter have discussed the possibility that the United States will more aggressively pursue unilateral measures, using the threat of retaliation unless other countries open their markets to American goods. ``We simply are not going to be tolerant of continued unfair trading practices where we believe those are disadvantageous to the United States,'' Yeutter said, adding that failure of the Uruguay Round would cause the United States to ``very aggressively'' use the tools at its disposal to open markets. Yeutter said a GATT failure also would intensify the push to reach bilateral free trade agreements with various countries along the lines of the U.S.-Canada free trade deal. Some believe it was not a coincidence that Bush spent two days this week visiting Mexico to promote such an arrangement with America's southern neighbor. The danger in these activities, many economists believe, is that world trade could begin to shrink as trade tensions intensify and countries split into warring trading blocs. The unity achieved by the West in four decades of the Cold War could disintegrate into a global trade war, according to this doomsday scenario. The GATT negotiating structure was created in 1947 as an effort to prevent a recurrence of the 1930s trade wars, which played a part in the Great Depression and the global economic disputes that boiled over into World War II. In this round of talks, the administration had high hopes of achieving a vastly expanded package to cover more than $1 trillion of world trade not now under global rules. The administration sought to dramatically reduce farm subsidies that rob U.S. and other farmers of foreign sales, to remove barriers keeping American service companies such as banks and insurance firms out of foreign markets and to wipe out copyright piracy and counterfeiting, which cost U.S. businesses an estimated $60 billion in lost sales annually. The United States has insisted that without sharp reductions in farm subsidies, farm exporting Third World nations will not go along with other trade reforms in areas such as services and copyright protection. ``We need fundamental reform in agriculture. A mini-deal will not achieve either the international support or the U.S. domestic support we need,'' said an administration official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Key members of Congress, including Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, and Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., have added their backing to the administration's hard-line negotiating stance. ``If the Uruguay Round were to fail, we have many avenues to pursue in an attempt to open markets,'' Baucus said. ``We should not be ideologically wedded only to a multilateral approach to trade issues. We should take a more pragmatic approach and use whatever works best to open markets.'' But some observers see danger in the willingness of U.S. policymakers to walk away from the Uruguay Round, especially with recessionary storm clouds building around the world. ``With the threat of war, uncertain financial markets, the savings and loan crisis and everything else, this is a lousy time to have a headline that would read `World Trade Talks Collapse,''' said William Brock, former trade representative in the Reagan administration. ``I think we would take a terrible risk in economic terms.''

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Jobs To Go at British Aerospace
DOC.TEXT: Britain's leading defense contractor, British Aerospace, is closing two factories and cutting 5,000 jobs because of a worldwide reduction in orders for military aircraft, the company said Friday. The company's Kingston, south London, factory which makes fuselages for the Britain's Harrier jet fighters, will be closed by the end of 1992, with the loss of 2,000 jobs. The Preston, northern England, plant which makes the Tornado jet fighter and the European Fighter Aircraft will close by early 1993, with the loss of 3,000 jobs. The company said the work would be transferred to other British Aerospace plants. British Aerospace said it hoped to shed 5,000 employees from its workforce of 27,000 by attrition rather than layoffs. A company statement said the plant closures were forced ``both by advances in technology and by the changing international market.''

DOC.HEAD: Digital Radio Broadcasts Begin in Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts first three grafs to CLARIFY that satellite is in geo-stationary orbit, sted spinning around the world and that the signal still received by electronic equipment on the ground. Pickup 4th, `Because the... SUBS 9th graf pvs, ``Radio GIGA ... to CORRECT `sympathy'' to ``symphony.'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Listeners tuned in to a radio station today that broadcasts digital signals to the entire nation from a satellite, in what its developers say is a first. Unlike AM and FM radio broadcasts, which suffer from static, hiss and limited frequency response, the station beams signals directly from a satellite to listeners in digital form, similar to the system used by compact discs. ``That results in sound quality that is far better than FM radio, and equals that on CDs,'' said Tadanobu Kishi, an official in the Ministry of Posts and Communications. Because the broadcasts are digital, listeners with digital audio tape recorders can make recordings that are virtually perfect copies of the original master tapes. But to receive the new digital station, listeners need a small satellite dish and a special tuner that can be attached to a television set to receive TV broadcasts from the same satellite. Starting in April, its commercial-free broadcasts will be scrambled and lengthened from 12 to 24 hours a day, and consumers will need to buy a $200 decoder and pay a $4.60 monthly fee. ``Since we're the first in the world, we want to try to make it as popular as possible,'' said Yoko Ogame, a Satellite Digital Audio Broadcasting Co. official. Radio GIGA (its frequency is measured in gigahertz) began broadcasting today with a special ``Earth Symphony'' that featured the sounds of waves at the Seychelle Islands, whale songs off Maui Island, a moonlight walk in Tennessee and midnight in a Japanese forest. The Ministry of Posts and Communications hopes the station and 18 other digital satellite stations to follow next year, will offer a broader range of programming than current commercial broadcasts. Most areas in Japan have few radio stations, in part because of a ministry policy that required equal facilities for all parts of the archipelago. Tokyo's 12 million people have only four FM stations - two commercial, one public and one that carries school lectures. The company hopes to have up to 700,000 paying customers within two years. Its radio format will consist of ``relaxing'' music from a variety of styles with a minimum of talk, Ms. Ogame said. Owned by a consortium of companies, the station shares a sttellite channel, or transponder, with Japan Satellite Broadcasting, a private satellite TV station that also began broadcasting on Friday and owns 10 percent of Satellite Digital. Japan has been a pioneer in direct-broadcast satellites, which are more powerful than regular communications satellites and beam signals directly to platter-size antennas at consumers' homes. The public Japan Broadcasting Corp., NHK, operates the country's two other satellite TV channels. More commercial channels are expected when another satellite becomes operational next year. That satellite also will boost the number of digital radio stations to 19, Kishi said. Stations will be able to broadcast commercials if they wish, ``but we've asked that they be commercial-free if they scramble more than half their broadcasts.'' Some cable TV systems in the United States have offered digital audio, and a few TV stations have conducted localized test audio broadcasts on unused UHF channels. NHK says about 3.2 million households pay about $7.70 a month to watch its unscrambled satellite TV broadcasts. Many more have purchased satellite tuners, industry officials say. ``We welcome additional stations as a step toward the coming era of satellite broadcasting,'' NHK spokesman Takehiko Motohashi said. ``But while satellites are good for unified national broadcasting, regular land-based broadcasts are best for localized news and programming.''

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Delivers First MD-11 Jumbo Jet
DOC.TEXT: Finland's national airline, Finair, took ownership of McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s first MD-11 jumbo jet. The three-engine MD-11 is built by the company's Douglas Aircraft Co. in Long Beach. McDonnell Douglas has pinned hopes for a Douglas turnaround on the MD-11, the long-distance, fuel-efficient successor to its DC-10. St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas hopes the program will generate $40 billion in revenues during the next five years. The aircraft giant has invested more than $700 million to develop the MD-11 and $2.8 billion in production inventory buildup. Speaking to a crowd of more than 1,000 invited guests and employees at a ceremony Thursday at which the new plane was rolled out, Douglas President Robert Hood declared the delivery an ``event of triumph and joy.'' ``Our choice of the MD-11 was strongly influenced by the excellent reliability of our DC-10 trijets,'' said Esko Kukkonen, Finnair's executive vice president for operations. Airlines have given McDonnell Douglas 375 commitments to purchase MD-11s, including 174 firm orders. The ceremony was a bright moment for McDonnell Douglas, which was hit by bad news this week with a report that the Air Force estimates Douglas will lose $600 million on its C-17 cargo plane because of cost overruns on fixed price contracts. McDonnell Douglas officials disputed that, saying they still hope the C-17 program can avoid losses. The Air Force plans to buy 120 C-17s for $30 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Blame Saddam for Saturday's Gas Tax Increase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, Flying and ... to describe non-commerical aviation fuel. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Drivers will pay as much as 5.1 cents a gallon more for gasoline starting Saturday, and they won't be able to blame Saddam Hussein. A federal tax increase is taking effect, and half of the $25 billion it produces over the next five years will go for deficit reduction. Most of the rest will pay for highway and mass transit improvements. A family that drives 12,000 miles in a car that averages 22 miles per gallon will pay about $28 more a year. Flying and shipping by air also will cost more beginning Saturday. The 8 percent federal tax on airline tickets will rise to 10 percent and the 5 percent levy on air freight will go up to 6.25 percent. Those increases, when combined with higher taxes on non-commercial aviation fuel used by private planes, will bring in almost $12 billion over five years. Nothing in the law says service station owners must pass along the higher gasoline and diesel tax to consumers - but economics indicates they will. ``Prices will go up at 12:01 a.m.,'' predicted Dave Haddad Sr. of Pittsburgh, president of the Service Station Dealers of America. ``Half the retailers are making one, two or three cents profit on a gallon,'' he said. ``How can they eat a nickel a gallon? Retailers have no alternative but to increase the price by five cents a gallon.'' The new federal tax on gasoline used on highways or in motorboats will be 14.1 cents a gallon; the tax on diesel for highway use, 20.1 cents. Diesel used by trains will face a new 2.5 cent tax. The tax on non-commercial aviation gasoline will rise to 15.1 cents and the levy on non-commercial jet fuel goes to 17.6 cents a gallon. The nickel-a-gallon boost for gasoline follows the price runup that hit after Aug. 2, when Iraqi President Saddam invaded Kuwait, shutting off most of the oil from both those Persian Gulf nations. Jerry Cheske of American Automobile Association headquarters in Orlando, Fla., said that as of Tuesday, the national average price of a gallon of customer-pumped regular unleaded gasoline was $1.366. That was up 0.7 cents from a week earlier and 29.1 cents above the Aug. 1 average. If most retailers boost their prices by the full 5 or 5.1 cents a gallon, the nationwide average price would rise to about $1.41 a gallon. Before the tax was raised, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that almost 94 percent of households buy motor fuel and will pay an average of $990 for it this year. With state taxes included, the average tax on gasoline in the United States last year was 30 cents a gallon. That compares with $3.05 in Italy, $2.76 in Denmark and $2.34 in France and Ireland. The last federal tax increase was 5 cents a gallon in 1983. The latest increase was passed by Congress in October as part of a plan to reduce the federal deficit by nearly $500 billion over the next five years. The increase includes 5 cents that will be divided between highway improvements and deficit reduction, and 0.1 cent per gallon to clean up leaking underground storage tanks. The Highway Trust Fund, which finances most federal highway and bridge construction, will get 2.5 cents of the increase. The mass transit side of the highway fund, which has been getting 1 cent of the 9-cent gas and diesel tax, will get 1{ cents of the 14.1-cent levy. The increased taxes on airline tickets and cargo, expected to bring in about $4 billion over five years, will go for deficit reduction for the next two years, then into the trust fund that finances airport and airway improvements. An estimated $50 million a year of taxes that otherwise would go to the highway fund will be drained off to finance restoration of wetlands. That is the tax likely to be collected from the sale of gasoline used for such non-highway machinery as lawn mowers, snow blowers, chain saws and leaf mulchers.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC To Give Freedom National Bank Depositors 50 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A New York congressman says the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. did only ``half the right thing'' by deciding to pay depositors of the defunct Freedom National Bank 50 percent of their uninsured balances. Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., announced on Thursday night that the FDIC had authorized payment to uninsured clients of the Harlem-based bank such as churches and charitable organizations. Freedom National, the nation's fourth-largest black-owned bank, closed its doors earlier this month. Alan Witney, an FDIC spokesman in Washington, confirmed Rangel's announcement. ``That's a good first step, but I still insist that when the government tells people their money is insured and that it is safe, they really mean that,'' Rangel said. ``The FDIC has done half the right thing.'' The FDIC only insures deposits of up to $100,000. Many local charities - including Harlem- and Brooklyn-based organizations providing day care, foster care, housing and victims assistance - had multiple accounts in the bank with totals that exceeded that amount. The FDIC said checks would go out ``in a couple of days'' to depositors who had filed claims, Rangel said. But the congressman whose district includes parts of Harlem said ``the FDIC has a long way to go to make things up to the depositors at Freedom National and to the community, whom they failed to give any time to either withdraw their money or to make other arrangements.'' Rangel said he would continue his efforts for full compensation to the depositors. ``There is still a double standard between the treatment accorded the depositors at Freedom and those at a number of larger banks,'' said Rangel. ``In the cases of several large failing banks ... the FDIC prevented any losses at all to the depositors.'' Freedom National was founded in 1964 as a financial resource for Harlem. It lost $4 million over the past two years before being closed down by federal regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Fire at Stock Exchange Forces Closing Until Monday
DOC.TEXT: Trading on the Brussels stock exchange was cancelled Friday after a fire forced officials to close the building. The exchange is expected to reopen Monday. No one was hurt in the early morning fire which broke out in a second floor high power room and reached the roof. Firemen quickly controlled it and the exchange's main trading computer did not seem damaged but smoke left a layer of soot on most of the building's interior, including brokers' desks, screens and telephones. Stock Exchange Prsident Jean Peterbroeck said repair and cleaning would be carried out through the weekend and trading would resume Monday. It was the second time this year that a fire closed the bourse.

The stock market posted modest losses this morning in a continuation of a pullback that began mid-week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 6.19 points at 2,512.62 after the first half hour of trading. Decliners outnumbered advancing issues by almost 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 325 up, 591 down and 504 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.01 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. But analysts said the market seemed to avoid overreacting to bearish news, such as the United Nations action authorizing the use of force against Iraq if it does not withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15 and a disappointing report on the economic outlook at General Motors. ``It's absorbing it in a way it did not one or two months ago,'' said analyst Jack Solomon at Bear, Stearns & Co. ``Now, it seems to be isolated rather than contagion.'' GM fell } to 36\ after saying its operating net would fall in the fourth quarter as it cuts back vehicle production. The NYSE's composite index was off .35 at 172.79. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell .65 to 299.22. On Thursday the Dow lost 16.34 points to close at 2,518.81. Losing issues outnumbered gaining ones by about 9 to 7 with 839 down, 655 up and 514 unchanged. The NYSE's composite index declined 0.76 to 173.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.90 to 299.87.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Approve Sale of Great American Branches
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators approved the sale of Great American Bank's California operations to Wells Fargo & Co., but also issued a case-and-desist order to the thrift in approving its revised capital plan. The approval of the sale calls for Great American to hand over 130 retail branches in the state with $6.4 billion in deposits to Wells Fargo for approximately $491 million. But the Office of Thrift Supervision (OTS) warned in the order issued Thursday that a violation of the revised capital plan would result in possible seizure of what remains of Great American or its submission to a merger or acquisition negotiated on behalf of the OTS. Great American's capital plan reflects the anticipated effect of the transaction with Wells Fargo and details Great American's plans for achieving compliance with new capital requirements by the end of 1994. Great American chief executive Robert Kemper said approval of the revised capital plan ``was a major step forward for this institution,'' and was confident it could meet the stringent provisions outlined under the plan. ``We wouldn't have put together a capital plan if we felt we couldn't accomplish it,'' Kemper said. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, Wells Fargo's primary regulator, approved the Great American sale in late October. The OTS and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. did not announce their approval until Thursday. Great American will be left with roughly $9 billion in assets and 81 retail branches in Arizona, Washington and Colorado and a huge problem loan portfolio.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Prices Turn Mixed After Stronger Opening
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices turned mixed after a strong opening this morning on the CHicago Board of Trade, where the action again was dominated by speculation about Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. The markets opened higher amid unconfirmed rumors that President Bush was prepared to waive a trade law that requires the Soviets to Liberalize their emigration policies before becoming eligible for U.S. food export credit guarantees, analysts said. Profit-taking quickly eroded gains in the soybean market but corn remained mostly stronger in reaction to lighter-than-expected delivery notices posted today against the December contract. Corn also was supported by unconfirmed talk the Soviet UNion or Eastern European countries may have bought at least 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn overnight. Wheat drew strength from the Agriculture Department's confirmation that the Soviets bought 16,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat flour at subsidized prices. DOn Roose, grain analyst with U.S. Commodities Inc., said time is running out for the United States to offer export credits to the Soviets for large food purchases. ``They're picking the stuff up around the world. If we don't do it in the next week or two, it's just going to be too late,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to 3} cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.42} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.26 a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1} cents higher with December at $1.09 a bushel; and soybeans were 2\ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.92} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .58 cent lower with December at 78.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .05 cent higher with January at 87.45 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .30 cent lower with December at 50.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .65 cent lower to 1.15 cents higher with February at 65.80 cents a pound. Cattle futures rose on Thursday; pork futures fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Tokheim Plans to Close Tennessee Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Tokheim Corp., a major manufacturer of service station gasoline pumps, said Friday it will close its Newbern, Tenn., assembly plant to reduce manufacturing costs and become more competitive. Operations at the Tennessee plant, which currently employs 308 people, will be consolidated into the Fort Wayne fabrication and machining plant by the late summer of 1991, the company said. Tokheim officials said a new contract with members of the United Auto Workers union at the Fort Wayne factory was a main factor in their decision to relocate the Newbern operations to northeastern Indiana. The agreement extends to April 1997 and contains a no-strike provision until April 2000. ``The new contract allows for much greater flexibility within our manufacturing group at a competitive labor cost,'' said DOnald E. Rhodes, senior vice president of manufacturing. Rhodes added that the plant consolidation will allow the company to increase productivity and improve quality while reducing response time to customer orders. The Newbern plant will be sold. Workers who do not relocate to Fort Wayne or receive another position with the company will be provided with severance and placement programs. Fourth-quarter net earnings will reflect a one-time, after tax charge of about $1.1 million to $1.4 million, or 17 to 22 cents per Share, representing the estimated net costs and expenses directly associated with the plant closing, the company said. Because of the consolidation, net earnings are expected to improve by up to 40 cents per share beginning in 1992. Tokheim designs and manufactures electronic petroleum marketing and monitoring systems, including service station equipment and card-activated transaction systems. The company also designs and produces process control automation systems for the natural gas, oil, petrochemical, process water and agriculture markets.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Gain on Bush Comments
DOC.TEXT: Treasury bond prices moved sharply higher today after President Bush announced he was sending Secretary of State James Baker III to Iraq for talks aimed at ending the Middle EAst crisis. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond gained ] point, or $3.75 per $1,000 in face amount, by midday. Its yield, which moves in an opposite direction from the bond's price, fell to 8.45 percent from 8.49 percent late Thursday. Analysts said the bond market was heartened by the prospect that war in the Middle East might be averted through diplomatic Channels. On Thursday, bond prices slumped after the U.N. Security Council approved a resolution allowing the use of military force to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait. But there was still some caution in the market. Immediately after Bush's announcement, bond prices surged | point higher but they gave up some ground as some traders decided to take some quick profits. The market was focused on the Persian Gulf, and had little reaction to the news that the government's chief economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, fell 1.2 percent in October, its fourth straight monthly decline. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 3-32 point to [ point, intermediate maturities gained 3-16 point to \ point, and long-term issues rose between \ point and 5-16 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.25 to 1,172.07. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.22 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 7.01 percent. Yields on six-month bills slipped to 7.33 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 6.99 percent. Yields on one-year bills dropped to 7.29 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 6.83 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 7{ percent, down from 7 9-16 point late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Gillette Threatens To Close Boston Plant if Ozone-Protection Law Approved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `About 1,200...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with company statement hedging on threat, add figure on how many plant employs. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Mullaney said... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Gillette Co. is threatening to close the world's largest razor blade plant in Boston if the city bans ozone-depleting chemicals. The City Council is considering outlawing chemicals that, when released into the atmosphere, deplete the ozone layer protecting the Earth from damaging rays from the sun. At a hearing Thursday, Gillette Vice Chairman Joseph E. Mullaney said the ban would put the company at a significant competitive disadvantage, and if the bill is adopted, Gillette will close its plant in the South Boston section by January 1992. A statement from the company this morning soft-pedaled the threat somewhat, saying if the proposed ordinance is approved, Gillette ``will make any necessary decisions at that time.'' Joan Fitzgerald, a Gillette spokeswoman, said the company hoped a compromise wording for the ordinance could be worked out. The Gillette plant employs 3,100 people. Mullaney said Gillette uses the chemicals to coat the edges of razor blades and to clean equipment. The Du Pont Co., which provides the blade-coating chemicals, says it is searching for substitutes, and Gillette already has found some for the cleaning chemicals, Mullaney said. The proposed law would cost the company money by requiring labels starting Jan. 1 on all razors and packages of blades made at the plant, saying they were made with chemicals harmful to ozone. A year later, the substances would be banned. Mullaney said the company supports efforts to save the ozone but the Boston ban, coming on top of national and international efforts, would create varying standards and confusion. Gillette reformulated all of its domestic aerosol products in 1977 to replace chlorofluorocarbon propellants with propellants that do not affect the upper atmosphere, Mullaney said. Mark Sommer, an activist with the Greenpeace environmental organization, said similar bans in Newark, N.J., and Irvine, Calif., ``haven't resulted in one job loss or company relocation.'' Secretary of State Michael J. Connolly submitted testimony through an aide saying he supported the ban if it allows companies to seek exemptions on a hardship basis. Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce President James L. Sullivan said the ban would have a catastrophic effect on businesses and a negligible impact on saving the ozone layer.

DOC.HEAD: Restructuring to Result in $52 Million Annual Loss, Elimination of 140 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Society for Savings said today it will sell about $1.6 billion worth of assets in a restructuring that will result in a $52 million loss for the year and the elimination of 140 jobs. Society for Savings Bancorp Inc., the bank's parent company, said the bank needs to jettison about $130 million in non-performing commercial real estate loans and other assets to reduce expenses and remain competitive as New England's economy deteriorates. The bank will also increase its reserve fund to $103.5 million, up from the $49.5 million as of Sept. 30. ``The steps ... reflect a careful assessment of the prevailing industry conditions and the New England regional environment affecting the bank,'' the bank company said in its announcement. Meanwhile, the parent company announced that Elliott Miller will retire as president and chief executive officer as of Jan. 1 after 12 years as president. The projected 1990 loss includes a $58.6 million charge for severance payments and other restructuring expenses. The bank expects a fourth-quarter loss of $54.4 million, or $4.57 a share. The loss for the year amounts to $4.37 a share. The restructuring will take place in three stages over the next 13 months under a plan approved by the parent company's board of directors. First, the bank will sell a ``significant portion'' of its securities portfolio and selected loans portfolios of performing assets. Then it will sell about $130 million worth of non-performing commercial real estate loans and real estate the bank itself owns. Finally, the bank will try to sell certain other assets and lines of business. Gains from such sales will not be recorded until realized. The 140 jobs being eliminated represent about 15 percent of the bank's work force. That doesn't include those personnel who may work for business lines being sold off.

DOC.HEAD: LEading Indicators Fell in October
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf, 6th graf, ``The increase ... to reflect full Bush quote on economy. ALso moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell in October for the fourth straight month, signaling a recession that many economists say already has arrived. President Bush said today the economy is ``at best in a serious slowdown'' that could worsen. Leading Economic Indicators was the latest in a string of gloomy reports on the economy. Eight of the 11 forward-looking components in the index fell. In addition, the department said, the index actually dropped 0.1 percent in July rather than remaining unchanged as first reported. Three consecutive declines in the index have been viewed as a fairly reliable - although not infallible - sign that a recession is approaching. The gauge is designed to forecast economic conditions six to nine months in advance. Bush linked the economic downturn to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and said the new democracies in Eastern Europe also have been hurt by Saddam Hussein's actions. ``The increase in oil prices resulting directly from Saddam is hurting our country, too,'' Bush said at a nationally televised news conference. ``OUr economy, as I said the other day, is at best in a serious slowdown. And if uncertainty remains in the energy markets, the slowdown will get worse.'' they believe a recession already has started. Even Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, usually cautious about characterizing the economy, said this week it now is in a ``meaningful downturn.'' ``The October leading indicators contained clear, classical signs that we are in a recession,'' said William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of COmmerce. ``Instead of foretelling a recession that is a few months away, those indicators show that it already has started.'' Bush told a group of bankers Thursday that ``the slowdown or the recession or whatever one would call exactly what we're in now'' will be a short one. The index also sank 1.2 percent in August, the steepest decline since a 1.4 percent drop a month after the October 1987 stock market crash. It slid an additional 0.8 percent in September. There has not been a recession since World War II without the index turning down for at least three consecutive months. ON the other hand, the gauge was negative for six months in 1984 and again for four months following the 1987 crash. Both times, the economy escaped a recession. PUlling the index down were a dropin a figure measuring consumer confidence, an increase in weekly unemployment claims, a Decline in the average workweek, a drop in building permits, a decline in the money supply, falling stock prices, a decrease in the price of raw materials, and faster business delivery times. The only positive contributors were increases in orders for Consumer goods, orders for new plants and equipment and in unfilled Orders. The various changes left the index at 141.6 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and down 1.9 percent from its level a year ago. The index has fallen during six of the 10 months so far this year. Since most of the components are announced earlier, many economists view the index more as a useful statistic in summarizing economic events than a genuine ``leading indicator.'' ``I would not say it's gospel'' in forecasting recessions, said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International. ``We should never think there is one single measure that can capture all of the flavor of the modern, sophisticated economy.'' ``It's like asking a painter to paint the most beautiful picture in the world using only one color,'' Brusca added. ``The painter might find it to be a very interesting challenge, but I doubt the work would be without serious shortfalls.'' Laurence H Meyer, economist for a St. Louis economic forecasting firm, maintains the Persian Gulf crisis pre-empted the advance warning this time. ``What we had was an economy thatsliding toward a recession ... then got hit with a series of adverse shocks which pushed it over the edge very abruptly,'' he said. Meyer and other economists also note that better inventory management has cut into the index's lead-time in recent years. ``Production cutbacks are following demand much more closely so we're not seeing inventory pile up as demand softens,'' he said. ``We're not getting the normal lead time.'' IN past recessions, there were major inventory accumulations which caused severe production cutbacks as businesses attempted to sell their backlogs. That in turn caused the loss of jobs and worsened the downturn.

DOC.HEAD: Sorgenti to Retire as CEO of Arco Chemical
DOC.TEXT: Harold A. Sorgenti, president and chief executive officer of Arco Chemical Co., will take early retirement effective next June, the chemical company said Friday. Alan R. Hirsig, president of Arco Chemical Europe and a vice president of the parent company, has been selected his successor. Sorgenti, 56, joined Arco's predecessor, Atlantic Refining Co., in 1959. He was named president of the Arco Chemical Division in 1979. In 1987, Arco Chemical Co. was reconstructed as a separate subsidiary of the Atlantic-Richfield Co. and Sorgenti was elected to his present position. Hirsig, 51, will take over Jan. 1. A 29-year employee of the company, he has worked in a number of research and managerial positions. Arco Chemical makes and markets intermediate chemicals and specialty goods, such as urethanes and solvents, tertiary butyl alcohol and styrene monomer.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Chairman of Ashland Oil Spared Prison Sentence
LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: Orin E. Atkins, the former chairman of Ashland Oil Inc., was sentenced Friday to probation and community service for trying to sell confidential company documents to Iran. U.S. District Judge Charles S. Haight of Manhattan said that although he felt Atkins had committed a serious crime, he decided prison time was not warranted because Atkins cooperated with prosecutors and agreed to pay restitution to Ashland. The restitution settlement, announced in court by Ashland attorney John C. Elam, calls for Atkins to forgo more than $2 million in consulting fees and pension benefits and repay $250,000. Haight sentenced Atkins to two years' probation and 600 hours of community service. The judge imposed no additional fine, citing Atkins' diminished finances. Atkins, 66, of North Palm Beach, Fla., pleaded guilty in September 1989 to conspiracy and wire fraud and agreed to cooperate with the government. He had faced a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Atkins admitted that after he resigned as chairman in 1981 but remained as a paid Ashland consultant, he obtained confidential documents involving the company's decision not to pay the National Iranian Oil Co. for $283 million in crude oil purchased in 1979. The company said it withheld payment because of a trade ban on Iran that the United States imposed following the taking of American hostages at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in November 1979. Atkins and others involved in the scheme offered to sell the documents to the Iranian company for use in a possible lawsuit against Ashland over its non-payment. The documents were offered at various times for $20 million or a 25 percent contingency fee. While the Iranians never bought the documents, they later sued Ashland and last year obtained a $325 million settlement, which with interest was worth more than $500 million. In a statement to the court before sentencing, Atkins described the embarrassment and anguish his acts caused his family and friends. ``I have no excuses for my actions other than I think anger or some resentment obviously short-circuited my brain,'' Atkins said. His attorney, James Moss, asked Haight to impose only probation, saying Atkins had been punished enough. Moss said the restitution agreement with Ashland had left his client in ``almost financial destitution.'' The judge said he believed Atkins' role in the scheme was an isolated occurrence. ``This act of venal criminality was aberrational,'' Haight said. ``It stands in stark contrast to everything else he had done, said or attempted to do.'' As part of his cooperation with prosecutors, Atkins testified earlier this year at the trial of an attorney, Charles Barnett, who was accused of participating in the scheme to sell the Ashland documents to the Iranian company. Barnett, of Palm Beach, Fla., was acquitted. A third defendant, oil broker Roy Furmark, pleaded guilty to a role in the conspiracy and is scheduled to be sentenced in federal court on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda Buys Cray Supercomputer
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Corp., one of Japan's major automakers, said Friday it has purchased a high-performance supercomputer from U.S.-based Cray Research Inc. in an effort to improve its automotive research and development ability. It said the new computer, the Y-MP2E-216, offers about three times higher performance than the Cray X-MP-216 model that Mazda bought from the Minneapolis, Minnesota-based manufacturer in April 1989. Mazda officials said they expect the new model will increase the company's computer simulation capacity in such areas as crash analysis for improving vehicle safety and vehicle structural analysis for weight reduction. Business sources said the new supercomputer would cost about $10 million. Supercomputers are high-capacity machines that can quickly perform calculations on vast amounts of figures.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Investors Group Says Get Out of Junk Funds Before It's Too Late
DOC.TEXT: Bond Investors Association Inc. is offering some advice to junk bond mutual fund investors: Get out before it's too late. The non-profit organization tracks bond defaults and predicts $50 billion in junk bonds will go bad in 1991 and 1992. Mutual funds that invested in the dismal junk bond market are holding many bonds they would happily sell if they could find buyers, the Miami Lakes, Fla.-based association said. Because the funds have been forced to sell their liquid holdings as investors cash in shares, the funds are left with default-vulnerable and hard-to-sell issues, said C. Richard Lehman, BIA president. That leads to a number of problems, according to Lehman, including the possibility that the bond funds will default at a rate higher than the market as a whole. On top of that, the group says, the bond funds' daily net asset values, or their net worth, are routinely overstated. If the bond funds could actually sell their unwanted securities, the bonds' market prices would likely plummet, bringing down the net asset value, BIA said. ``A fund holder who is selling his shares is being overpaid relative to the realizable value of the portfolio,'' BIA said in the December edition of the Defaulted Bonds Newsletter. ``The only benefit fund holders still have is the ability to liquidate their holdings even while their fund cannot,'' the association said. BIA did not mention particular mutual funds. ``We decided not to try to finger the specific candidates, although we could,'' Lehman said. Junk bond fund managers were not willing to talk about the report. A spokeswoman for the Investment Company Institute, Betty Hart, said investors frequently hedge their risk by diversifying investments. ``There are a number of different types of mutual funds with varying objectives and, generally speaking, for any fund that is highly aggressive, whether it be equities or bonds, good financial planning principles suggest people have more than one investment,'' Ms. Hart said. BIA also takes the bond funds to task for their accounting methods. The group wants the Securities and Exchange Commission to force the funds to set aside some of the interest income to cover losses expect from defaults. ``This is not unlike a business concern that sells its products on credit to high risk customers without booking a provision for uncollectible accounts receivable,'' the newsletter said. There is good news, though. If the junk bond market is going to recover, the gains could be huge. BIA suggests investors who want to stay in junk bonds should sell their current fund holding and buy into a newly established fund or one with assets of less than $100 million. BIA says go ahead and pay the typical 5 percent front-end load. ``A new fund should outperform an existing fund by many times this cost,'' the newsletter said. The junk funds have been feeling heat lately. The collapse of the market has sent prices reeling and their corresponding yields soaring. The Securities and Exchange Commission in October asked the funds to make it clear to potential investors that high yield means high risk. The bonds' prices have been beaten down as the market has become more worrisome that a recession will make it hard, if not impossible, for some issuers to make interest and principal payments.

DOC.HEAD: First Shares Offered In State-Run Companies
DOC.TEXT: Poles lined up at banks Friday to buy shares in the first five state-run companies to be privatized under the country's post-Communist economic reforms. A Western-style advertising campaign with sophisticated graphics tried to educate potential buyers on how the investments work, where to purchase shares and what risks to consider. ``Learn the power of your money,'' the advertisements say. Five companies, considered to be the better run and more efficient from the beleaguered socialized economy, are being privatized in the first round of economic reforms. They are the Krosno glass works, the Kielce construction company Exbud, the Lodz textile company Prochnik, a Silesian cable factory and Tonsil, an audio equipment company. Share prices ranged from 50,000 zlotys, about $5, to 112,000 zlotys, or $12. The minimum purchase was five shares. Ultimately, some 7,000 companies, accounting for more than 80 percent of the Polish economy, are to be transferred from state to private ownership or otherwise liquidated in the drive to create a capitalist economy and an investment market. Government economists devised complex systems for selling off the companies, reserving up to 20 percent of shares for workers at lower prices, retaining some for the state treasury and limiting the portion that can be purchased by foreigners. By late January, the shares will be allocated to buyers, although the shares will be held by the national banks until a stock market is created. At two Warsaw banks, 1,500 applications for the first offring were received by 3 p.m., with the average purchase put at 10 million zlotys, or about $1,050, state television reported. Oversubscription was expected for most of the companies, although uncertainty caused by the presidential campaign now under way and the financial pressure of the holiday season might limit sales, said Grzegorz Meza, an economist in the privatization ministry. ``This is the worst possible time,'' he said. ``But even if people are not experienced in investment, we think Poles will think this is going to be good business.''

DOC.HEAD: GM Cuts Indiana Production
With AM-GM-Stempel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 360 workers at General Motors Corp.'s Fort Wayne Assembly Plant will be laid off indefinitely Jan. 14. Keri Hulsey, assistant public affairs director for the company's truck and bus division, said the plant is cutting production to reduce a growing surplus of CK trucks. ``We are bringing our production in line with the sales of the vehicles,'' she said. ``Many of our plants are facing the same type of situation.'' The announcement came a day after Robert C. Stempel, GM chairman, delivered a speech in Fort Wayne announcing the nation's biggest automaker will cut fourth-quarter North American production by 110,000 units beyond an earlier 181,000 cut. Stempel said the 3,000 workers at the Fort Wayne Assembly Plant have continued to make productivity gains. Continuing progress in quality and competitiveness is ``the only real guarantee of job security for the long-term,'' he said, after touring the plant Thursday. A CK plant in Pontiac, Mich., will also lay off 350 employees the same day Fort Wayne production is curtailed. But a CK plant in Oshua, Ontario, will escape layoffs because it produces a more popular version of the truck, with an extended cab. She would not predict when sales may strengthen enough to call back workers.

DOC.HEAD: Hopes for Soviet Sales Boost Corn, Wheat Futures
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and corn futures prices closed higher Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade after President Bush said he would consider waiving U.S. export restrictions and grant food export credits to the Soviet Union. Soybean futures ended mixed as profit-taking erased gains that were posted immediately after Bush's remarks. The Soviets have been seeking export credits to enable them to buy U.S. grain, including about 1.2 million metric tons of wheat and 600,000 metric tons of corn they are obligated to purchase by year's end under a long-term grain agreement. The Bush administration has maintained it cannot grant export credits without violating a 1974 law that denies the Soviets coveted most-favored-nation trade status because of their restrictions on emigration. But Bush told a news conference Friday that he may have clearer authority to waive the trade restrictions than he had thought, and that he would consider doing so. ``A lot of the trade now is assuming it's a done deal,'' said Dan Cekander, a grain analyst with the Chicago trading company Rodman & Renshaw Inc. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to 6{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.45{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2{ cents higher with December at $2.27{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 4 cents higher with December at $1.11\ a bushel; soybeans were 4} cents lower to 2{ cents higher with January at $5.90 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls Sharply On Bush Hint of Diplomacy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES in lede, graf 4, with oil falling more than $4
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices tumbled more than $4 per barrel today as President Bush held out the possibility of a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Contracts for light sweet crude fell more than $1 per barrel in a span of several minutes while Bush was on television giving his assessment of the crisis. His remarks followed a vote late Thursday in which the U.N. Security Council authorized the use of force to push Iraqi troops out of oil-rich Kuwait if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein does not withdraw them by Jan. 15. Crude then kept falling sharply, sinking below the $30 per barrel threshold, after Bush's news conference had ended. By late afternoon, contracts for crude delivery in January were down $4.21 per barrel, at $28.70, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil's biggest move during the crisis was a fall of $5.41 per barrel on Oct. 22. Contracts for crude delivery in several later months were down by their daily limit of $1.50 per barrel. Bush said he would invite Iraqi's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, to come to Washington in December to discuss the situation. Bush also mentioned the possibility that he would send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. ``The reaction is very much to his inviting Tariq Aziz to Washington and Baker to Baghdad,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The market had moved up earlier in the week in anticipation of the U.N. resolution, so Bush's comments indicating that he would send troops into combat if necessary did not move the market. The president said he would accept nothing less than a complete withdrawal of Iraqi troops and freedom for hostages held by Saddam. ``This has been a war premium market,'' Hittle said. ``We rose on expectation of the U.N. resolution being passed. With his comment today, we're losing that war premium and backing off.'' As oil plummeted, prices for refined petroleum products also fell. By early afternoon, home heating oil was down 6.42 cents at 87.10 cents a gallon on December delivery contracts. Unleaded gasoline fell 5.12 cents a gallon to 78.25 cents on December delivery contracts. Some of the contracts for product delivery in later months were down by their daily limit of 4 cents a gallon. Natural gas was off 7.5 cents at $2.415 per 1,000 cubic feet on contracts for delivery in January.

DOC.HEAD: Stock, Bond Prices Leap, Oil Prices Plummet On Bush's Comments, Economic News
DOC.TEXT: Stock and bond prices climbed sharply Friday and oil prices fell after comments by President Bush led to renewed hope that the Iraqi stalemate could be resolved peacefully and that interest rates could fall. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 43.32 points to 2,562.13 an hour before the 4 p.m. EST closing bell. The price of oil tumbled more than $4 a barrel as fear of war in the Mideast oil fields eased. Government bond prices also rallied. At a midmornig news conference, Bush said he said remains ``hopeful we can achieve a peaceful solution to this crisis.'' Bush said he would send Secretary of State James Baker to Baghdad to meet with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and suggested that Iraq's foreign mininster visit Washington for discussions. The president also added his voice to the growing belief that the nation's economy has entered an major slump. ``Our economy, as I said the other day, is at best in a serious slowdown. And if uncertainty remains in the energy markets, the slowdown will get worse,'' he said. Those comments compounded government figures released Friday morning that also indicated a looming recession. The Commerce Department said its Index of Leading Economic Indicators fell 1.2 percent in October on top of three previous monthly declines including July, when the index was first reported to have been flat. Three consecutive declines in the forward-looking index are considered a fairly reliable sign that a recession is near. News of an economic downturn makes it more likely the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates, which is good for both the stock and bond markets. The price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond was up a full point by midafternoon. A point equals a $10 change in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
